paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter RUMOR all painted with tongues$NEWLINE$RUMOR
paragraphs.translated: RUMOR enters, wearing a costume covered with painted tongues.$NEWLINE$RUMOR

paragraphs.original: RUMOR$NEWLINE$Open your ears, for which of you will stop$NEWLINE$The vent of hearing when loud Rumor speaks?$NEWLINE$I, from the orient to the drooping west,$NEWLINE$Making the wind my post-horse, still unfold$NEWLINE$The acts commenced on this ball of earth.$NEWLINE$Upon my tongues continual slanders ride,$NEWLINE$The which in every language I pronounce,$NEWLINE$Stuffing the ears of men with false reports.$NEWLINE$I speak of peace while covert enmity$NEWLINE$Under the smile of safety wounds the world.$NEWLINE$And who but Rumor, who but only I,$NEWLINE$Make fearful musters and prepared defense,$NEWLINE$Whiles the big year, swoll'n with some other grief,$NEWLINE$Is thought with child by the stern tyrant war,$NEWLINE$And no such matter? Rumor is a pipe$NEWLINE$Blown by surmises, jealousies, conjectures,$NEWLINE$And of so easy and so plain a stop$NEWLINE$That the blunt monster with uncounted heads,$NEWLINE$The still-discordant wav'ring multitude,$NEWLINE$Can play upon it. But what need I thus$NEWLINE$My well-known body to anatomize$NEWLINE$Among my household? Why is Rumor here?$NEWLINE$I run before King Harry’s victory,$NEWLINE$Who in a bloody field by Shrewsbury$NEWLINE$Hath beaten down young Hotspur and his troops,$NEWLINE$Quenching the flame of bold rebellion$NEWLINE$Even with the rebels' blood. But what mean I$NEWLINE$To speak so true at first? My office is$NEWLINE$To noise abroad that Harry Monmouth fell
paragraphs.translated: RUMOR$NEWLINE$Open your ears! For who could possibly block them when loud Rumor speaks? I make the wind my horse, and ride it from the Orient in the east to the place where the sun sets in the west, describing the events taking place in the world. I continually tell lies and I tell them in every language, stuffing men’s ears with falsehoods. I say that things are peaceful when, in reality, concealed hatred is at work, hidden behind smiles of good will.$NEWLINE$And who but Rumor—who besides me—can make armies prepare anxious defenses, when in fact the world is uneasy for other reasons and there’s no war coming at all? Rumor is like a flute. Guesswork, suspicion, and speculation are the breath that makes it sound, and it’s so easy to play that even the common masses—that dim monster with innumerable heads, forever clamoring and wavering—can play it. But why should I describe myself in such detail to the one group of people who knows exactly what falsehood is all about: a theater audience? Why am I here?$NEWLINE$King Henry has won the war, and at Shrewsbury, he ended the rebellion against him by defeating Hotspur and his allies, quenching the fire of revolt with the rebels' own blood. But what am I doing, telling you the truth up front? My job is to spread word that Hotspur in his fury killed Prince Hal, and that Douglas killed the King. I’ve spread this rumor through all the peasant

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Under the wrath of noble Hotspur’s sword,$NEWLINE$And that the King before the Douglas' rage$NEWLINE$Stooped his anointed head as low as death.$NEWLINE$This have I rumored through the peasant towns$NEWLINE$Between that royal field of Shrewsbury$NEWLINE$And this worm-eaten hold of ragged stone,$NEWLINE$Where Hotspur’s father, old Northumberland,$NEWLINE$Lies crafty-sick. The posts come tiring on,$NEWLINE$And not a man of them brings other news$NEWLINE$Than they have learnt of me. From Rumor’s tongues$NEWLINE$They bring smooth comforts false, worse than true wrongs.
paragraphs.translated: villages from Shrewsbury to the place where I now stand: in front of the worm-eaten, dilapidated castle of Northumberland, Hotspur’s father, who lies within and pretends to be sick.$NEWLINE$The messengers are coming hot and heavy, and every single one of them will report nothing but what he’s heard from me. Straight from Rumor, they bring pretty tales of false comfort, which are far worse than truthful news of misfortune.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: RUMOR exits.$NEWLINE$RUMOR

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter LORD BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$LORD BARDOLPH
paragraphs.translated: LORD BARDOLPH enters.$NEWLINE$LORD BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: LORD BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Who keeps the gate here, ho?
paragraphs.translated: LORD BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Hello? Who’s the doorman around here?

paragraphs.original: Enter the PORTER$NEWLINE$PORTER
paragraphs.translated:
The
PORTER opens the door.$NEWLINE$PORTER$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: Where is the Earl?
paragraphs.translated: (to the PORTER) Where’s the Earl?$NEWLINE$to the$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: PORTER$NEWLINE$What shall I say you are?
paragraphs.translated: PORTER$NEWLINE$Who shall I say you are?

paragraphs.original: LORD BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Tell thou the Earl$NEWLINE$That the Lord Bardolph doth attend him here.
paragraphs.translated: LORD BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Tell the Earl that the Lord Bardolph is here to see him.

paragraphs.original: PORTER$NEWLINE$His lordship is walked forth into the orchard.$NEWLINE$Please it your Honor knock but at the gate$NEWLINE$And he himself will answer.
paragraphs.translated: PORTER$NEWLINE$His lordship is out walking in the orchard. If you don’t mind, knock at the orchard gate and he’ll answer it himself.

paragraphs.original: NORTHUMBERLAND Enter$NEWLINE$NORTHUMBERLAND
paragraphs.translated: NORTHUMBERLAND enters from another side of the stage.$NEWLINE$NORTHUMBERLAND

paragraphs.original: LORD BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Here comes the Earl.
paragraphs.translated: LORD BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Here comes the Earl.

paragraphs.original: Exit PORTER$NEWLINE$PORTER
paragraphs.translated: The PORTER exits.$NEWLINE$PORTER

paragraphs.original: NORTHUMBERLAND$NEWLINE$What news, Lord Bardolph? Every minute now$NEWLINE$Should be the father of some stratagem.$NEWLINE$The times are wild. Contention, like a horse$NEWLINE$Full of high feeding, madly hath broke loose$NEWLINE$And bears down all before him.
paragraphs.translated: NORTHUMBERLAND$NEWLINE$What’s the news, Lord Bardolph? Every minute, new violence erupts; it is a wild time. Conflict is like a horse, fed with too much rich food: it has broken out uncontrollably, and tramples everyone who stands before it.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: LORD BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Noble Earl,$NEWLINE$I bring you certain news from Shrewsbury.
paragraphs.translated: LORD BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Noble Earl, I have reliable news from Shrewsbury.

paragraphs.original: NORTHUMBERLAND$NEWLINE$Good, an God will!
paragraphs.translated: NORTHUMBERLAND$NEWLINE$Good news, God willing.

paragraphs.original: LORD BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$As good as heart can wish.$NEWLINE$The King is almost wounded to the death,$NEWLINE$And, in the fortune of my lord your son,$NEWLINE$Prince Harry slain outright; and both the Blunts$NEWLINE$Killed by the hand of Douglas; young Prince John$NEWLINE$And Westmoreland and Stafford fled the field;$NEWLINE$And Harry Monmouth’s brawn, the hulk Sir John,$NEWLINE$Is prisoner to your son. O, such a day,$NEWLINE$So fought, so followed, and so fairly won,$NEWLINE$Came not till now to dignify the times$NEWLINE$Since Caesar’s fortunes.
paragraphs.translated: LORD BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$As good as one could wish for. The King has been wounded and is near death. And, thanks to your son’s luck, Prince Harry has been killed. Douglas killed both Lords Blunt. Prince John of Lancaster, Westmoreland, and Stafford fled the battlefield. And your son captured that hulking Sir John Falstaff, Prince Harry’s fattened pig. Oh, there hasn’t been a battle so well fought or a victory so well won since the days of Julius Caesar! It brings honor to our times.

paragraphs.original: NORTHUMBERLAND$NEWLINE$How is this derived?$NEWLINE$Saw you the field? Came you from Shrewsbury?
paragraphs.translated: NORTHUMBERLAND$NEWLINE$How do you know all this? Did you see the battlefield? Did you come from Shrewsbury?

paragraphs.original: LORD BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$I spake with one, my lord, that came from thence,$NEWLINE$A gentleman well bred and of good name,$NEWLINE$That freely rendered me these news for true.
paragraphs.translated: LORD BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$I talked with someone, my lord, who was coming from there. He was a gentleman, with good breeding and a good reputation. He swore that all this was the truth.

paragraphs.original: NORTHUMBERLAND$NEWLINE$Here comes my servant Travers, who I sent$NEWLINE$On Tuesday last to listen after news.
paragraphs.translated: NORTHUMBERLAND$NEWLINE$Here comes my servant, Travers. I sent him last Tuesday to find out what was happening.

paragraphs.original: Enter TRAVERS$NEWLINE$TRAVERS
paragraphs.translated: TRAVERS enters.$NEWLINE$TRAVERS

paragraphs.original: LORD BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$My lord, I overrode him on the way;$NEWLINE$And he is furnished with no certainties$NEWLINE$More than he haply may retail from me.
paragraphs.translated: LORD BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Sir, I passed him on my way here. He doesn’t know anything more than what I told him.

paragraphs.original: NORTHUMBERLAND$NEWLINE$Now, Travers, what good tidings comes with you?
paragraphs.translated: NORTHUMBERLAND$NEWLINE$Now Travers, what good news do you have?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: TRAVERS$NEWLINE$My lord, Sir John Umfrevile turned me back$NEWLINE$With joyful tidings and, being better horsed,$NEWLINE$Outrode me. After him came spurring hard$NEWLINE$A gentleman, almost forspent with speed,$NEWLINE$That stopp’d by me to breathe his bloodied horse.$NEWLINE$He asked the way to Chester, and of him$NEWLINE$I did demand what news from Shrewsbury.$NEWLINE$He told me that rebellion had bad luck$NEWLINE$And that young Harry Percy’s spur was cold.$NEWLINE$With that he gave his able horse the head$NEWLINE$And, bending forward, struck his armèd heels$NEWLINE$Against the panting sides of his poor jade$NEWLINE$Up to the rowel-head, and starting so$NEWLINE$He seemed in running to devour the way,$NEWLINE$Staying no longer question.
paragraphs.translated:
TRAVERS$NEWLINE$Sir,
Lord Bardolph told me happy news and I turned around, to come back here. But he had a faster horse, so he passed me and got here first.$NEWLINE$Lord$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$Another man came after him, riding hard. He was nearly exhausted from going so fast, and he stopped to give his bleeding horse a break. He asked me for directions to Chester, and I demanded to hear news from Shrewsbury. He said that the rebels had been beaten, and that Harry Percy’s spur was cold. Then he took off on his horse, leaned forward in his saddle, and jammed his heels into the animal’s side so hard that they almost disappeared. He rode so fast he seemed to be devouring the highway. He didn’t stay around to answer any of my questions.

paragraphs.original: NORTHUMBERLAND$NEWLINE$Ha? Again:$NEWLINE$Said he young Harry Percy’s spur was cold?$NEWLINE$Of Hotspur, Coldspur? That rebellion$NEWLINE$Had met ill luck?
paragraphs.translated: NORTHUMBERLAND$NEWLINE$What? Say that again: he said that Harry Percy’s spur was cold? Hotspur is now “Coldspur?” That the rebels had bad luck?

paragraphs.original: LORD BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$My lord, I’ll tell you what:$NEWLINE$If my young lord your son have not the day,$NEWLINE$Upon mine honor, for a silken point$NEWLINE$I’ll give my barony. Never talk of it.
paragraphs.translated: LORD BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$My lord, I’ll tell you what—if your son hasn’t won, on my honor, I’ll exchange all my land for a lace to tie stockings with; don’t even say such a thing.

paragraphs.original: NORTHUMBERLAND$NEWLINE$Why should that gentleman that rode by Travers$NEWLINE$Give then such instances of loss?
paragraphs.translated: NORTHUMBERLAND$NEWLINE$But why would that gentleman who rode past Travers describe such examples of loss?

paragraphs.original: LORD BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Who, he?$NEWLINE$He was some hilding fellow that had stolen$NEWLINE$The horse he rode on and, upon my life,$NEWLINE$Spoke at a venture. Look, here comes more news.
paragraphs.translated: LORD BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Who, him? He was some insignificant nobody who stole the horse he was riding and, I bet my life, was just talking nonsense. Look, here comes another messenger.

paragraphs.original: Enter MORTON$NEWLINE$MORTON
paragraphs.translated: MORTON enters.$NEWLINE$MORTON

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: NORTHUMBERLAND$NEWLINE$Yea, this man’s brow, like to a title leaf,$NEWLINE$Foretells the nature of a tragic volume.$NEWLINE$So looks the strand whereon the imperious flood$NEWLINE$Hath left a witness’d usurpation.—$NEWLINE$Say, Morton, didst thou come from Shrewsbury?
paragraphs.translated: NORTHUMBERLAND$NEWLINE$Yes. And the look on his face is like the title page of a book: it hints at the tragic story within. His brow is lined with furrows, like a beach after a wild flood. Morton, did you come from Shrewsbury?

paragraphs.original: MORTON$NEWLINE$I ran from Shrewsbury, my noble lord,$NEWLINE$Where hateful death put on his ugliest mask$NEWLINE$To fright our party.
paragraphs.translated: MORTON$NEWLINE$I ran from Shrewsbury, my noble lord. Death was there, frightening our side with his ugliest mask.

paragraphs.original: NORTHUMBERLAND$NEWLINE$How doth my son and brother?$NEWLINE$Thou tremblest, and the whiteness in thy cheek$NEWLINE$Is apter than thy tongue to tell thy errand.$NEWLINE$Even such a man, so faint, so spiritless,$NEWLINE$So dull, so dead in look, so woebegone,$NEWLINE$Drew Priam’s curtain in the dead of night,$NEWLINE$And would have told him half his Troy was burnt;$NEWLINE$But Priam found the fire ere he his tongue,$NEWLINE$And I my Percy’s death ere thou report’st it.$NEWLINE$This thou wouldst say, “Your son did thus and thus;$NEWLINE$Your brother thus; so fought the noble Douglas”—$NEWLINE$Stopping my greedy ear with their bold deeds.$NEWLINE$But in the end, to stop my ear indeed,$NEWLINE$Thou hast a sigh to blow away this praise,$NEWLINE$Ending with “Brother, son, and all are dead.”
paragraphs.translated: NORTHUMBERLAND$NEWLINE$How are my son and my brother? You’re trembling, and the paleness of your face is more likely to convey your news than your tongue. This is like that old story about the burning of Troy. A man like you—faint, lifeless, dull, deadly-looking, sad—woke King Priam in the dead of night to tell him that half the city of Troy had been burned down. But Priam saw the fire before this man could speak, and I can see my Percy’s death before you report it. You’re going to tell me, “Your son did such-and-such; your brother did this; the noble Douglas fought like so.” You’ll stuff my greedy ears with stories of their bold deeds. But in the end, you’ll stop my ears forever with a sigh that blows away all your words of praise. You will end your story by saying, “Your brother, your son, everyone-dead.”

paragraphs.original: MORTON$NEWLINE$Douglas is living, and your brother yet,$NEWLINE$But for my lord your son—
paragraphs.translated: MORTON$NEWLINE$Douglas is alive, and so is your brother, for now. But as for your son, my lord—

paragraphs.original: NORTHUMBERLAND$NEWLINE$Why, he is dead.$NEWLINE$See what a ready tongue suspicion hath!$NEWLINE$He that but fears the thing he would not know$NEWLINE$Hath, by instinct, knowledge from others' eyes$NEWLINE$That what he feared is chancèd. Yet speak, Morton.$NEWLINE$Tell thou an earl his divination lies,
paragraphs.translated: NORTHUMBERLAND$NEWLINE$Why, he is dead. My suspicion is so quick to speak! When a man fears something, and doesn’t want to know the truth, he can still tell when that thing has happened; by instinct, he can read it in another man’s eyes. But speak, Morton. Tell me, who am an earl, that I have

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: And I will take it as a sweet disgrace$NEWLINE$And make thee rich for doing me such wrong.
paragraphs.translated: no talent for prophecy. I’ll take it as a pleasant insult, and I’ll pay you richly for doing me that wrong.

paragraphs.original: MORTON$NEWLINE$You are too great to be by me gainsaid,$NEWLINE$Your spirit is too true, your fears too certain.
paragraphs.translated: MORTON$NEWLINE$You are too great a man to be slandered by me. Your instinct is correct; your fears are true.

paragraphs.original: NORTHUMBERLAND$NEWLINE$Yet, for all this, say not that Percy’s dead.$NEWLINE$I see a strange confession in thine eye.$NEWLINE$Thou shak’st thy head and hold’st it fear or sin$NEWLINE$To speak a truth. If he be slain, say so.$NEWLINE$The tongue offends not that reports his death;$NEWLINE$And he doth sin that doth belie the dead,$NEWLINE$Not he which says the dead is not alive.$NEWLINE$Yet the first bringer of unwelcome news$NEWLINE$Hath but a losing office, and his tongue$NEWLINE$Sounds ever after as a sullen bell$NEWLINE$Remembered tolling a departing friend.
paragraphs.translated: NORTHUMBERLAND$NEWLINE$But despite all this, don’t say that Percy’s dead. I can see a strange sort of confession in your eyes. You shake your head; you’re afraid to tell the truth, or you think it would be sinful. If he’s been killed, say so. The man who reports a death doesn’t offend with that report. To lie about the dead is a sin, but it is no sin to say that a dead man is not alive. It’s a losing situation, being the first man to bring unwelcome news. That man’s voice sounds forever like a sad bell, and it will always be remembered for tolling the death of a friend.

paragraphs.original: LORD BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$I cannot think, my lord, your son is dead.
paragraphs.translated: LORD BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$My lord, I cannot believe your son is dead.

paragraphs.original: MORTON$NEWLINE$I am sorry I should force you to believe$NEWLINE$That which I would to God I had not seen,$NEWLINE$But these mine eyes saw him in bloody state,$NEWLINE$Rend'ring faint quittance, wearied and outbreathed,$NEWLINE$To Harry Monmouth; whose swift wrath beat down$NEWLINE$The never-daunted Percy to the earth,$NEWLINE$From whence with life he never more sprung up.$NEWLINE$In few, his death, whose spirit lent a fire$NEWLINE$Even to the dullest peasant in his camp,$NEWLINE$Being bruited once, took fire and heat away$NEWLINE$From the best tempered courage in his troops;$NEWLINE$For from his metal was his party steeled,$NEWLINE$Which, once in him abated, all the rest$NEWLINE$Turned on themselves, like dull and heavy lead.$NEWLINE$And as the thing that’s heavy in itself$NEWLINE$Upon enforcement flies with greatest speed,
paragraphs.translated: MORTON$NEWLINE$I’m sorry that I must force you to believe this, when I wish to God that I hadn’t seen it myself. But I saw him, in his bloody state, with my own eyes. He was barely able to fight back, exhausted and out of breath. Harry Monmouth’s swift fury beat the unflinching Percy down to the ground, and once he was there, Percy never rose again. To be brief, Percy’s spirit inspired the entire army, down to the dullest peasant. When the news got out that he had been killed, it took the fire and courage away from even the bravest soldiers. Percy’s metal steeled the whole army; when they learned that he had been blunted, they bent and warped like dull, heavy lead.$NEWLINE$And just as a heavy object gains momentum once it’s pushed into motion, our army, made heavy by

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: So did our men, heavy in Hotspur’s loss,$NEWLINE$Lend to this weight such lightness with their fear$NEWLINE$That arrows fled not swifter toward their aim$NEWLINE$Than did our soldiers, aiming at their safety,$NEWLINE$Fly from the field. Then was the noble Worcester$NEWLINE$Too soon ta'en prisoner; and that furious Scot,$NEWLINE$The bloody Douglas, whose well-laboring sword$NEWLINE$Had three times slain th'appearance of the King,$NEWLINE$Gan vail his stomach and did grace the shame$NEWLINE$Of those that turned their backs and in his flight,$NEWLINE$Stumbling in fear, was took. The sum of all$NEWLINE$Is that the King hath won and hath sent out$NEWLINE$A speedy power to encounter you, my lord,$NEWLINE$Under the conduct of young Lancaster$NEWLINE$And Westmoreland. This is the news at full.
paragraphs.translated: Hotspur’s death, suddenly started moving fast—faster than arrows flying toward a target—but they flew toward safety, not toward the battle. Soon, Worcester, that furious Scotsman, was captured. The warlike Douglas, who killed three enemies disguised as King Henry, began to lose courage: he ran away as well, lending his authority to the shameful retreat. But running in fear, he stumbled and was captured.$NEWLINE$The bottom line is that King Henry has won. He’s sent a speedy force after you, sir, led by young John of Lancaster and Westmoreland. That is the whole story.

paragraphs.original: NORTHUMBERLAND$NEWLINE$For this I shall have time enough to mourn.$NEWLINE$In poison there is physic, and these news,$NEWLINE$Having been well, that would have made me sick,$NEWLINE$Being sick, have in some measure made me well.$NEWLINE$And as the wretch whose fever-weakened joints,$NEWLINE$Like strengthless hinges, buckle under life,$NEWLINE$Impatient of his fit, breaks like a fire$NEWLINE$Out of his keeper’s arms, even so my limbs,$NEWLINE$Weakened with grief, being now enraged with grief,$NEWLINE$Are thrice themselves. Hence therefore, thou nice crutch.$NEWLINE$A scaly gauntlet now with joints of steel$NEWLINE$Must glove this hand. And hence, thou sickly coif.$NEWLINE$Thou art a guard too wanton for the head$NEWLINE$Which princes, fleshed with conquest, aim to hit.$NEWLINE$Now bind my brows with iron, and approach$NEWLINE$The ragged’st hour that time and spite dare bring$NEWLINE$To frown upon th'enraged Northumberland.$NEWLINE$Let heaven kiss earth! Now let not Nature’s hand$NEWLINE$Keep the wild flood confined. Let order die,$NEWLINE$And let this world no longer be a stage
paragraphs.translated: NORTHUMBERLAND$NEWLINE$There will be time to mourn for this. Sometimes poison can be a kind of medicine: this news, which would have made me sick had I been well, has, because I am sick, made me well. A dying man—his joints weakened by fever, dangling like useless hinges and crumpling under the man’s own weight—will sometimes be stuck with a fit of impatience, causing him to burst out of his caretaker’s arms. My limbs are like that now; once weakened by grief, they’re now enraged by grief, and are three times as powerful as they were before. Away from me, you unmanly crutch! Chain mail armor will cover my hands now. Away from me, you invalid’s cap! You are too fanciful a helmet for this head which is now the target of kings, grown arrogant with their victories. Wrap my head in iron, and then attack me with the roughest things that destiny and hatred will dare to bring upon me in my rage. Let the sky come crashing down! Let the ocean overflow the shores! Let law and order die! And let the world no longer be a stage for a long, drawn-out struggle: let the spirit of

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: To feed contention in a lingering act;$NEWLINE$But let one spirit of the firstborn Cain$NEWLINE$Reign in all bosoms, that, each heart being set$NEWLINE$On bloody courses, the rude scene may end,$NEWLINE$And darkness be the burier of the dead.
paragraphs.translated: Cain, who committed the first murder against his brother Abel, live in every heart. If every heart is a murderer’s heart, this violent play will end, and darkness will shroud the corpses.

paragraphs.original: LORD BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$This strainèd passion doth you wrong, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: LORD BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$This extreme passion is bad for you, sir.

paragraphs.original: MORTON$NEWLINE$Sweet Earl, divorce not wisdom from your honor.$NEWLINE$The lives of all your loving complices$NEWLINE$Lean on your health, the which, if you give o'er$NEWLINE$To stormy passion, must perforce decay.$NEWLINE$You cast th' event of war, my noble lord,$NEWLINE$And summed the account of chance before you said$NEWLINE$“Let us make head.” It was your presurmise$NEWLINE$That, in the dole of blows your son might drop.$NEWLINE$You knew he walked o'er perils on an edge,$NEWLINE$More likely to fall in than to get o'er.$NEWLINE$You were advised his flesh was capable$NEWLINE$Of wounds and scars, and that his forward spirit$NEWLINE$Would lift him where most trade of danger ranged.$NEWLINE$Yet did you say “Go forth,” and none of this,$NEWLINE$Though strongly apprehended, could restrain$NEWLINE$The stiff-borne action. What hath then befall'n,$NEWLINE$Or what did this bold enterprise brought forth,$NEWLINE$More than that being which was like to be?
paragraphs.translated: MORTON$NEWLINE$Gentle Earl, don’t abandon your wisdom. All your allies are depending on you and your well-being. If you allow yourself to indulge in this kind of stormy emotion, your health will deteriorate even further. Before you said, “Let’s raise an army,” you calculated how the war might end, and you thought carefully about the likeliness of a victory. You knew from the beginning that, once the fighting started, your son might die. You knew that he was treading dangerously, as if on the edge of a precipice: you knew he was more likely to fall over than make it across. You were warned that your son was made of flesh and blood, and that it was possible he’d get hurt. You were warned that his temper and hot-headedness would push him into the most dangerous situations. But you still said, “Go forward.” None of this consideration, even though it was clearly understood, could stop the stubborn course of events. So what happened here? What has been the result of this brave undertaking? Only this: precisely what was likely to happen in the first place.

paragraphs.original: LORD BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$We all that are engagèd to this loss$NEWLINE$Knew that we ventured on such dangerous seas$NEWLINE$That if we wrought out life, ’twas ten to one;$NEWLINE$And yet we ventured, for the gain proposed$NEWLINE$Choked the respect of likely peril feared;
paragraphs.translated: LORD BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$We all knew that we were venturing into dangerous waters. We knew the odds were ten to one that we would come out alive, and yet we ventured forward anyway. The potential reward of winning outweighed the fear of our probable loss.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: And since we are o'erset, venture again.$NEWLINE$Come, we will all put forth, body and goods.
paragraphs.translated: We lost this time, but let’s try again. Come, we’ll all go for it, body and soul.

paragraphs.original: MORTON$NEWLINE$'Tis more than time.—And, my most noble lord,$NEWLINE$I hear for certain, and do speak the truth:$NEWLINE$The gentle Archbishop of York is up$NEWLINE$With well-appointed powers. He is a man$NEWLINE$Who with a double surety binds his followers.$NEWLINE$My lord your son had only but the corpse,$NEWLINE$But shadows and the shows of men, to fight;$NEWLINE$For that same word “rebellion” did divide$NEWLINE$The action of their bodies from their souls,$NEWLINE$And they did fight with queasiness, constrained,$NEWLINE$As men drink potions, that their weapons only$NEWLINE$Seemed on our side. But, for their spirits and souls,$NEWLINE$This word “rebellion,” it had froze them up$NEWLINE$As fish are in a pond. But now the Bishop$NEWLINE$Turns insurrection to religion.$NEWLINE$Supposed sincere and holy in his thoughts,$NEWLINE$He’s followed both with body and with mind,$NEWLINE$And doth enlarge his rising with the blood$NEWLINE$Of fair King Richard, scraped from Pomfret stones;$NEWLINE$Derives from heaven his quarrel and his cause;$NEWLINE$Tells them he doth bestride a bleeding land,$NEWLINE$Gasping for life under great Bolingbroke;$NEWLINE$And more and less do flock to follow him.
paragraphs.translated: MORTON$NEWLINE$It is the appropriate time. Good sir, I hear for certain, and I tell you truthfully, that the Archbishop of York has raised a powerful army. He motivates his men with both his earthly and his spiritual powers. My lord, your son commanded only his soldiers' bodies. The word “rebellion” frightened them, separating their bodies from their hearts. It caused them to fight timidly, hesitantly, as though they were taking medicine: their weapons seemed to be on our side, but their spirits and souls were frozen, like fish in an icy pond. But now, the Archbishop turns our rebellion into a religious cause. Everyone believes he’s a righteous and holy man, and they follow him not only in body but also in mind. He enhances his cause by preaching about the blood of good King Richard, which was spilled at Pomfret Castle. The Archbishop claims that he derives his authority from heaven; tells the men that the whole country is bleeding, gasping for life under the terrible leadership of Bolingbroke. And so men from every walk of life flock like sheep to follow him.

paragraphs.original: NORTHUMBERLAND$NEWLINE$I knew of this before, but, to speak truth,$NEWLINE$This present grief had wiped it from my mind.$NEWLINE$Go in with me and counsel every man$NEWLINE$The aptest way for safety and revenge.$NEWLINE$Get posts and letters, and make friends with speed.$NEWLINE$Never so few, and never yet more need.
paragraphs.translated: NORTHUMBERLAND$NEWLINE$I knew all this, but to tell you the truth, this terrible grief had pushed it out of my thoughts. Come inside; I want to hear everyone’s ideas on the best way to defend ourselves and enact our revenge. Send out messengers and letters, and make new allies quickly. Our numbers have never been smaller, but there’s never been more need for what we have to do.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter Sir John FALSTAFF, with his PAGE bearing his sword and buckler$NEWLINE$FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$PAGE
paragraphs.translated:
Sir John FALSTAFF enters with his
PAGE, who carries a sword and shield.$NEWLINE$FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$PAGE$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Sirrah, you giant, what says the doctor to my water?
paragraphs.translated:
FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Sirrah, you
giant, what did the doctor say about my urine?$NEWLINE$Sirrah$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$giant$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: PAGE$NEWLINE$He said, sir, the water itself was a good healthy water, but,$NEWLINE$for the party that owed it, he might have more diseases than$NEWLINE$he knew for.
paragraphs.translated: PAGE$NEWLINE$He said that the urine itself was good, healthy urine, but that the man who owned it probably had more diseases than he could tell.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Men of all sorts take a pride to gird at me. The brain of this$NEWLINE$foolish-compounded clay, man, is not able to invent$NEWLINE$anything that tends to laughter more than I invent, or is$NEWLINE$invented on me. I am not only witty in myself, but the cause$NEWLINE$that wit is in other men. I do here walk before thee like a sow that hath$NEWLINE$overwhelmed all her litter but one. If the Prince put$NEWLINE$thee into my service for any other reason than to set me off,$NEWLINE$why then I have no judgment. Thou whoreson mandrake,$NEWLINE$thou art fitter to be worn in my cap than to wait at my heels.$NEWLINE$I was never manned with an agate till now, but I will inset$NEWLINE$you neither in gold nor silver, but in vile apparel, and send$NEWLINE$you back again to your master for a jewel. The juvenal, the$NEWLINE$Prince your master, whose chin is not yet fledge—I will$NEWLINE$sooner have a beard grow in the palm of my hand than he$NEWLINE$shall get one off his cheek, and yet he will not stick to say$NEWLINE$his face is a face royal. God may finish it when He will. 'Tis$NEWLINE$not a hair amiss yet. He may keep it still at a face royal, for$NEWLINE$a barber shall never earn sixpence out of it, and yet he’ll be$NEWLINE$crowing as if he had writ man ever since his father was$NEWLINE$a bachelor. He may keep his own grace, but he’s almost out of
paragraphs.translated:
FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$All kinds of people make it a matter of pride to heckle me. No man—that foolishly assembled lump of clay—could ever invent something quite as funny as I seem to be to other people. I’m not only witty on my own, but I bring out wit in other people. Look at the two of us, walking here: I look like a sow that’s smothered all of her baby pigs, except for you. If the Prince sent you to serve me for any other reason than to irritate me, I’m a fool. You weedy little son of a bitch: you’re so tiny that you should be a decoration on my hat, not a servant at my feet. I’ve never had a servant before who was as tiny as a ring stone. But I won’t set you in a gold or silver ring; I’ll wrap you in rags and send you back to your master, to be used as a jewel—that youth, the Prince your master, whose chin is still lacking a beard. Why, I’ll grow a beard in the palm of my hand before he’ll have one that he can shave off his face. And yet, this doesn’t stop him from claiming that he has a face for
royalty. Well, God will give him a beard whenever he chooses to—there’s not a hair out of place yet. It’s a good thing the Prince’s face is a royal, because a barber will never earn a coin from shaving it. And still, the$NEWLINE$royalty$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: mine, I can assure him. What said Master Dommelton about$NEWLINE$the satin for my short cloak and my slops?
paragraphs.translated: Prince brags that he’s been a full-grown man since before he was born. He can keep that title, for all I care; I have no affection for him now, I can assure him. What did Master Dommelton say about the satin for my cape and baggy trousers?

paragraphs.original: PAGE$NEWLINE$He said, sir, you should procure him better assurance than$NEWLINE$Bardolph. He would not take his band and yours. He liked$NEWLINE$not the security.
paragraphs.translated: PAGE$NEWLINE$He said that you have to give him a better guarantee of payment than just saying Bardolph was good for it. He wouldn’t accept Bardolph’s promise or yours; he felt that neither should be trusted.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Let him be damned like the glutton! Pray God his tongue be$NEWLINE$hotter! A whoreson Achitophel, a rascally yea-forsooth$NEWLINE$knave, to bear a gentleman in hand and then stand upon$NEWLINE$security! The whoreson smoothy-pates do now wear$NEWLINE$nothing but high shoes and bunches of keys at their girdles;$NEWLINE$and if a man is through with them in honest taking up, then$NEWLINE$they must stand upon security. I had as lief they would put$NEWLINE$ratsbane in my mouth as offer to stop it with “security.” I$NEWLINE$looked he should have sent me two-and-twenty yards of$NEWLINE$satin, as I am a true knight, and he sends me “security.” Well,$NEWLINE$he may sleep in security, for he hath the horn of abundance,$NEWLINE$and the lightness of his wife shines through it, and yet cannot$NEWLINE$he see though he have his own lantern to light him.$NEWLINE$Where’s$NEWLINE$Bardolph?
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Damn him to hell then, just like Dives in the Bible—the rich glutton who rejected the beggar Lazarus! And may Dommelton burn even hotter! He’s a son-of-a-bitch traitor! A two-faced liar, who smiles and says “Yes sir, that’ll be fine” to my face, and then demands a guarantee of payment! These bastard shopkeepers, with their fashionable short haircuts, and fancy shoes, and their fat key chains on their belts—you make an agreement to put something on credit, and then they throw a “guarantee of payment” at you. I would rather eat rat poison than guarantee my payment. I expected him to send me twenty-two yards of satin, and instead he sends me a “guarantee of payment.” Well, let him guarantee himself a good night’s sleep. After all, his wife’s in somebody else’s bed, so why not? She’s practically shining a spotlight on her adultery, but he’s so clueless he can’t even tell. Where’s Bardolph?

paragraphs.original: PAGE$NEWLINE$He’s gone into Smithfield to buy your Worship a horse.
paragraphs.translated: PAGE$NEWLINE$He went to Smithfield to buy you a horse, sir.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$I bought him in Paul’s, and he’ll buy me a horse in$NEWLINE$Smithfield. An I could get me but a wife in the stews, I were$NEWLINE$manned, horsed, and wived.
paragraphs.translated:
FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$I bought Bardolph at
St. Paul’s Cathedral, and he’s buying me a horse in Smithfield. Now if he could just find me a wife in a whorehouse, I’d be fully stocked with high-quality servants, horses, and wives.$NEWLINE$St. Paul’s Cathedral$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter the Lord CHIEF JUSTICE and SERVANT$NEWLINE$CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$SERVANT
paragraphs.translated: The Lord CHIEF JUSTICE and his SERVANT enter.$NEWLINE$CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$SERVANT

paragraphs.original: PAGE$NEWLINE$Sir, here comes the nobleman that committed the Prince for striking$NEWLINE$him about Bardolph.
paragraphs.translated: PAGE$NEWLINE$Sir, here comes the man who put the Prince in jail for hitting him during that argument about Bardolph.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Wait close. I will not see him.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Hide; I don’t want to talk to him.

paragraphs.original: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$What’s he that goes there?
paragraphs.translated: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$Who is that man?

paragraphs.original: SERVANT$NEWLINE$Falstaff, an ’t please your Lordship.
paragraphs.translated: SERVANT$NEWLINE$Falstaff, if it please you, sir.

paragraphs.original: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$He that was in question for the robbery?
paragraphs.translated: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$The man who was a suspect in that robbery?

paragraphs.original: SERVANT$NEWLINE$He, my lord; but he hath since done good service at$NEWLINE$Shrewsbury, and, as I hear, is now going with some charge to the Lord John of Lancaster.
paragraphs.translated: SERVANT$NEWLINE$That’s the one. But he did good work in the Battle of Shrewsbury, and I hear he’s taking some soldiers to help Lord John of Lancaster.

paragraphs.original: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$What, to York? Call him back again.
paragraphs.translated: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$Where, to York? Tell him to come here.

paragraphs.original: SERVANT$NEWLINE$Sir John Falstaff!
paragraphs.translated: SERVANT$NEWLINE$Sir John Falstaff!

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Boy, tell him I am deaf.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Boy, tell him I’m deaf.

paragraphs.original: PAGE$NEWLINE$You must speak louder. My master is deaf.
paragraphs.translated: PAGE$NEWLINE$You have to speak up; my master is deaf.

paragraphs.original: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$I am sure he is, to the hearing of any thing good.—Go pluck$NEWLINE$him by the elbow. I must speak with him.
paragraphs.translated: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$I’m sure he is, when anything good’s being said. Go, tap him on the shoulder. I must speak with him.

paragraphs.original: SERVANT$NEWLINE$Sir John!
paragraphs.translated: SERVANT$NEWLINE$Sir John!

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$What, a young knave and begging? Is there not wars? Is$NEWLINE$there not employment? Doth not the King lack subjects? Do$NEWLINE$not the rebels need soldiers? Though it be a shame to be on$NEWLINE$any side but one, it is worse shame to beg than to be on the
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$What? A young troublemaker? A beggar? Isn’t there a war on? Isn’t there work to do? Doesn’t the King need subjects? Don’t the rebels need soldiers? Though it’s shameful to be on any side but the King’s, it’s even more shameful to be an idle beggar than a soldier on

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: worst side, were it worse than the name of rebellion can tell$NEWLINE$how to make it.
paragraphs.translated: wrong side—even if the rebellion were more despicable than the word “rebellion” already leads me to believe.

paragraphs.original: SERVANT$NEWLINE$You mistake me, sir.
paragraphs.translated: SERVANT$NEWLINE$You’re mistaken, sir.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Why sir, did I say you were an honest man? Setting my$NEWLINE$knighthood and my soldiership aside, I had lied in my throat$NEWLINE$if I had said so.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Why is that? Did I say you were an honest man? Because, setting aside the fact that I’m knight and a soldier, I’d be nothing but a liar if I said that.

paragraphs.original: SERVANT$NEWLINE$I pray you, sir, then set your knighthood and our soldiership$NEWLINE$aside, and give me leave to tell you, you lie in your throat if$NEWLINE$you say I am any other than an honest man.
paragraphs.translated: SERVANT$NEWLINE$Then please, sir, set aside your knighthood and your soldiership and let me tell you that you’re a deliberate liar, if you say I’m anything other than an honest man.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$I give thee leave to tell me so? I lay aside that which grows$NEWLINE$to me? If thou gett’st any leave of me, hang me; if thou tak’st$NEWLINE$leave, thou wert better be hanged. You hunt counter. Hence!$NEWLINE$Avaunt!
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Should I allow you to say that? Should I set aside something that’s mine by right? If I allow you anything, hang me. If you allow yourself, hang you. You’re running in the wrong direction: get out of here! Go!

paragraphs.original: SERVANT$NEWLINE$Sir, my lord would speak with you.
paragraphs.translated: SERVANT$NEWLINE$Sir, my master wants to speak with you.

paragraphs.original: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$Sir John Falstaff, a word with you.
paragraphs.translated: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$Sir John Falstaff, I’d like a word with you.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$My good lord. God give your Lordship good time of the day.$NEWLINE$I am glad to see your Lordship abroad. I heard say your$NEWLINE$Lordship was sick: I hope your Lordship goes abroad by$NEWLINE$advice. Your Lordship, though not clean past your youth,$NEWLINE$have yet some smack of an ague in you, some relish of the$NEWLINE$saltness of time in you, and I most humbly beseech your$NEWLINE$Lordship to have a reverent care of your health.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$My good sir! God grant you a good day! It’s great to see you out and about: I’d heard you were sick. I hope your doctor knows you’re out. Though you’re not entirely past your youth, your lordship, you have a touch of age in you, a touch of the passage of time, and I must humbly urge you to take good care of your health.

paragraphs.original: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$Sir John, I sent for you before your expedition to$NEWLINE$Shrewsbury.
paragraphs.translated: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$Sir John, I sent for you to come see me before you left for Shrewsbury.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$An ’t please your Lordship, I hear his Majesty is returned$NEWLINE$with some discomfort from Wales.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$If you don’t mind my saying so, I hear the King is back from Wales and it didn’t go so well.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$I talk not of his Majesty. You would not come when I sent$NEWLINE$for you.
paragraphs.translated: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$I’m not talking about the King. You didn’t come when I sent for you.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$And I hear, moreover, his Highness is fallen into this same$NEWLINE$whoreson apoplexy.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$And I also hear that the King has fallen into a terrible paralysis.

paragraphs.original: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$Well, God mend him. I pray you let me speak with you.
paragraphs.translated: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$Well, God give him a speedy recovery. Please, let me speak with you.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$This apoplexy, as I take it, is a kind of lethargy, an ’t please$NEWLINE$your Lordship, a kind of sleeping in the blood, a whoreson$NEWLINE$tingling.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$His paralysis is, as I understand it, a kind of lethargy, if it please you. It’s a sleepiness in the blood, a nasty tingling.

paragraphs.original: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$What tell you me of it? Be it as it is.
paragraphs.translated: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$Why are you telling me this? Let it be.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$It hath its original from much grief, from study, and$NEWLINE$perturbation of the brain. I have read the cause of his effects$NEWLINE$in Galen. It is a kind of deafness.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$It comes from heavy sadness; from too much reading, and too much thinking. I read about it in the reference books: it’s a kind of deafness.

paragraphs.original: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$I think you are fallen into the disease, for you hear not what$NEWLINE$I say to you.
paragraphs.translated: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$I think you must have that disease as well, because you’re not hearing a word I’m saying.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Very well, my lord, very well. Rather, an ’t please you, it is$NEWLINE$the disease of not listening, the malady of not marking, that$NEWLINE$I am troubled withal.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Very likely, my lord, very likely. But actually, sir, I have the not-listening disease; I have the not-paying-attention sickness.

paragraphs.original: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$To punish you by the heels would amend the attention of$NEWLINE$your ears, and I care not if I do become your physician.
paragraphs.translated: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$The cure for that illness would be to put you in shackles, and I wouldn’t mind being your doctor.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$I am as poor as Job, my lord, but not so patient. Your$NEWLINE$Lordship may minister the potion of imprisonment to me in$NEWLINE$respect of poverty, but how should I be your patient to follow$NEWLINE$your prescriptions, the wise may make some dram of a$NEWLINE$scruple, or indeed a scruple itself.
paragraphs.translated:
FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$I may be as poor as
Job, but I’m not as patient. You may be able to throw me in jail because of my poverty, but some people might have slight reservations about that.$NEWLINE$Job$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$I sent for you, when there were matters against you for your$NEWLINE$life, to come speak with me.
paragraphs.translated: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$I sent for you to come speak with me. There were charges against you that might have earned you the death penalty.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$As I was then advised by my learned counsel in the laws of$NEWLINE$this land-service, I did not come.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$I was advised that, since I was working for the army at the time, I shouldn’t go.

paragraphs.original: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$Well, the truth is, Sir John, you live in great infamy.
paragraphs.translated: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$The truth is, Sir John, that you are massively notorious.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$He that buckles him in my belt cannot live in less.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Anybody who wears a belt this big couldn’t be anything less than massive.

paragraphs.original: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$Your means are very slender, and your waste is great.
paragraphs.translated: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$Your bank account is thin, and yet you put it to huge waste.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$I would it were otherwise. I would my means were greater$NEWLINE$and my waist slender.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$I wish it were the other way around: that my bank account were huge and my waist were thin.

paragraphs.original: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$You have misled the youthful Prince.
paragraphs.translated: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$You’ve misled the young Prince.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$The young Prince hath misled me. I am the fellow with the$NEWLINE$great belly, and he my dog.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$The young Prince has misled me. I’m the man with the big belly, and he’s the dog who walks in front of me.

paragraphs.original:
CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$Well, I am loath to gall a new-healed wound. Your day’s$NEWLINE$service at Shrewsbury hath a little gilded over your night’s$NEWLINE$exploit on
Gad’s Hill. You may thank th' unquiet time for$NEWLINE$Gad’s Hill$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$your quiet o'erposting that action.
paragraphs.translated: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$Well, I’d rather not open up a wound that’s just healed. The good work you did at Shrewsbury has made up a little for the bad thing you did at Gad’s Hill. You can thank the rebellion for helping you get away with that terrible deed.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$My lord.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Really?

paragraphs.original: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$But since all is well, keep it so. Wake not a sleeping wolf.
paragraphs.translated: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$But since things are calm now, let’s keep them that way. We won’t wake a sleeping wolf.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$To wake a wolf is as bad as to smell a fox.
paragraphs.translated:
FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$To wake a wolf is as bad as to
smell a fox.$NEWLINE$smell a fox$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$What, you are as a candle, the better part burnt out.
paragraphs.translated: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$What? You’re like a candle, half burned out.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$A wassail candle, my lord, all tallow. If I did say of wax, my$NEWLINE$growth would approve the truth.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Maybe, if I were a big, fat holiday candle made of animal fat. But you’d be better off saying that I’m a wax candle: I keep “waxing” larger and larger.

paragraphs.original: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$There is not a white hair on your face but should have his$NEWLINE$effect of gravity.
paragraphs.translated: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$Your gray beard should be a sign that you’re a man of gravity.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$His effect of gravy, gravy, gravy.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$I’m a man of gravy, gravy, gravy.

paragraphs.original: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$You follow the young Prince up and down like his ill angel.
paragraphs.translated: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$You follow the young Prince everywhere, like a false angel on his shoulder.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Not so, my lord. Your ill angel is light, but I hope he that$NEWLINE$looks upon me will take me without weighing. And yet in$NEWLINE$some respects I grant I cannot go. I cannot tell. Virtue is of$NEWLINE$so little regard in these costermongers' times that true valor$NEWLINE$is turned bear-herd; pregnancy is made a tapster, and hath his$NEWLINE$quick wit wasted in giving reckonings. All the other gifts$NEWLINE$appurtenant to man, as the malice of this age shapes them,$NEWLINE$are not worth a gooseberry. You that are old consider not the$NEWLINE$capacities of us that are young. You do measure the heat of$NEWLINE$our livers with the bitterness of your galls, and we that are in$NEWLINE$the vaward of our youth, I must confess, are wags too.
paragraphs.translated:
FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$That’s not so, my lord. False
angels are light, and anyone can see without having to weigh me that I’m too heavy. But I don’t know; in some ways, you’re right. I’m not for these times. Virtue counts for so little in this commercial world of ours. True courage is worthless; it’s only used by animal trainers in the bear-baiting rings. Intelligence is good for nobody but bartenders, who waste their wits totaling up tavern bills. In these mean-spirited days, man’s best qualities aren’t worth a thing. You older folks don’t value us young people. You measure our fiery passion according to your melancholic bitterness. And I have to tell you, those of us who are highly advanced in our youth, we’re spirited as well as young.$NEWLINE$angels$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$Do you set down your name in the scroll of youth, that are$NEWLINE$written down old with all the characters of age? Have you$NEWLINE$not a moist eye, a dry hand, a yellow cheek, a white beard,
paragraphs.translated: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$You’d add your name to the list of the young? You, who have age written all over you? Don’t you have mucus in your eyes? Dry skin? Jaundice? A white beard? An

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: a decreasing leg, an increasing belly? Is not your voice$NEWLINE$broken, your wind short, your chin double, your wit single,$NEWLINE$and every part about you blasted with antiquity? And will$NEWLINE$you yet call yourself young? Fie, fie, fie, Sir John.
paragraphs.translated: arthritic leg? A growing belly? Isn’t your voice scratchy? Your breath short? Your chin doubled? Your last wit abandoned? Isn’t every part of you devastated by age? And still you call yourself young? Shame on you, Sir John.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$My lord, I was born about three of the clock in the afternoon,$NEWLINE$with a white head and something a round belly. For my$NEWLINE$voice, I have lost it with halloing and singing of anthems. To$NEWLINE$approve my youth further, I will not. The truth is, I am only$NEWLINE$old in judgment and understanding. And he that will caper$NEWLINE$with me for a thousand marks, let him lend me the money,$NEWLINE$and have at him! For the box of the ear that the Prince gave$NEWLINE$you, he gave it like a rude prince, and you took it like a$NEWLINE$sensible lord. I have checked him for it, and the young lion$NEWLINE$repents. Marry, not in ashes and sackcloth, but in new silk and old sack.
paragraphs.translated:
FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Sir, I was born around three o'clock in the afternoon, with a white head and a bit of a round belly. As for my scratchy voice, I lost it through shouting and singing loud songs. But I won’t try to prove how young I am any longer. I have only one trait of old age, and that is wisdom. If somebody wants to challenge me to a dance contest for a thousand-
mark wager, let him hand me the money and off we go. Now, as for the fact that the Prince hit you on the head, he did it like a rude prince and you took it like a sensible gentleman. I reprimanded him for it, and he repents. He’s not wearing the traditional sackcloth and ashes, for sure, but he’s repenting in silk cloth and wine.$NEWLINE$mark$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$Well, God send the Prince a better companion.
paragraphs.translated: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$May God send the Prince a better friend!

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$God send the companion a better prince. I cannot rid my$NEWLINE$hands of him.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$May God send the friend a better prince! I can’t get him off my hands!

paragraphs.original: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$Well, the King hath severed you and Prince Harry. I hear you$NEWLINE$are going with Lord John of Lancaster against the$NEWLINE$Archbishop and the Earl of Northumberland.
paragraphs.translated: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$Well, the King has separated you and Prince Harry. I hear you’re going with John of Lancaster to go fight Northumberland and the Archbishop.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Yea, I thank your pretty sweet wit for it. But look you pray,$NEWLINE$all you that kiss my Lady Peace at home, that our armies join$NEWLINE$not in a hot day, for, by the Lord, I take but two shirts out with$NEWLINE$me, and I mean not to sweat extraordinarily. If it be a hot day$NEWLINE$and I brandish anything but a bottle, I would I might never$NEWLINE$spit white again. There is not a dangerous action can peep$NEWLINE$out his head but I am thrust upon it. Well, I cannot last ever.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Yes, and thanks for reminding me. I hope that all of you who stay home, safe and sound, will say a prayer that we soldiers don’t end up in some hot battle. For, by the Lord, I’ve only packed two shirts, and I don’t want to sweat too much. If things get hot and I pull out any other weapon besides a bottle, I’ll never drink wine again. I get sent out on every dangerous assignment

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: But it was always yet the trick of our English nation, if they$NEWLINE$have a good thing, to make it too common. If ye will needs$NEWLINE$say I am an old man, you should give me rest. I would to God$NEWLINE$my name were not so terrible to the enemy as it is. I were$NEWLINE$better to be eaten to death with a rust than to be scoured to$NEWLINE$nothing with perpetual motion.
paragraphs.translated: that comes up. Well, I can’t live forever. That’s the thing about the English: when they have something good, they use it continually. If you’re going to insist that I’m an old man, then let me rest. I wish to God the enemy weren’t as scared of me as they are: I’d rather sit and rust than be worn out by all this work.

paragraphs.original: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$Well, be honest, be honest; and God bless your expedition!
paragraphs.translated: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$Well, stay honest, stay honest. God bless your undertaking.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Will your Lordship lend me a thousand pound to furnish me$NEWLINE$forth?
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Could your lordship lend me a thousand pounds for some equipment I need?

paragraphs.original: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$Not a penny, not a penny. You are too impatient to bear$NEWLINE$crosses. Fare you well. Commend me to my cousin$NEWLINE$Westmoreland.
paragraphs.translated: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$Not a penny, not a penny: you’re too impatient to endure adversity. Farewell; give my regards to my kinsman Westmoreland.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt CHIEF JUSTICE and SERVANT$NEWLINE$CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$SERVANT
paragraphs.translated: The CHIEF JUSTICE and his SERVANT exit.$NEWLINE$CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$SERVANT

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$If I do, fillip me with a three-man beetle. A man can no more$NEWLINE$separate age and covetousness than he can part young limbs$NEWLINE$and lechery; but the gout galls the one, and the pox pinches$NEWLINE$the other, and so both the degrees prevent my curses.—Boy!
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$If I do, hit me with a sledgehammer. Old age and greed go together like youth and lust. Gout afflicts one and syphilis plagues the other, so there’s no point in me cursing either the old or the young: they’re both cursed already. Boy!

paragraphs.original: PAGE$NEWLINE$Sir.
paragraphs.translated: PAGE$NEWLINE$Sir?

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$What money is in my purse?
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$How much money’s in my wallet?

paragraphs.original: PAGE$NEWLINE$Seven groats and two pence.
paragraphs.translated:
PAGE$NEWLINE$About seven
groats and two pence.$NEWLINE$groats$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$I can get no remedy against this consumption of the purse.$NEWLINE$Borrowing only lingers and lingers it out, but the disease is$NEWLINE$incurable. Go bear this letter to my Lord of Lancaster, this$NEWLINE$to the Prince, this to the Earl of Westmoreland; and this to$NEWLINE$old Mistress Ursula, whom I have weekly sworn to marry$NEWLINE$since I perceived the first white hair on my chin. About it.$NEWLINE$You know where to find me.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$There no way to cure the illness that’s making my wallet waste away; borrowing makes it live a little longer, but the disease is incurable. Bring this letter to Lord John of Lancaster, this one to the Prince, this one to Westmoreland, and this one to Madame Ursula. I’ve promised to marry her every single week since I got my first gray hair. Get going: you know where I’ll be.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Exit PAGE$NEWLINE$PAGE
paragraphs.translated: The PAGE exits.$NEWLINE$PAGE

paragraphs.original: A pox of this gout! Or, a gout of this pox, for the one or the$NEWLINE$other plays the rogue with my great toe. 'Tis no matter if I$NEWLINE$do halt. I have the wars for my color, and my pension shall$NEWLINE$seem the more reasonable. A good wit will make use of$NEWLINE$anything. I will turn diseases to commodity.
paragraphs.translated: Damn this gout! Or damn this syphilis! One of them is really messing up my big toe. Oh well, it doesn’t matter if I limp. I can blame it on the war, and that will help justify my disability payments. A sharp brain can turn any problem to its advantage. I’ll turn my diseases into cash.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter the ARCHBISHOP of York, Thomas MOWBRAY the Earl Marshal, Lord HASTINGS, and LORD BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$MOWBRAY$NEWLINE$HASTINGS$NEWLINE$LORD BARDOLPH
paragraphs.translated: The ARCHBISHOP of York, Thomas MOWBRAY the Earl Marshal, Lord HASTINGS and LORD BARDOLPH enter.$NEWLINE$ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$MOWBRAY$NEWLINE$HASTINGS$NEWLINE$LORD BARDOLPH

paragraphs.original: ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$Thus have you heard our cause and known our means,$NEWLINE$And, my most noble friends, I pray you all$NEWLINE$Speak plainly your opinions of our hopes.$NEWLINE$And first, Lord Marshal, what say you to it?
paragraphs.translated: ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$So that’s what we’re fighting for, and that’s the kind of support we have. Now please, my noble friends, tell me frankly if you think we have a chance. First you, Marshal Mowbray. What do you say?

paragraphs.original: MOWBRAY$NEWLINE$I well allow the occasion of our arms,$NEWLINE$But gladly would be better satisfied$NEWLINE$How in our means we should advance ourselves$NEWLINE$To look with forehead bold and big enough$NEWLINE$Upon the power and puissance of the King.
paragraphs.translated: MOWBRAY$NEWLINE$I absolutely agree with our reasons for fighting. But given our resources, I’d feel better if I knew how we’re going to grow bold and strong enough to defeat this mighty and powerful King.

paragraphs.original: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$Our present musters grow upon the file$NEWLINE$To five-and-twenty thousand men of choice,$NEWLINE$And our supplies live largely in the hope$NEWLINE$Of great Northumberland, whose bosom burns$NEWLINE$With an incensèd fire of injuries.
paragraphs.translated: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$Our army has grown to twenty-five thousand good men. Our reinforcements are coming with Northumberland, and his heart burns with anger over all he’s lost.

paragraphs.original: LORD BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$The question then, Lord Hastings, standeth thus:$NEWLINE$Whether our present five-and-twenty thousand$NEWLINE$May hold up head without Northumberland.
paragraphs.translated: LORD BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Then, Lord Hastings, this is the question: can our twenty-five thousand get the job done without Northumberland?

paragraphs.original: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$With him we may.
paragraphs.translated: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$With him, we can.

paragraphs.original: LORD BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Yea, marry, there’s the point.$NEWLINE$But if without him we be thought too feeble,$NEWLINE$My judgment is we should not step too far$NEWLINE$Till we had his assistance by the hand.$NEWLINE$For in a theme so bloody-faced as this,$NEWLINE$Conjecture, expectation, and surmise$NEWLINE$Of aids incertain should not be admitted.
paragraphs.translated: LORD BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Yes, exactly, and that’s the point. If we’re too weak without him, then I don’t think we should advance until we know that his help is guaranteed. In a fight as bloody as this one, we need to be certain about the status of our supporters: we can’t rely on conjecture, hope, and guesswork when aid isn’t guaranteed.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$'Tis very true, Lord Bardolph; for indeed$NEWLINE$It was young Hotspur’s cause at Shrewsbury.
paragraphs.translated: ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$That’s right, Lord Bardolph. That’s what happened to young Hotspur at Shrewsbury.

paragraphs.original: LORD BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$It was, my lord; who lined himself with hope,$NEWLINE$Eating the air on promise of supply,$NEWLINE$Flatt'ring himself in project of a power$NEWLINE$Much smaller than the smallest of his thoughts,$NEWLINE$And so, with great imagination$NEWLINE$Proper to madmen, led his powers to death$NEWLINE$And, winking, leapt into destruction.
paragraphs.translated: LORD BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$That’s true, my lord. Hotspur fortified himself with nothing but hope, and mistook empty words as a true promise of reinforcements. He imagined that a huge army was coming to his aid, but what actually arrived turned out to be even smaller than the smallest of his fantasies. And so, with daydreams that could only belong to a madman, he closed his eyes and leaped into destruction.

paragraphs.original: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$But, by your leave, it never yet did hurt$NEWLINE$To lay down likelihoods and forms of hope.
paragraphs.translated: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$But, begging your pardon, there’s no harm in making guesses and hopeful strategies.

paragraphs.original: LORD BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Yes, if this present quality of war—$NEWLINE$Indeed the instant action, a cause on foot—$NEWLINE$Lives so in hope, as in an early spring$NEWLINE$We see the appearing buds, which to prove fruit$NEWLINE$Hope gives not so much warrant as despair$NEWLINE$That frosts will bite them. When we mean to build,$NEWLINE$We first survey the plot, then draw the model,$NEWLINE$And when we see the figure of the house,$NEWLINE$Then must we rate the cost of the erection,$NEWLINE$Which if we find outweighs ability,$NEWLINE$What do we then but draw anew the model$NEWLINE$In fewer offices, or at last desist$NEWLINE$To build at all? Much more in this great work,$NEWLINE$Which is almost to pluck a kingdom down$NEWLINE$And set another up, should we survey$NEWLINE$The plot of situation and the model,$NEWLINE$Consent upon a sure foundation,$NEWLINE$Question surveyors, know our own estate,$NEWLINE$How able such a work to undergo,$NEWLINE$To weigh against his opposite. Or else
paragraphs.translated: LORD BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Yes, there is. Presently, our armies are already in motion, but putting our hope in them is as ridiculous as expecting that early spring buds will produce fruit: at that time of year, buds are more likely to be killed by frost than to bloom. When we want to put up a building, first we survey the land, and then we draw up a set of plans. Then we calculate the cost, and if we can’t afford it, we revise the plans with fewer rooms, or we decide not to build at all. In the great task we’re attempting—the taking down of one kingdom, and the building of another—we have even more reason to evaluate the land and the plans. We must be certain that the foundation is sound, that the engineer is skilled. We must know precisely what we can afford, how ready and able we are, and we must consider the opposing arguments.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: We fortify in paper and in figures,$NEWLINE$Using the names of men instead of men,$NEWLINE$Like one that draws the model of a house$NEWLINE$Beyond his power to build it, who, half through,$NEWLINE$Gives o'er and leaves his part-created cost$NEWLINE$A naked subject to the weeping clouds$NEWLINE$And waste for churlish winter’s tyranny.
paragraphs.translated: Otherwise, it becomes a meaningless exercise: papers and numbers, and names of men rather than real, live men. That’s like drawing up plans for a house you can’t possibly afford, building half of it, and then abandoning the partly-built structure to be ruined by the elements.

paragraphs.original: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$Grant that our hopes, yet likely of fair birth,$NEWLINE$Should be stillborn and that we now possessed$NEWLINE$The utmost man of expectation,$NEWLINE$I think we are a body strong enough,$NEWLINE$Even as we are, to equal with the King.
paragraphs.translated: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$Let’s suppose that everything we’re hoping for fails to materialize, and the army we have now is as big as it’s going to get. I still think that, even in this condition, we’re a match for the King.

paragraphs.original: LORD BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$What, is the King but five-and twenty-thousand?
paragraphs.translated: LORD BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Why? Does the King only have twenty-five thousand men?

paragraphs.original: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$To us no more, nay, not so much, Lord Bardolph,$NEWLINE$For his divisions, as the times do brawl,$NEWLINE$Are in three heads: one power against the French,$NEWLINE$And one against Glendower; perforce a third$NEWLINE$Must take up us. So is the unfirm King$NEWLINE$In three divided, and his coffers sound$NEWLINE$With hollow poverty and emptiness.
paragraphs.translated: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$The King isn’t facing us with any more than that—in fact, he doesn’t even have that many, Lord Bardolph. This is a time of war, and the King’s had to divide his army into three sections. One division is fighting the French; one’s fighting Glendower. That leaves a third of his army to fight against us. The King is weak and divided into three, and the coffers of his treasury echo with the sounds of hollow poverty and emptiness.

paragraphs.original: ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$That he should draw his several strengths together$NEWLINE$And come against us in full puissance$NEWLINE$Need not be dreaded.
paragraphs.translated: ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$There’s no reason to fear that he will pull all three divisions together and confront us with his full strength.

paragraphs.original: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$If he should do so,$NEWLINE$He leaves his back unarmed, the French and Welsh$NEWLINE$Baying him at the heels. Never fear that.
paragraphs.translated: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$If he did that, he’d be vulnerable at the rear, and the French and the Welsh would be at his heels. He would never let that happen.

paragraphs.original: LORD BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Who is it like should lead his forces hither?
paragraphs.translated: LORD BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Who’s going to lead his troops against us?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$The Duke of Lancaster and Westmoreland;$NEWLINE$Against the Welsh, himself and Harry Monmouth;$NEWLINE$But who is substituted against the French$NEWLINE$I have no certain notice.
paragraphs.translated: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$The Duke of Lancaster and Westmoreland. The King and Harry Monmouth will fight against the Welsh. I don’t know for sure who is in charge of the fight against the French.

paragraphs.original: ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$Let us on,$NEWLINE$And publish the occasion of our arms.$NEWLINE$The commonwealth is sick of their own choice.$NEWLINE$Their over-greedy love hath surfeited.$NEWLINE$An habitation giddy and unsure$NEWLINE$Hath he that buildeth on the vulgar heart.$NEWLINE$O thou fond many, with what loud applause$NEWLINE$Didst thou beat heaven with blessing Bolingbroke$NEWLINE$Before he was what thou wouldst have him be.$NEWLINE$And being now trimmed in thine own desires,$NEWLINE$Thou, beastly feeder, art so full of him$NEWLINE$That thou provok’st thyself to cast him up.$NEWLINE$So, so, thou common dog, didst thou disgorge$NEWLINE$Thy glutton bosom of the royal Richard,$NEWLINE$And now thou wouldst eat thy dead vomit up$NEWLINE$And howl’st to find it. What trust is in these times?$NEWLINE$They that, when Richard lived, would have him die$NEWLINE$Are now become enamored on his grave.$NEWLINE$Thou, that threw’st dust upon his goodly head$NEWLINE$When through proud London he came sighing on$NEWLINE$After th' admired heels of Bolingbroke,$NEWLINE$Criest now “O earth, yield us that King again,$NEWLINE$And take thou this!” O thoughts of men accursed!$NEWLINE$Past and to come seems best; things present, worst.
paragraphs.translated: ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$Let’s continue. We’ll publicly proclaim the reasons we’re fighting. The people are sick of the leadership they themselves supported. They were greedy for it, but now they have overfed. When you build your foundation on the public’s love, you build on shaky and unsure ground. Oh, you foolish masses! You shouted your love for Bolingbroke to the skies, before you knew what he’d turn into. Now that you’re dressed in the things you desired, you monstrous devourer, you’re so full of Bolingbroke that you’re ready to vomit him up. This, you vulgar dog, is just how you emptied your gluttonous stomach of King Richard; and now you want to eat up your dead vomit, and you howl trying to find it. What can you count on in this world? The very people who wanted Richard dead when he was alive are now in love with his corpse. The very people who threw garbage on his noble head when he marched through London in shame behind the admired Bolingbroke are now saying, “Oh Earth, return that King, and take this one!” Curses on men’s thoughts! Only the past and the future appeal to them; whatever they have right now they despise.

paragraphs.original: MOWBRAY$NEWLINE$Shall we go draw our numbers and set on?
paragraphs.translated: MOWBRAY$NEWLINE$Should we gather our troops and press forward?

paragraphs.original: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$We are time’s subjects, and time bids begone.
paragraphs.translated: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$Time is our commander, and time proposes we be on our way.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter MISTRESS QUICKLY, with two officers; FANG with her and SNARE following$NEWLINE$MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$FANG$NEWLINE$SNARE
paragraphs.translated: MISTRESS QUICKLY enters with Sheriff FANG. Deputy SNARE follows.$NEWLINE$MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$FANG$NEWLINE$SNARE

paragraphs.original: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$Master Fang, have you entered the action?
paragraphs.translated: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$Master Fang, have you filed the lawsuit?

paragraphs.original: FANG$NEWLINE$It is entered.
paragraphs.translated: FANG$NEWLINE$It’s filed.

paragraphs.original: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$Where’s your yeoman? Is ’t a lusty yeoman? Will a'$NEWLINE$stand to ’t?
paragraphs.translated: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$Where’s your deputy? Is he a strong deputy? Will he rise to the occasion?

paragraphs.original: FANG$NEWLINE$Sirrah! Where’s Snare?
paragraphs.translated: FANG$NEWLINE$Sirrah, where’s Snare?

paragraphs.original: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$O Lord, ay, good Master Snare.
paragraphs.translated: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$Oh my goodness! Master Snare!

paragraphs.original: SNARE$NEWLINE$Here, here.
paragraphs.translated: SNARE$NEWLINE$Here, here.

paragraphs.original: FANG$NEWLINE$Snare, we must arrest Sir John Falstaff.
paragraphs.translated: FANG$NEWLINE$Snare, we’ve got to arrest Sir John Falstaff.

paragraphs.original: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$Yea, good Master Snare, I have entered him and all.
paragraphs.translated: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$Yes, good Master Snare. I’ve filed the suit against him and everything.

paragraphs.original: SNARE$NEWLINE$It may chance cost some of us our lives, for he will stab.
paragraphs.translated: SNARE$NEWLINE$It could cost some of us our lives: he’ll stab.

paragraphs.original: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$Alas the day, take heed of him. He stabbed me in mine own$NEWLINE$house, and that most beastly, in good faith. He cares not what$NEWLINE$mischief he does. If his weapon be out, he will foin like any$NEWLINE$devil. He will spare neither man, woman, nor child.
paragraphs.translated: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$Oh my goodness! Watch out for him: he stabbed me in my own house, and it was nasty. I swear, he doesn’t care what trouble he causes. Once he’s got his weapon out, he’ll thrust it like the devil. He won’t spare man, woman, or child.

paragraphs.original: FANG$NEWLINE$If I can close with him, I care not for his thrust.
paragraphs.translated: FANG$NEWLINE$If I can get close to him, I won’t worry about his thrusting.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$No, nor I neither. I’ll be at your elbow.
paragraphs.translated: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$Me neither. I’ll be right next to you.

paragraphs.original: FANG$NEWLINE$An I but fist him once, an he come but within my view—
paragraphs.translated: FANG$NEWLINE$If I can grab him once, if he just comes within my grasp–

paragraphs.original: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$I am undone by his going. I warrant you, he’s an infinitive$NEWLINE$thing upon my score. Good Master Fang, hold him sure.$NEWLINE$Good Master Snare, let him not ’scape. He comes$NEWLINE$continuantly to Pie Corner, saving your manhoods, to buy a$NEWLINE$saddle, and he is indited to dinner to the Lubber’s Head in$NEWLINE$Lumbert Street, to Master Smooth’s the silkman. I pray you,$NEWLINE$since my exion is entered, and my case so openly known to$NEWLINE$the world, let him be brought in to his answer. A hundred$NEWLINE$mark is a long one for a poor lone woman to bear, and I have$NEWLINE$borne, and borne, and borne, and have been fubbed off, and$NEWLINE$fubbed off, and fubbed off from this day to that day, that it$NEWLINE$is a shame to be thought on. There is no honesty in such$NEWLINE$dealing, unless a woman should be made an ass and a beast$NEWLINE$to bear every knave’s wrong. Yonder he comes, and that$NEWLINE$errant malmsey-nose knave, Bardolph, with him. Do your$NEWLINE$offices, do your offices, Master Fang and Master Snare, do$NEWLINE$me, do me, do me your offices.
paragraphs.translated:
MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$I’m
bankrupt from his never paying. He’s run up an infinitive bill with me. Catch him, Master Fang! Don’t let him get away, Master Snare! He’s always going to
Pie Corner—sorry to mention it—to buy a saddle. And every day he gets
indited to lunch with Master Smooth the silk seller, at the Leopard’s Head on Lumbert Street. Please bring him to justice. I’ve been entered—I mean, my lawsuit’s been entered at court, and the whole world knows how easy I am—I mean how easy it was for him to rip me off. A hundred
marks is a lot for a poor, solitary woman to take. And I’ve taken it, and taken it, and taken it. And I’ve been fobbed off and fobbed off and fobbed off, day in and day out. It’s horrible to even think about. That’s a terrible way to treat people, unless you think that every woman should be made an ass and an animal, and that she should be opened to every jerk’s molestation. Here he comes, with that notorious wine-faced crook, Bardolph. Do me a favor and do me your jobs, Master Fang and Master Snare. Do me! Do me! Do me a favor and do me your jobs!$NEWLINE$bankrupt$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$Pie Corner$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$indited$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$marks$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$
