paragraphs.original: Enter FALSTAFF, BARDOLPH, and PAGE$NEWLINE$FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$PAGE
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF, his PAGE, and BARDOLPH enter.$NEWLINE$FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$PAGE$NEWLINE$BARDOLPH

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$How now! Whose mare’s dead? What’s the matter?
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$What’s going on? Whose horse died? What’s the matter?

paragraphs.original: FANG$NEWLINE$Sir John, I arrest you at the suit of Mistress Quickly.
paragraphs.translated: FANG$NEWLINE$Sir John, you’re under arrest for charges brought by Mistress Quickly.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Away, varlets!—Draw, Bardolph. Cut me off the villain’s$NEWLINE$head. Throw the quean in the channel.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Get out of here, you crooks! Draw your sword, Bardolph. Cut off this rascal’s head, and throw this whore in the gutter.

paragraphs.original: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$Throw me in the channel? I’ll throw thee in the channel. Wilt$NEWLINE$thou, wilt thou, thou bastardly rogue?—Murder, murder!—$NEWLINE$Ah, thou honeysuckle villain, wilt thou kill God’s officers$NEWLINE$and the King’s? Ah, thou honeyseed rogue, thou art a$NEWLINE$honeyseed, a man-queller, and a woman-queller.
paragraphs.translated:
MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$Throw me in the gutter? I’ll throw you in the gutter. You will? You will? You bastardly cheat! Murder! Murder! Oh, you
honeysuckle criminal! You’re going to kill God’s sheriffs, and the King’s? Oh, you honey-seed creep! You’re a honey-seed, a man-killer, and a woman-killer.$NEWLINE$honeysuckle$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Keep them off, Bardolph.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Keep them off me, Bardolph.

paragraphs.original: FANG$NEWLINE$A rescue, a rescue!
paragraphs.translated: FANG$NEWLINE$An escape! An escape!

paragraphs.original: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$Good people, bring a rescue or two.— (to FALSTAFF) Thou$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$wot, wot thou? Thou wot, wot ta? Do, do, thou rogue. Do,$NEWLINE$thou hempseed.
paragraphs.translated:
MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$Somebody, bring an
escape or two! (to FALSTAFF) You will, will you? You will, will you? Go ahead, go ahead, you scoundrel! You hemp-seed!$NEWLINE$escape$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Away, you scullion, you rampallion, you fustilarian! I’ll$NEWLINE$tickle your catastrophe.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Get off, you serving wench! You ruffian! You fat old hag! I’ll beat you on the backside!

paragraphs.original: Enter the Lord CHIEF JUSTICE and his men$NEWLINE$CHIEF JUSTICE
paragraphs.translated: The Lord CHIEF JUSTICE and his men enter.$NEWLINE$CHIEF JUSTICE

paragraphs.original: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$What is the matter? Keep the peace here, ho!
paragraphs.translated: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$What’s the matter? Let’s have some order here!

paragraphs.original: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$Good my lord, be good to me. I beseech you stand to me.
paragraphs.translated: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$Good sir, be good to me. I beg you, stand up for me.

paragraphs.original: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$How now, Sir John? What, are you brawling here?$NEWLINE$Doth this become your place, your time, and business?$NEWLINE$You should have been well on your way to York.—$NEWLINE$(to FANG) Stand from him, fellow: wherefore hang’st thou$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$upon him?
paragraphs.translated: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$Well if it isn’t Sir John! Are you making trouble here? Is this appropriate for a man of your position, your age, and your responsibilities? You should be well on your way to York by now. (to FANG) Get off him, man. Why are you holding him?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$O my most worshipful lord, an ’t please your Grace, I am a$NEWLINE$poor widow of Eastcheap, and he is arrested at my suit.
paragraphs.translated: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$Oh, most excellent lord, begging your pardon: I’m a poor Eastcheap widow, and he’s arrested on charges I brought against him.

paragraphs.original: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$For what sum?
paragraphs.translated: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$What sum does he owe you?

paragraphs.original: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$It is more than for some, my lord; it is for all I have. He hath$NEWLINE$eaten me out of house and home. He hath put all my substance$NEWLINE$into that fat belly of his. (to FALSTAFF) But I will have some of$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$it out again, or I will ride thee o' nights like the mare.
paragraphs.translated: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$It’s more than some, sir: it’s all, all that I have. He’s eaten me out of house and home. He’s put everything I own into that fat belly of his. (to FALSTAFF) But I’ll get some of it back again, or I’ll ride you all night like a bad dream.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$I think I am as like to ride the mare if I have any vantage of$NEWLINE$ground to get up.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$I think I might just ride you, if I get the chance to mount you.

paragraphs.original: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$How comes this, Sir John? Fie, what man of good temper$NEWLINE$would endure this tempest of exclamation? Are you not$NEWLINE$ashamed to enforce a poor widow to so rough a course to$NEWLINE$come by her own?
paragraphs.translated: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$What is this, Sir John? Damn! How could any decent man put up with this storm of screaming and cursing? Aren’t you ashamed to force a poor widow to take these extreme measures simply to get what’s hers?

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$(to MISTRESS QUICKLY) What is the gross sum that I owe thee?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$(to MISTRESS QUICKLY) What’s the total I owe you?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$Marry, if thou wert an honest man, thyself and the money$NEWLINE$too. Thou didst swear to me upon a parcel-gilt goblet, sitting$NEWLINE$in my Dolphin chamber at the round table by a sea-coal fire,$NEWLINE$upon Wednesday in Wheeson week, when the Prince broke$NEWLINE$thy head for liking his father to a singing-man of Windsor,$NEWLINE$thou didst swear to me then, as I was washing thy wound, to$NEWLINE$marry me and make me my lady thy wife. Canst thou deny$NEWLINE$it? Did not goodwife Keech, the butcher’s wife, come in then$NEWLINE$and call me Gossip Quickly, coming in to borrow a mess of$NEWLINE$vinegar; telling us she had a good dish of prawns, whereby$NEWLINE$thou didst desire to eat some, whereby I told thee they were$NEWLINE$ill for a green wound? And didst thou not, when she was$NEWLINE$gone downstairs, desire me to be no more so familiarity with
paragraphs.translated: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$My goodness! If you were an honest man, you’d give yourself to me, as well as the money. You swore to me—over a gold-plated wine goblet, in the Dolphin Room in my tavern, at the round table, next to the fire, on the Wednesday seven weeks after Easter, when the Prince swung at your head for claiming his father was a fake—you swore, while I was cleaning your wounds, to marry me and make me a proper lady and your wife. Can you deny it? Didn’t Mrs. Baconfat, the butcher’s wife, come into the room then and ask to borrow some vinegar, saying that she had some good prawns—and you wanted to eat some, and I told you that it was a bad idea, to eat shrimp when you had a fresh wound—and

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: such poor people, saying that ere long they should call me$NEWLINE$madam? And didst thou not kiss me and bid me fetch thee$NEWLINE$thirty shillings? I put thee now to thy book-oath. Deny it if$NEWLINE$thou canst.
paragraphs.translated:
when she left, didn’t you tell me to stop being friends with low types like her, because before long we’d be married and I’d be a proper lady? And didn’t you kiss me and tell me to lend you thirty
shillings? Put your hand on the bible and deny it, if you dare.$NEWLINE$shillings$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$My lord, this is a poor mad soul, and she says up and down$NEWLINE$the town that her eldest son is like you. She hath been in good$NEWLINE$case, and the truth is, poverty hath distracted her. But, for$NEWLINE$these foolish officers, I beseech you I may have redress$NEWLINE$against them.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Sir, this is a poor, insane soul. She’s been saying all over town that her oldest son looks just like you. She was once rich, but poverty has driven her crazy. Now, as for these two foolish officers, I would like to press charges against them.

paragraphs.original: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$Sir John, Sir John, I am well acquainted with your manner$NEWLINE$of wrenching the true cause the false way. It is not a$NEWLINE$confident brow, nor the throng of words that come with such$NEWLINE$more than impudent sauciness from you, can thrust me from$NEWLINE$a level consideration. You have, as it appears to me,$NEWLINE$practiced upon the easy-yielding spirit of this woman, and$NEWLINE$made her serve your uses both in purse and in person.
paragraphs.translated: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$Sir John, Sir John. I know too well how you are accustomed to turning the truth into a big lie. But neither your confident demeanor nor the storm of words that accompanies your insolent disrespect will sway me from making a just consideration. As far as I can see, you’ve taken advantage of this trusting woman, and you’ve made her give you cash and other favors.

paragraphs.original: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$Yea, in truth, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$Yes, truthfully, sir.

paragraphs.original: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$Pray thee, peace.— (to FALSTAFF) Pay her the debt you owe$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$her, and unpay the villany you have done her. The one you$NEWLINE$may do with sterling money, and the other with current$NEWLINE$repentance.
paragraphs.translated: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$Quiet, please. (to FALSTAFF) Pay her what you owe her, and undo the wrongdoings you’ve done to her. You can do the first with money, and the second with a sincere apology.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$My lord, I will not undergo this sneap without reply. You call$NEWLINE$honorable boldness “impudent sauciness.” If a man will$NEWLINE$make curtsy and say nothing, he is virtuous. No, my lord, my$NEWLINE$humble duty remembered, I will not be your suitor. I say to$NEWLINE$you, I do desire deliverance from these officers, being upon$NEWLINE$hasty employment in the King’s affairs.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Sir, I will not put up with this snub without a reply. You call my brave, honorable dealings insolent disrespect. Does a man have to stand here, silent and bowing, to be a virtuous man? No, sir. With all due respect, I won’t bow down to you. I say that I want to be set free by these officers, seeing as I have urgent work to do for the King.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$You speak as having power to do wrong; but answer in th'$NEWLINE$effect of your reputation, and satisfy this poor woman.
paragraphs.translated: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$You talk as though you have permission to break the law. But act appropriately to your status: satisfy this poor woman.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Come hither, hostess.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Come here, hostess.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF takes MISTRESS QUICKLY aside$NEWLINE$FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$MISTRESS QUICKLY
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF takes MISTRESS QUICKLY aside.$NEWLINE$FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$MISTRESS QUICKLY

paragraphs.original: Enter GOWER$NEWLINE$GOWER
paragraphs.translated: GOWER enters.$NEWLINE$GOWER

paragraphs.original: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$Now, Master Gower, what news?
paragraphs.translated: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$Master Gower, what’s going on?

paragraphs.original: GOWER$NEWLINE$The King, my lord, and Harry Prince of Wales$NEWLINE$Are near at hand. The rest the paper tells.
paragraphs.translated: GOWER$NEWLINE$My lord, the King and Harry Prince of Wales are nearby. This letter will tell you the rest.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$As I am a gentleman!
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$On my honor.

paragraphs.original: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$Faith, you said so before.
paragraphs.translated: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$Honestly, that’s what you said before.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$As I am a gentleman. Come. No more words of it.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$On my honor. Come, let’s not talk about it anymore.

paragraphs.original: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$By this heavenly ground I tread on, I must be fain to pawn$NEWLINE$both my plate and the tapestry of my dining chambers.
paragraphs.translated: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$By heaven above and below, I’ll have to pawn my good china and the tapestries in my dining rooms.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Glasses, glasses, is the only drinking. And for thy walls, a$NEWLINE$pretty slight drollery, or the story of the Prodigal or the$NEWLINE$German hunting in waterwork is worth a thousand of these$NEWLINE$bed-hangers and these fly-bitten tapestries. Let it be ten$NEWLINE$pound, if thou canst. Come, an ’twere not for thy humors,$NEWLINE$there’s not a better wench in England. Go wash thy face, and$NEWLINE$draw the action. Come, thou must not be in this humor with$NEWLINE$me. Dost not know me? Come, come, I know thou wast set$NEWLINE$on to this.
paragraphs.translated:
FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$It’s not such a big deal. Glass is the only good thing to drink out of anyway. And as for the
walls, something pretty and comical—or a depiction of the prodigal son; or maybe one of those German hunting scenes, painted on the wall to look like a tapestry—why, those are worth a thousand of those bed curtains and moth-eaten tapestries.$NEWLINE$walls$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$Let me borrow just ten pounds, all right? Come on—other than your moodiness, you’re the best wench in England. Go wash your face and withdraw the lawsuit. Come on—don’t be this way with me. Don’t you know me? Come, come, I know somebody put you up to this.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$Pray thee, Sir John, let it be but twenty nobles. I' faith, I am$NEWLINE$loath to pawn my plate, so God save me, la.
paragraphs.translated:
MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$Please, Sir John, let’s call it
twenty nobles. I don’t want to have to pawn my china, in God’s name!$NEWLINE$twenty nobles$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Let it alone. I’ll make other shift. You’ll be a fool still.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$All right, forget it. I’ll figure something else out. You’ll always be a fool.

paragraphs.original: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$Well, you shall have it, though I pawn my gown. I hope$NEWLINE$you’ll come to supper. You’ll pay me all together?
paragraphs.translated: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$All right, I’ll lend it to you, even if I have to pawn my clothes. I hope you’ll have dinner here tonight. You’ll pay me the full amount then?

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Will I live? (to BARDOLPH) Go with her, with her. Hook on,$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$hook on.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Will I live? (to BARDOLPH) Go, stick with her, stick with her. Don’t let her out of your sight.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$Will you have Doll Tearsheet meet you at supper?
paragraphs.translated: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$Do you want Doll Tearsheet to meet you at dinner?

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$No more words. Let’s have her.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$No more talking. Let’s have her.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt MISTRESS QUICKLY, FANG, SNARE, BARDOLPH, and the PAGE$NEWLINE$MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$FANG$NEWLINE$SNARE$NEWLINE$BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$PAGE
paragraphs.translated: MISTRESS QUICKLY, BARDOLPH, the PAGE, FANG, and SNARE exit.$NEWLINE$MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$PAGE$NEWLINE$FANG$NEWLINE$SNARE

paragraphs.original: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$I have heard better news.
paragraphs.translated: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$I’ve heard better news.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$What’s the news, my good lord?
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$What’s the news, my lord?

paragraphs.original: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$Where lay the King last night?
paragraphs.translated: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$Where did the King spend last night?

paragraphs.original: GOWER$NEWLINE$At Basingstoke, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: GOWER$NEWLINE$At Basingstoke, sir.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$I hope, my lord, all’s well. What is the news, my lord?
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$I hope everything’s okay, sir. What’s the news?

paragraphs.original: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$Come all his forces back?
paragraphs.translated: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$And his armies have come back?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: GOWER$NEWLINE$No; fifteen hundred foot, five hundred horse$NEWLINE$Are marched up to my Lord of Lancaster$NEWLINE$Against Northumberland and the Archbishop.
paragraphs.translated: GOWER$NEWLINE$No. Fifteen hundred infantrymen and five hundred horsemen are marching to meet Lord Lancaster, to fight against Northumberland and the Archbishop.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Comes the King back from Wales, my noble lord?
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Is the King back from Wales, my noble lord?

paragraphs.original: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$You shall have letters of me presently.$NEWLINE$Come. Go along with me, good Master Gower.
paragraphs.translated: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$I’ll give you some letters shortly. Come with me, Master Gower.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$My lord!
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Sir!

paragraphs.original: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$What’s the matter?
paragraphs.translated: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$What’s the matter?

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Master Gower, shall I entreat you with me to dinner?
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Master Gower, would you like to join me for lunch?

paragraphs.original: GOWER$NEWLINE$I must wait upon my good lord here. I thank you, good Sir$NEWLINE$John.
paragraphs.translated: GOWER$NEWLINE$I have to attend to this noble man right here. But thank you, Sir John.

paragraphs.original: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$Sir John, you loiter here too long, being you are to take$NEWLINE$soldiers up in counties as you go.
paragraphs.translated: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$Sir John, you’ve been loitering here too long. You have to recruit soldiers in the counties you pass through on your way north.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Will you sup with me, Master Gower?
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Will you join me for supper, then, Master Gower?

paragraphs.original: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$What foolish master taught you these manners, Sir John?
paragraphs.translated: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$What foolish teacher taught you these manners, Sir John?

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Master Gower, if they become me not, he was a fool that$NEWLINE$taught them me.—This is the right fencing grace, my lord:$NEWLINE$tap for tap, and so part fair.
paragraphs.translated:
FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Master Gower, if my
manners are inappropriate, I must have indeed been taught by a fool. That’s how the game is played—tit for tat, and game over.$NEWLINE$manners$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$Now the Lord lighten thee. Thou art a great fool.
paragraphs.translated: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$God help you! You are a great fool.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter PRINCE HENRY and POINS$NEWLINE$PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$POINS
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY and POINS enter.$NEWLINE$PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$POINS

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Before God, I am exceeding weary.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$I swear to God, I’m exceedingly tired.

paragraphs.original: POINS$NEWLINE$Is ’t come to that? I had thought weariness durst not have$NEWLINE$attached one of so high blood.
paragraphs.translated: POINS$NEWLINE$Really? I would have thought that weariness wouldn’t dare afflict someone as highly born as you.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Faith, it does me; though it discolors the complexion of my$NEWLINE$greatness to acknowledge it. Doth it not show vilely in me$NEWLINE$to desire small beer?
paragraphs.translated:
PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Well, it afflicts me, although saying so dims my nobility somewhat. Does it make me seem coarse and common to say that I’d love a
small beer?$NEWLINE$small beer$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: POINS$NEWLINE$Why, a prince should not be so loosely studied as to$NEWLINE$remember so weak a composition.
paragraphs.translated: POINS$NEWLINE$A prince shouldn’t be vulgarly inclined toward things like small beer.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Belike then my appetite was not princely got, for, by my$NEWLINE$troth, I do now remember the poor creature small beer. But$NEWLINE$indeed these humble considerations make me out of love$NEWLINE$with my greatness. What a disgrace is it to me to remember$NEWLINE$thy name, or to know thy face tomorrow, or to take note how$NEWLINE$many pair of silk stockings thou hast—with these, and those$NEWLINE$that were thy peach-colored ones—or to bear the inventory$NEWLINE$of thy shirts, as, one for superfluity and another for use. But$NEWLINE$that the tennis-court keeper knows better than I, for it is a$NEWLINE$low ebb of linen with thee when thou keepest not racket$NEWLINE$there, as thou hast not done a great while, because the rest of$NEWLINE$the low countries have made a shift to eat up thy holland; and$NEWLINE$God knows whether those that bawl out the ruins of thy linen$NEWLINE$shall inherit His kingdom; but the midwives say the children$NEWLINE$are not in the fault, whereupon the world increases and$NEWLINE$kindreds are mightily strengthened.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Then I suppose don’t have a prince’s appetite, because right now all I can think about is small beer. But it’s true: all these everyday considerations distance me from my own nobility. It’s disgraceful that I should be familiar with a man like you! To know your name, your face, and your wardrobe so intimately that I know that you have two pairs of stockings: the ones you’re wearing now, and those peach-colored ones. I even know how many shirts you have: one to wear, and one extra. But then, the keeper of the tennis courts knows your wardrobe better than I do, for when you’ve run out of clean shirts, you don’t show up to play. And you haven’t played in a while, because the whore houses have eaten all the rest of your money, which you’d otherwise use to buy more shirts. God only knows whether all the crying brats you’ve fathered will make it to heaven. But then, the midwives say that babies don’t bear the sins of the parents. That’s how the population increases, and families are strengthened.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: POINS$NEWLINE$How ill it follows, after you have labored so hard, you should$NEWLINE$talk so idly! Tell me, how many good young princes would$NEWLINE$do so, their fathers being so sick as yours at this time is?
paragraphs.translated: POINS$NEWLINE$It seems wrong, after all your hard work in battle, that you should be spending your time now in idle chatter. How many other princes would behave like this if their fathers were as sick as yours?

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Shall I tell thee one thing, Poins?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Can I tell you something, Poins?

paragraphs.original: POINS$NEWLINE$Yes, faith, and let it be an excellent good thing.
paragraphs.translated: POINS$NEWLINE$Sure; and make sure it’s an excellent thing.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$It shall serve among wits of no higher breeding than thine.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$It’ll be fine, for people who aren’t any smarter than you are.

paragraphs.original: POINS$NEWLINE$Go to. I stand the push of your one thing that you will tell.
paragraphs.translated: POINS$NEWLINE$Go ahead. I’m can take whatever you have to say.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Marry, I tell thee it is not meet that I should be sad, now my$NEWLINE$father is sick—albeit I could tell thee, as to one it pleases me,$NEWLINE$for fault of a better, to call my friend, I could be sad, and sad$NEWLINE$indeed too.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Here it is, then. It’s not seemly for me to be sad over my father’s illness. But I could tell you—as a person who, for lack of anyone else, I’m pleased to call my friend—that I could be sad. I could be very sad, indeed.

paragraphs.original: POINS$NEWLINE$Very hardly, upon such a subject.
paragraphs.translated: POINS$NEWLINE$It would be difficult to feel that way over a thing like this.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$By this hand, thou thinkest me as far in the devil’s book as$NEWLINE$thou and Falstaff for obduracy and persistency. Let the end$NEWLINE$try the man. But I tell thee, my heart bleeds inwardly that my$NEWLINE$father is so sick: and keeping such vile company as thou art$NEWLINE$hath in reason taken from me all ostentation of sorrow.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$I swear, you must think that I’m as sinful as you and Falstaff are, and as stubborn and persistent. We’ll see about that. But I’m telling you: my heart is bleeding for my father, and for his illness. But because I’m hanging out with lowlifes like you, I can’t show how sorrowful I am.

paragraphs.original: POINS$NEWLINE$The reason?
paragraphs.translated: POINS$NEWLINE$Why?

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$What wouldst thou think of me if I should weep?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$What would you think of me if I started crying?

paragraphs.original: POINS$NEWLINE$I would think thee a most princely hypocrite.
paragraphs.translated: POINS$NEWLINE$I would think you’re a royal hypocrite.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$It would be every man’s thought, and thou art a blessed$NEWLINE$fellow to think as every man thinks. Never a man’s thought$NEWLINE$in the world keeps the roadway better than thine. Every man$NEWLINE$would think me an hypocrite indeed. And what accites your$NEWLINE$most worshipful thought to think so?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$That’s what everyone would be thinking. And what’s great about you is that you think just the way everyone else does: nobody sticks to popular opinion quite as well as you. Everyone would think I was a hypocrite, indeed. And, your honor, what makes you think that?

paragraphs.original: POINS$NEWLINE$Why, because you have been so lewd and so much engraffed$NEWLINE$to Falstaff.
paragraphs.translated: POINS$NEWLINE$Because you’ve behaved so badly, and because you’re so attached to Falstaff.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$And to thee.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$And to you.

paragraphs.original: POINS$NEWLINE$By this light, I am well spoke on. I can hear it with my own$NEWLINE$ears. The worst that they can say of me is that I am a second$NEWLINE$brother, and that I am a proper fellow of my hands; and those$NEWLINE$two things, I confess, I cannot help. By the Mass, here comes$NEWLINE$Bardolph.
paragraphs.translated: POINS$NEWLINE$Honestly, people think highly of me; I hear their praises with my own ears. The worst thing they can say about me is that, as a younger brother, I’ve had no inheritance from my family, and that I’m a good fighter. And I can’t help either of those things. By God, here comes Bardolph.

paragraphs.original: Enter BARDOLPH and the PAGE$NEWLINE$BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$PAGE
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH and the PAGE enter.$NEWLINE$BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$PAGE

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$And the boy that I gave Falstaff. He had him from me$NEWLINE$Christian, and look if the fat villain have not transformed$NEWLINE$him ape.
paragraphs.translated:
PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$And the boy who I sent to work for Falstaff. He was a normal boy when I sent him, and now look:
the fat bastard’s turned him into an ape.$NEWLINE$the fat bastard’s turned him into an ape.$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$God save your Grace.
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$God save your grace!

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$And yours, most noble Bardolph.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$And yours, most noble Bardolph!

paragraphs.original: POINS$NEWLINE$(to BARDOLPH) Come, you virtuous ass, you bashful fool,$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$must you be blushing? Wherefore blush you now? What a$NEWLINE$maidenly man-at-arms are you become! Is ’t such a matter$NEWLINE$to get a pottle-pot’s maidenhead?
paragraphs.translated:
POINS$NEWLINE$(to BARDOLPH) Come on, you principled ass, you timid fool! Why are you blushing? What a womanly solider you are! Is it that big a deal to deflower a two-quart
tankard of ale?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$tankard of ale$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: PAGE$NEWLINE$He calls me e'en now, my lord, through a red lattice, and I$NEWLINE$could discern no part of his face from the window. At last I$NEWLINE$spied his eyes, and methought he had made two holes in the$NEWLINE$ale-wife’s new petticoat and so peeped through.
paragraphs.translated: PAGE$NEWLINE$Just now he called to me from behind a red window shade, and I couldn’t tell his face from the curtain! Finally I saw his eyes, and I thought he’d made two holes in a whore’s skirt and peeped through them!

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Has not the boy profited?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$This kid’s learned a lot from Falstaff, hasn’t he?

paragraphs.original: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Away, you whoreson upright rabbit, away!
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Get out of here, you little rabbit! Get out!

paragraphs.original: PAGE$NEWLINE$Away, you rascally Althea’s dream, away!
paragraphs.translated: PAGE$NEWLINE$You get out, you rotten Althea’s dream!

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Instruct us, boy. What dream, boy?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$What dream, boy? Tell us.

paragraphs.original: PAGE$NEWLINE$Marry, my lord, Althea dreamt she was delivered of a$NEWLINE$firebrand, and therefore I call him her dream.
paragraphs.translated: PAGE$NEWLINE$Sir, Althea dreamed she gave birth to a red-hot iron. That’s why I call him her dream; he’s all red in the face.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$A crown’s worth of good interpretation. There ’tis, boy.
paragraphs.translated:
PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$That joke’s worth a
crown! Here you go, boy.$NEWLINE$crown$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: POINS$NEWLINE$O, that this good blossom could be kept from cankers! Well,$NEWLINE$there is sixpence to preserve thee.
paragraphs.translated: POINS$NEWLINE$I wish this wholesome little flower could be kept away from disease. Well, here’s a sixpence for you.

paragraphs.original: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$An you do not make him hanged among you, the gallows$NEWLINE$shall have wrong.
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$If between the three of you this boy doesn’t end up hanged, the gallows will be cheated.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$And how doth thy master, Bardolph?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$How’s your master Falstaff doing, Bardolph?

paragraphs.original: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Well, my good lord. He heard of your Grace’s coming to$NEWLINE$town. There’s a letter for you.
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Fine, sir. He heard you were coming to town. Here’s a letter for you.

paragraphs.original: POINS$NEWLINE$Delivered with good respect. And how doth the Martlemas$NEWLINE$your master?
paragraphs.translated: POINS$NEWLINE$Delivered very respectfully. How is that fattened calf, your boss?

paragraphs.original: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$In bodily health, sir.
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$His body’s healthy, sir.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: POINS$NEWLINE$Marry, the immortal part needs a physician, but that moves$NEWLINE$not him. Though that be sick, it dies not.
paragraphs.translated: POINS$NEWLINE$That’s right, it’s just his immortal soul that needs a doctor. But he doesn’t care. His soul may be sick, but it won’t die.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$(reads to himself) I do allow this wen to be as familiar with$NEWLINE$(reads to himself)$NEWLINE$me as my dog, and he holds his place, for look you how be$NEWLINE$writes. (he hands the letter to POINS)$NEWLINE$(he hands the letter to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$(reads to himself) I allow this wart to be as familiar with me as my dog, and he holds onto his privileged position. Listen to how he writes. (he hands the letter to POINS)$NEWLINE$(reads to himself)$NEWLINE$(he hands the letter to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: POINS$NEWLINE$(reads) John Falstaff, knight. Every man must know that as$NEWLINE$(reads)$NEWLINE$John Falstaff, knight.$NEWLINE$oft as he has occasion to name himself, even like those that$NEWLINE$are kin to the King, for they never prick their finger but they$NEWLINE$say, “There’s some of the King’s blood spilt.” “How comes$NEWLINE$that?” says he that takes upon him not to conceive. The$NEWLINE$answer is as ready as a borrower’s cap: “I am the King’s$NEWLINE$poor cousin, sir.”
paragraphs.translated: POINS$NEWLINE$(reads) “John Falstaff, knight”—he always throws that title around, every chance he gets. It’s like people who are related to the King: every time they get a tiny cut, they say, “Some of the King’s blood has been spilled.” Then someone pretends not to get it, and asks, “How do you mean?” The answer comes faster than a beggar can whip out his cap: “I’m the King’s poor relative.”$NEWLINE$(reads)

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Nay, they will be kin to us, or they will fetch it from Japheth. But to the letter. (takes the letter and reads) Sir John alstaff, knight, to the son of the King nearest his father, Harry Prince of Wales, greeting.$NEWLINE$(takes the letter and reads)$NEWLINE$Sir John alstaff, knight, to the son of the King nearest his father, Harry Prince of Wales, greeting.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Right. They all say they’re related to us, even if they have to trace the family tree all the way back to Japhet, the common ancestor of all Europeans. But back to the letter. (takes the letter and reads) “Sir John Falstaff—knight to the son of the King, nearest to his father, Harry Prince of Wales—sends his greetings.”$NEWLINE$(takes the letter and reads)

paragraphs.original: POINS$NEWLINE$Why, this is a certificate.
paragraphs.translated: POINS$NEWLINE$Listen to that. It sounds like a contract.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Peace! (reads) I will imitate the honorable Romans in brevity.$NEWLINE$(reads)$NEWLINE$I will imitate the honorable Romans in brevity.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Quiet! (reads) “I will copy the Romans in shortness.”$NEWLINE$(reads)

paragraphs.original: POINS$NEWLINE$He sure means brevity in breath, short-winded.
paragraphs.translated: POINS$NEWLINE$He must mean shortness of breath, and wheezing.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$(reads) I commend me to thee, I commend thee, and I leave thee. Be not too familiar with Poins, for he misuses thy favors so much that he swears thou art to marry his sister$NEWLINE$(reads) I commend me to thee, I commend thee, and I leave thee. Be not too familiar with Poins, for he misuses thy favors so much that he swears thou art to marry his sister
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$(reads) “I salute myself, I salute you, and I’m done. Don’t get too close to Poins. He takes such rampant advantage of your kindness that he swears you will marry his sister Nell. Confess your sins when you have the time; and with that, farewell. Yours up and down$NEWLINE$(reads)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Nell. Repent at idle times as thou mayest, and so, farewell. Thine by yea and no, which is as much as to say, as thou usest him, Jack Falstaff with my familiars, John with my brothers and sisters, and Sir John with all Europe.$NEWLINE$Nell. Repent at idle times as thou mayest, and so, farewell. Thine by yea and no, which is as much as to say, as thou usest him, Jack Falstaff with my familiars, John with my brothers and sisters, and Sir John with all Europe.
paragraphs.translated: (which is to say, in whatever way you feel like), I remain Jack Falstaff to my friends, John to my brothers and sisters, and Sir John to all Europe.”

paragraphs.original: POINS$NEWLINE$My lord, I’ll steep this letter in sack and make him eat it.
paragraphs.translated: POINS$NEWLINE$Sir, I’ll soak this letter in wine and shove it down his throat.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$That’s to make him eat twenty of his words. But do you use$NEWLINE$me thus, Ned? Must I marry your sister?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$That would be making him eat twenty of his words. But are you taking advantage of me like he says, Ned? Must I marry your sister?

paragraphs.original: POINS$NEWLINE$God send the wench no worse fortune! But I never said so.
paragraphs.translated: POINS$NEWLINE$It would be her lucky day if you did. But I never said that.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Well, thus we play the fools with the time, and the spirits of$NEWLINE$the wise sit in the clouds and mock us. (to BARDOLPH) Is your$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$master here in London?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Well, we’re wasting time, and the angels in heaven are mocking us. (to BARDOLPH) Is your boss here in London?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Yea, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Yes, my lord.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Where sups he? Doth the old boar feed in the old frank?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Where’s he eating tonight? Is the old pig eating in the old sty?

paragraphs.original: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$At the old place, my lord, in Eastcheap.
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$At the old place, my lord. In Eastcheap.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$What company?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Who’s with him?

paragraphs.original: PAGE$NEWLINE$Ephesians, my lord, of the old church.
paragraphs.translated: PAGE$NEWLINE$The usual old characters.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Sup any women with him?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Are any women eating with him?

paragraphs.original: PAGE$NEWLINE$None, my lord, but old Mistress Quickly and Mistress Doll$NEWLINE$Tearsheet.
paragraphs.translated: PAGE$NEWLINE$No women sir. Just old Mistress Quickly and Mistress Doll Tearsheet.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$What pagan may that be?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$What heathen is that?

paragraphs.original: PAGE$NEWLINE$A proper gentlewoman, sir, and a kinswoman of my$NEWLINE$master’s.
paragraphs.translated: PAGE$NEWLINE$A proper lady, sir, and my master’s relative.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Even such kin as the parish heifers are to the town bull.—$NEWLINE$Shall we steal upon them, Ned, at supper?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Exactly the kind of relative as the country cows are to the town bull. Ned, should we spy on them as they eat supper?

paragraphs.original: POINS$NEWLINE$I am your shadow, my lord. I’ll follow you.
paragraphs.translated: POINS$NEWLINE$I’m after you like a shadow, my lord: I’ll follow you.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Sirrah—you, boy—and Bardolph, no word to your master$NEWLINE$that I am yet come to town. (gives them money) There’s for$NEWLINE$(gives them money)$NEWLINE$your silence.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Sirrah, you boy, and you, Bardolph—don’t tell your master that I’m back in town. (gives them money) This is for your silence.$NEWLINE$(gives them money)

paragraphs.original: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$I have no tongue, sir.
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$I have no tongue to speak with, sir.

paragraphs.original: PAGE$NEWLINE$And for mine, sir, I will govern it.
paragraphs.translated: PAGE$NEWLINE$As for my tongue, I’ll manage it.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Fare you well. Go.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Farewell to you both; go now.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Exeunt BARDOLPH and PAGE$NEWLINE$BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$PAGE
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH and the PAGE exit.$NEWLINE$BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$PAGE

paragraphs.original: This Doll Tearsheet should be some road.
paragraphs.translated:
This Doll Tearsheet must be some
road.$NEWLINE$road$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: POINS$NEWLINE$I warrant you, as common as the way between Saint Alban’s$NEWLINE$and London.
paragraphs.translated: POINS$NEWLINE$Truly, she’s as well-traveled as the highway to London.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$How might we see Falstaff bestow himself tonight in his true$NEWLINE$colors, and not ourselves be seen?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$How can we see Falstaff behave like his true self tonight, and yet not be detected ourselves?

paragraphs.original: POINS$NEWLINE$Put on two leathern jerkins and aprons, and wait upon him$NEWLINE$at his table as drawers.
paragraphs.translated: POINS$NEWLINE$We’ll put on leather jackets and aprons and wait upon him as bartenders.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$From a god to a bull: a heavy decension. It was Jove’s case.$NEWLINE$From a prince to a 'prentice: a low transformation that shall$NEWLINE$be mine, for in everything the purpose must weigh with the$NEWLINE$folly. Follow me, Ned.
paragraphs.translated:
PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Should a God disguise himself as a bull? That’s quite a degradation. Well,
Jove did it. And should a prince disguise himself as an apprentice bartender and transform into something so lowly? Yes, I will: in every undertaking, the ends must match the means. Follow me, Ned.$NEWLINE$Jove$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter NORTHUMBERLAND, LADY NORTHUMBERLAND, and LADY PERCY$NEWLINE$NORTHUMBERLAND$NEWLINE$LADY NORTHUMBERLAND$NEWLINE$LADY PERCY
paragraphs.translated: NORTHUMBERLAND, LADY NORTHUMBERLAND, and LADY PERCY enter.$NEWLINE$NORTHUMBERLAND$NEWLINE$LADY NORTHUMBERLAND$NEWLINE$LADY PERCY

paragraphs.original: NORTHUMBERLAND$NEWLINE$I pray thee, loving wife and gentle daughter,$NEWLINE$Give even way unto my rough affairs.$NEWLINE$Put not you on the visage of the times$NEWLINE$And be, like them, to Percy troublesome.
paragraphs.translated: NORTHUMBERLAND$NEWLINE$Please, my loving wife and sweet daughter-in-law, support me in my difficult tasks. Don’t let the grimness of these days be reflected in your faces; don’t add to Percy’s troubles.

paragraphs.original: LADY NORTHUMBERLAND$NEWLINE$I have given over. I will speak no more.$NEWLINE$Do what you will; your wisdom be your guide.
paragraphs.translated: LADY NORTHUMBERLAND$NEWLINE$I give up; I won’t say any more. Do what you want. Let your wisdom guide you.

paragraphs.original: NORTHUMBERLAND$NEWLINE$Alas, sweet wife, my honor is at pawn,$NEWLINE$And, but my going, nothing can redeem it.
paragraphs.translated: NORTHUMBERLAND$NEWLINE$For goodness sake, sweet wife, my honor is at stake. Nothing can redeem it except my going.

paragraphs.original: LADY PERCY$NEWLINE$O yet, for God’s sake, go not to these wars.$NEWLINE$The time was, father, that you broke your word,$NEWLINE$When you were more endeared to it than now,$NEWLINE$When your own Percy, when my heart’s dear Harry,$NEWLINE$Threw many a northward look to see his father$NEWLINE$Bring up his powers; but he did long in vain.$NEWLINE$Who then persuaded you to stay at home?$NEWLINE$There were two honors lost, yours and your son’s.$NEWLINE$For yours, the God of heaven brighten it.$NEWLINE$For his, it stuck upon him as the sun$NEWLINE$In the gray vault of heaven, and by his light$NEWLINE$Did all the chivalry of England move$NEWLINE$To do brave acts. He was indeed the glass$NEWLINE$Wherein the noble youth did dress themselves.$NEWLINE$He had no legs that practiced not his gait;$NEWLINE$And speaking thick, which nature made his blemish,$NEWLINE$Became the accents of the valiant;$NEWLINE$For those that could speak low and tardily$NEWLINE$Would turn their own perfection to abuse
paragraphs.translated: LADY PERCY$NEWLINE$For God’s sake, don’t go to these wars! Father-in-law, you once broke your word when you had better reason to keep it than you do now. Your own son Percy—my heart’s beloved Harry—looked northward again and again, hoping to see his father coming with an army. But he hoped in vain. Who persuaded you to stay home that time? Two honors were lost in that battle: yours, and your son’s. As for yours, I hope God will make it shine again. As for Harry’s honor, it clung to him like the sun in a pale blue sky, and by its light every knight in England was moved to act bravely. He was the mirror in which noble youths dressed themselves. All men copied his way of walking, except those who had no legs.$NEWLINE$And talking loudly and quickly—the one flaw nature had given him—became the speech pattern for all brave men. Those who spoke softly and slowly would corrupt their proper speech, just to seem more like

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: To seem like him. So that in speech, in gait,$NEWLINE$In diet, in affections of delight,$NEWLINE$In military rules, humors of blood,$NEWLINE$He was the mark and glass, copy and book,$NEWLINE$That fashioned others. And him—O wondrous him!$NEWLINE$O miracle of men!—him did you leave,$NEWLINE$Second to none, unseconded by you,$NEWLINE$To look upon the hideous god of war$NEWLINE$In disadvantage, to abide a field$NEWLINE$Where nothing but the sound of Hotspur’s name$NEWLINE$Did seem defensible. So you left him.$NEWLINE$Never, O never, do his ghost the wrong$NEWLINE$To hold your honor more precise and nice$NEWLINE$With others than with him. Let them alone.$NEWLINE$The Marshal and the Archbishop are strong.$NEWLINE$Had my sweet Harry had but half their numbers,$NEWLINE$Today might I, hanging on Hotspur’s neck,$NEWLINE$Have talked of Monmouth’s grave.
paragraphs.translated: Harry. In speech, bearing, and diet; in inclinations toward pleasure, in military actions, and in moods, he was the target, mirror, example, and rulebook that other men followed. And him—Oh wondrous him! Oh miracle of men!—you left him! The best man in the world, unsupported by you, faced the hideous god of war from a position of weakness. His only defense was the sound of his own name, and that is how you left him.$NEWLINE$Never insult his memory by letting your honor count more with strangers than with him. Leave them alone: Marshal Mowbray and the Archbishop are strong. If my darling Harry had had half their army, I might be hanging on his neck today, talking about Prince Hal’s grave.

paragraphs.original: NORTHUMBERLAND$NEWLINE$Beshrew your heart,$NEWLINE$Fair daughter, you do draw my spirits from me$NEWLINE$With new lamenting ancient oversights.$NEWLINE$But I must go and meet with danger there,$NEWLINE$Or it will seek me in another place$NEWLINE$And find me worse provided.
paragraphs.translated: NORTHUMBERLAND$NEWLINE$For goodness sake, pretty daughter-in-law. You take me out of myself, reminding me again of these past mistakes. But I must go and face danger there or danger will find me somewhere else, where I will be less prepared.

paragraphs.original: LADY NORTHUMBERLAND$NEWLINE$Oh, fly to Scotland$NEWLINE$Till that the nobles and the armèd commons$NEWLINE$Have of their puissance made a little taste.
paragraphs.translated: LADY NORTHUMBERLAND$NEWLINE$Oh, run to Scotland until these noblemen and their$NEWLINE$armies have skirmished against the king.

paragraphs.original: LADY PERCY$NEWLINE$If they get ground and vantage of the King,$NEWLINE$Then join you with them like a rib of steel$NEWLINE$To make strength stronger; but, for all our loves,$NEWLINE$First let them try themselves. So did your son;$NEWLINE$He was so suffered. So came I a widow,$NEWLINE$And never shall have length of life enough
paragraphs.translated: LADY PERCY$NEWLINE$If they make any headway against the King, then join them, and like a steel rod make their strength even stronger. But in the name of the love you feel for us, let them begin on their own. That’s how your son fought. You allowed him to do that, and that’s how I became a widow. If I spend the rest of my life pouring tears on

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: To rain upon remembrance with mine eyes$NEWLINE$That it may grow and sprout as high as heaven$NEWLINE$For recordation to my noble husband.
paragraphs.translated: the plant of remembrance, it will never grow tall enough to pay proper tribute to my extraordinary husband.

paragraphs.original: NORTHUMBERLAND$NEWLINE$Come, come, go in with me. 'Tis with my mind$NEWLINE$As with the tide swelled up unto his height,$NEWLINE$That makes a still-stand, running neither way.$NEWLINE$Fain would I go to meet the Archbishop,$NEWLINE$But many thousand reasons hold me back.$NEWLINE$I will resolve for Scotland. There am I$NEWLINE$Till time and vantage crave my company.
paragraphs.translated: NORTHUMBERLAND$NEWLINE$Come. Come. Go inside with me. My thoughts are like the ocean at high tide—neither coming in nor going out, seeming to stand still. I want to go join the Archbishop, but many thousands of reasons are holding me back. I’ll go to Scotland and wait there till events unfold and my help is called for.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter two DRAWERS$NEWLINE$DRAWERS
paragraphs.translated: Two DRAWERS enter.$NEWLINE$DRAWERS

paragraphs.original: FRANCIS$NEWLINE$What the devil hast thou brought there—applejohns? Thou$NEWLINE$knowest Sir John cannot endure an applejohn.
paragraphs.translated:
FRANCIS$NEWLINE$What the hell have you got there?
Apple johns? You know Sir John can’t stand apple johns.$NEWLINE$Apple johns$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: SECOND DRAWER$NEWLINE$Mass, thou sayest true. The Prince once set a dish of$NEWLINE$applejohns before him and told him there were five more Sir$NEWLINE$Johns and, putting off his hat, said “I will now take my leave$NEWLINE$of these six dry, round, old, withered knights.” It angered$NEWLINE$him to the heart. But he hath forgot that.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND DRAWER$NEWLINE$Damn, you’re right. One day the Prince put a plate of apple-johns in front of Falstaff and said, “Here are five more Sir Johns.” Then the Prince took off his hat and said, “I’m now going to bid farewell to these six dry, round, old, withered knights.” It angered Sir John deeply, but he got over it.

paragraphs.original: FRANCIS$NEWLINE$Why then, cover, and set them down, and see if thou canst$NEWLINE$find out Sneak’s noise. Mistress Tearsheet would fain hear$NEWLINE$some music.
paragraphs.translated: FRANCIS$NEWLINE$Well then, put the table cloth on and set the dish down. Go see if you can find Sneak’s band of musicians. Mistress Tearsheet wants to hear some music.

paragraphs.original: Enter THIRD DRAWER$NEWLINE$THIRD DRAWER
paragraphs.translated: Enter THIRD DRAWER$NEWLINE$THIRD DRAWER

paragraphs.original: THIRD DRAWER$NEWLINE$Dispatch: the room where they supped is too hot. They’ll$NEWLINE$come in straight.
paragraphs.translated: THIRD DRAWER$NEWLINE$Hurry! The room they ate in was too hot, and they’ll be here any minute.

paragraphs.original: FRANCIS$NEWLINE$Sirrah, here will be the Prince and Master Poins anon, and$NEWLINE$they will put on two of our jerkins and aprons, and Sir John$NEWLINE$must not know of it. Bardolph hath brought word.
paragraphs.translated: FRANCIS$NEWLINE$Sirrah, the Prince and Poins will be here soon. They’re going to put on a couple of our jackets and aprons. Sir John can’t know it’s them. Bardolph came and told me.

paragraphs.original: THIRD DRAWER$NEWLINE$By the Mass, here will be old utis. It will be an excellent$NEWLINE$stratagem.
paragraphs.translated: THIRD DRAWER$NEWLINE$Well, there’s going to be hilarity here! What a great scheme!

paragraphs.original: SECOND DRAWER$NEWLINE$I’ll see if I can find out Sneak.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND DRAWER$NEWLINE$I’ll see if I can find Sneak.

paragraphs.original: FRANCIS and THE DRAWERS exit$NEWLINE$FRANCIS$NEWLINE$THE DRAWERS
paragraphs.translated: The DRAWERS exit.$NEWLINE$DRAWERS

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter MISTRESS QUICKLY and DOLL TEARSHEET$NEWLINE$MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$DOLL TEARSHEET
paragraphs.translated: MISTRESS QUICKLY and DOLL TEARSHEET enter.$NEWLINE$MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$DOLL TEARSHEET

paragraphs.original: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$I' faith, sweetheart, methinks now you are in an excellent$NEWLINE$good temperality. Your pulsidge beats as extraordinarily as$NEWLINE$heart would desire, and your color, I warrant you, is as red$NEWLINE$as any rose, in good truth, la. But, i' faith, you have drunk$NEWLINE$too much canaries, and that’s a marvellous searching wine,$NEWLINE$and it perfumes the blood ere one can say “What’s this?”$NEWLINE$How do you now?
paragraphs.translated:
MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$I swear, sweetheart, you seem to be in a great
temporality. Your
pulsidge is beating as strongly as you could want, and your color is as red as a rose; truly! But seriously, I do think you’ve drank too much of that sweet wine from the Canary Islands—it’s a mighty powerful drink, and it’ll get into your blood faster than you can say, “What’s this?” How are you feeling now?$NEWLINE$temporality$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$pulsidge$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: DOLL TEARSHEET$NEWLINE$Better than I was. Hem.
paragraphs.translated: DOLL TEARSHEET$NEWLINE$Better than I was before. (she coughs or belches)$NEWLINE$(she coughs or belches)

paragraphs.original: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$Why, that’s well said. A good heart’s worth gold.$NEWLINE$Lo, here comes Sir John.
paragraphs.translated: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$Well said! A healthy heart is worth its weight in gold. Look, here comes Sir John.

paragraphs.original: Enter FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$FALSTAFF
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF enters.$NEWLINE$FALSTAFF

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$(sings) When Arthur first in court—Empty the jordan.$NEWLINE$(sings) When Arthur first in court$NEWLINE$(sings) And was a worthy king—How now, Mistress Doll?$NEWLINE$(sings) And was a worthy king—
paragraphs.translated:
FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$(singing)
“When Arthur first in court”—somebody empty the chamber pot! “And was a worthy king”—how are you, Mistress Doll?$NEWLINE$(singing)$NEWLINE$“When Arthur first in court”—somebody empty the chamber pot! “And was a worthy king”$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$Sick of a calm, yea, good faith.
paragraphs.translated:
MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$She’s sick of a
qualm, she is.$NEWLINE$qualm$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$So is all her sect. An they be once in a calm, they are sick.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$That’s how all the women in her profession are. As soon as they’re calm—and not in someone’s bed—they get sick.

paragraphs.original: DOLL TEARSHEET$NEWLINE$A pox damn you, muddy rascal. Is that all the comfort you$NEWLINE$give me?
paragraphs.translated: DOLL TEARSHEET$NEWLINE$You stupid bastard. Is this how you make me feel better?

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$You make fat rascals, Mistress Doll.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$You make fat bastards, Mistress Doll.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: DOLL TEARSHEET$NEWLINE$I make them? Gluttony and diseases make them; I make$NEWLINE$them not.
paragraphs.translated: DOLL TEARSHEET$NEWLINE$I make them fat? Gluttony and disease will make men fat; I have nothing to do with it.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$If the cook help to make the gluttony, you help to make the$NEWLINE$diseases, Doll. We catch of you, Doll, we catch of you. Grant$NEWLINE$that, my poor virtue, grant that.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Well, cooks help create gluttony, by making and selling food—the object of gluttony. And you help create diseases, Doll. We catch them from you, Doll, we catch them from you: admit it.

paragraphs.original: DOLL TEARSHEET$NEWLINE$Yea, joy, our chains and our jewels.
paragraphs.translated: DOLL TEARSHEET$NEWLINE$Sure, sweetheart. You catch us by the chains and the jewels, and then you steal them from us.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Your broaches, pearls, and ouches—for to serve bravely is$NEWLINE$to come halting off, you know; to come off the breach with$NEWLINE$his pike bent bravely, and to surgery bravely, to venture upon$NEWLINE$the charged chambers bravely—
paragraphs.translated:
FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$“Your
brooches, pearls, and gems”—We fight bravely and then come away limping. We retreat from the breach in the wall with our weapons bravely bent. We head off to the doctor, bravely. And then we charge into the
loaded chambers again, bravely.$NEWLINE$brooches, pearls, and gems”$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$loaded chambers$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: DOLL TEARSHEET$NEWLINE$Hang yourself, you muddy conger, hang yourself!
paragraphs.translated: DOLL TEARSHEET$NEWLINE$Drop dead, you filthy eel. Drop dead!

paragraphs.original: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$By my troth, this is the old fashion. You two never meet but$NEWLINE$you fall to some discord. You are both, i' good truth, as$NEWLINE$rheumatic as two dry toasts. You cannot one bear with$NEWLINE$another’s confirmities. What the good-year! One must bear,$NEWLINE$and that must be you. You are the weaker vessel, as they say,$NEWLINE$the emptier vessel.
paragraphs.translated:
MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$I
swear, this is how it always is. You two even see each other without fighting. You’re as hot as dry toast, you can’t stand each other’s bad qualities. Good grief! But one of you has to bear the burden, and that’s you, Doll. You’re the weaker sex, the empty vessel.$NEWLINE$swear$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: DOLL TEARSHEET$NEWLINE$Can a weak empty vessel bear such a huge full hogshead?$NEWLINE$There’s a whole merchant’s venture of Bourdeaux stuff in$NEWLINE$him. You have not seen a hulk better stuffed in the hold. —$NEWLINE$ome, I’ll be friends with thee, Jack. Thou art going to the
paragraphs.translated: DOLL TEARSHEET$NEWLINE$Can a weak, empty vessel bear the burden of such a huge, full barrel? There’s a whole merchant’s stock of Bordeaux wine in him; you’ve never seen a ship with a fuller cargo hold. Come, Jack, I’ll be friends with

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: wars, and whether I shall ever see thee again or no, there is$NEWLINE$nobody cares.
paragraphs.translated: you. You’re going off to war, and whether or not I ever see you again—well, who cares.

paragraphs.original: Enter FIRST DRAWER$NEWLINE$FIRST DRAWER
paragraphs.translated:
The FIRST
DRAWER enters.$NEWLINE$DRAWER$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: FIRST DRAWER$NEWLINE$Sir, Ancient Pistol’s below and would speak with$NEWLINE$you.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST DRAWER$NEWLINE$Sir, Ensign Pistol’s downstairs. He wants to talk with you.

paragraphs.original: DOLL TEARSHEET$NEWLINE$Hang him, swaggering rascal! Let him not come hither. It is$NEWLINE$the foul-mouthed’st rogue in England.
paragraphs.translated: DOLL TEARSHEET$NEWLINE$Let him drop dead, that hot-tempered jerk! Don’t let him in: he’s got the foulest mouth in England.

paragraphs.original: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$If he swagger, let him not come here. No, by my faith, I must$NEWLINE$live among my neighbors. I’ll no swaggerers: I am in good$NEWLINE$name and fame with the very best. Shut the door. There$NEWLINE$comes no swaggerers here. I have not lived all this while to$NEWLINE$have swaggering now. Shut the door, I pray you.
paragraphs.translated: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$If he’s going to make trouble, don’t let him in. No way; I have my neighbors to think about. I’ll have no troublemakers here. I’ve got my good reputation to watch out for. Shut the doors; no troublemakers are getting in here. I haven’t lived this long to have trouble now. Shut the doors, please.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Dost thou hear, hostess?
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Do you hear, hostess?

paragraphs.original: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$Pray you pacify yourself, Sir John. There comes no swaggerers$NEWLINE$here.
paragraphs.translated: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$Please, be quiet a second, Sir John. No troublemakers are coming in here.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Dost thou hear? It is mine ancient.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Didn’t you hear? It’s my ensign.

paragraphs.original: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$Tilly-vally, Sir John, ne'er tell me. And your ancient$NEWLINE$swaggerer comes not in my doors. I was before Master$NEWLINE$Tisick, the debuty t' other day, and, as he said to me—’twas$NEWLINE$no longer ago than Wednesday last, i' good faith—$NEWLINE$“Neighbour Quickly,” says he—Master Dumb, our minister,$NEWLINE$was by then—“Neighbour Quickly,” says he, “receive those$NEWLINE$that are civil, for,” said he, “you are in an ill name.” Now he$NEWLINE$said so, I can tell whereupon. “For,” says he, “you are an$NEWLINE$honest woman, and well thought on. Therefore take heed$NEWLINE$what guests you receive. Receive,” says he, “no swaggering
paragraphs.translated: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$Oh fiddlesticks, Sir John, I don’t want to hear it. Your Ensign Troublemaker is not coming in here. I talked to Master Tisick, the deputy, the other day. And he said to me—it couldn’t have been longer ago than last Wednesday—“I swear, neighbor Quickly,” he said. (Master Dumbe, the minister, was here at the time.) “Neighbor Quickly,” he said, “only let in people who are well behaved, because,” he said, “your reputation is suffering.” He said that, and I’ll tell you why. “You’re an honest woman, and people think highly of

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: companions.” There comes none here. You would bless you$NEWLINE$to hear what he said. No, I’ll no swaggerers.
paragraphs.translated: you. So think about who you let in. Don’t let in,” he said, “any troublemakers.” And none are getting in. You’d be lucky if you heard what he said. No way, no troublemakers.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$He’s no swaggerer, hostess, a tame cheater, i' faith. You may$NEWLINE$stroke him as gently as a puppy greyhound. He’ll not$NEWLINE$swagger with a Barbary hen if her feathers turn back in any$NEWLINE$show of resistance.—Call him up, drawer.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$He’s not a troublemaker, hostess. He’s a harmless cheater; you can pet him like a little puppy. He wouldn’t even start a fight with a guinea-hen, if her feathers stood up in annoyance. Get him up here, drawer.

paragraphs.original: Exit FIRST DRAWER$NEWLINE$FIRST DRAWER
paragraphs.translated: FIRST DRAWER exits.$NEWLINE$FIRST DRAWER

paragraphs.original: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$“Cheater,” call you him? I will bar no honest man my house,$NEWLINE$nor no cheater, but I do not love swaggering. By my troth,$NEWLINE$I am the worse when one says “swagger.” Feel, masters, how$NEWLINE$I shake; look you, I warrant you.
paragraphs.translated:
MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$You call him a
cheater? I won’t keep an honest man out of this bar, so I won’t keep a cheater out, either.$NEWLINE$cheater$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$But I don’t like troublemakers, I swear. I get sick when I hear the word, “troublemaker.” Feel, masters: I’m shaking. Look, I’m telling you.

paragraphs.original: DOLL TEARSHEET$NEWLINE$So you do, hostess.
paragraphs.translated: DOLL TEARSHEET$NEWLINE$You are shaking.

paragraphs.original: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$Do I? Yea, in very truth, do I, an ’twere an aspen leaf. I$NEWLINE$cannot abide swaggerers.
paragraphs.translated: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$I am?—I am! I swear, I’m shaking like a big tree leaf. I can’t stand troublemakers.

paragraphs.original: Enter PISTOL, BARDOLPH, and the PAGE$NEWLINE$PISTOL$NEWLINE$BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$PAGE
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL, BARDOLPH, and the PAGE enter.$NEWLINE$PISTOL$NEWLINE$BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$PAGE

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$God save you, Sir John.
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Good to see you, Sir John!

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Welcome, Ancient Pistol. Here, Pistol, I charge you with a$NEWLINE$cup of sack. Do you discharge upon mine hostess.
paragraphs.translated:
FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Welcome, Ensign Pistol. Here,
Pistol. I charge you with a glass of wine. Now discharge on the hostess.$NEWLINE$Pistol$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$I will discharge upon her, Sir John, with two bullets.
paragraphs.translated:
PISTOL$NEWLINE$I’ll unload two big
bullets on her, Sir John.$NEWLINE$bullets$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$She is pistol-proof. Sir, you shall not hardly offend her.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$She’s Pistol-proof, sir. You’ll hardly be able to injure her.

paragraphs.original: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$Come, I’ll drink no proofs nor no bullets. I’ll drink no more$NEWLINE$than will do me good, for no man’s pleasure, I.
paragraphs.translated: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$I won’t have any proofs or any bullets. I won’t drink any more than I feel like, not for any man.

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Then to you, Mistress Dorothy! I will charge you.
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Then here’s to you, Mistress. Dorothy, I’ll charge you.

paragraphs.original: DOLL TEARSHEET$NEWLINE$Charge me! I scorn you, scurvy companion. What, you poor,$NEWLINE$base, rascally, cheating lack-linen mate! Away, you mouldy$NEWLINE$rogue, away! I am meat for your master.
paragraphs.translated: DOLL TEARSHEET$NEWLINE$Charge me? Get lost, you sick jerk. What? You broke, rude, scheming, cheating, shirtless fool! Get away from me, you moldy bastard, away! I’m meant for your betters.

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$I know you, Mistress Dorothy.
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$I know you, Mistress Dorothy.

paragraphs.original: DOLL TEARSHEET$NEWLINE$Away, you cutpurse rascal, you filthy bung, away! By this$NEWLINE$wine, I’ll thrust my knife in your mouldy chaps an you play$NEWLINE$the saucy cuttle with me. Away, you bottle-ale rascal, you$NEWLINE$basket-hilt stale juggler, you. Since when, I pray you, sir?$NEWLINE$God’s light, with two points on your shoulder? Much!
paragraphs.translated: DOLL TEARSHEET$NEWLINE$Get away, you pickpocket rascal! You dirty thief, away! I swear on this wine, I’ll stick a knife in your rotten cheeks if you keep abusing me like this. Out, you boozy rascal! You imposter of a solider! Since when are you a soldier, I ask you? With two armor tags on your shoulder? I’m sure!

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$God let me not live, but I will murder your ruff for this.
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$I’ll strangle your neck for that, or I’ll die trying.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$No more, Pistol. I would not have you go off here. Discharge$NEWLINE$yourself of our company, Pistol.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Hold it, Pistol. I don’t want you to go off here. Discharge someplace else, Pistol.

paragraphs.original: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$No, good Captain Pistol, not here, sweet captain.
paragraphs.translated: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$No, good Captain Pistol. Not here, sweet captain.

paragraphs.original: DOLL TEARSHEET$NEWLINE$Captain? Thou abominable damned cheater, art thou not$NEWLINE$ashamed to be called captain? An captains were of my mind,$NEWLINE$they would truncheon you out for taking their names upon$NEWLINE$you before you have earned them. You a captain? You slave,
paragraphs.translated: DOLL TEARSHEET$NEWLINE$Captain? You horrible, damned liar, aren’t you ashamed to be called “captain”? If captains shared my opinions, they’d beat you for taking their rank without earning it. You, a captain? You bastard, for what? For

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: for what? For tearing a poor whore’s ruff in a bawdy house?$NEWLINE$He a captain! Hang him, rogue. He lives upon mouldy$NEWLINE$stewed prunes and dried cakes. A captain? God’s light, these$NEWLINE$villains will make the word as odious as the word “occupy,”$NEWLINE$which was an excellent good word before it was ill sorted.$NEWLINE$Therefore captains had need look to ’t.
paragraphs.translated:
tearing a poor whore’s clothes in a whorehouse? Him, a captain? Let him drop dead, the rogue! He lives off the moldy food you find in brothels. A captain? For God’s sake! Men like him will make the word “captain” as nasty as the word
“occupy,” which was a fine word before it got corrupted. Captains had better watch out.$NEWLINE$“occupy,”$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Pray thee go down, good ancient.
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Please, calm down, good ensign.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Hark thee hither, Mistress Doll.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Listen here, Mistress Doll.

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Not I. I tell thee what, Corporal Bardolph, I could tear her.$NEWLINE$I’ll be revenged of her.
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Not me. I’ll tell you what, Corporal Bardolph, I could tear her. I’ll get revenge on her.

paragraphs.original: PAGE$NEWLINE$Pray thee go down.
paragraphs.translated: PAGE$NEWLINE$Please, calm down!

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$I’ll see her damned first to Pluto’s damnèd lake, by this$NEWLINE$hand, to th' infernal deep with Erebus and tortures vile also.$NEWLINE$Hold hook and line, say I. Down, down, dogs! Down, Fates!$NEWLINE$Have we not Hiren here?
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$I’ll see her damned first. To the waters of hell, I swear, to the endless deep, with chaos and vile tortures. Hold onto that pole, I say. Down, down, dogs! Down, fates! Here’s my sword!

paragraphs.original: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$Good Captain Peesell, be quiet. 'Tis very late, i' faith. I$NEWLINE$beseek you now, aggravate your choler.
paragraphs.translated: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$Captain Pisser, be quiet! It’s late. I beg of you, stop being angry!

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$These be good humors indeed. Shall pack-horses$NEWLINE$And hollow pampered jades of Asia, which cannot go but$NEWLINE$thirty mile a day,$NEWLINE$Compare with Caesars and with cannibals, and Troyant$NEWLINE$Greeks? Nay, rather damn them with King$NEWLINE$Cerberus, and let the welkin roar. Shall we fall foul$NEWLINE$for toys?
paragraphs.translated:
PISTOL$NEWLINE$Now we’re talking! Are we going to let old
nags and pampered horses (who can’t manage more than a few miles a day) be compared with kings, and generals, and mythic heroes? No! Damn them to hell, and let the storms rage! Should we fight over nothing?$NEWLINE$nags$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$By my troth, captain, these are very bitter words.
paragraphs.translated: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$My goodness, captain! Those are strong words!

paragraphs.original: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Begone, good ancient. This will grow to a brawl anon.
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$You should go now, ensign. This is going to get out of control in a minute.

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Die men like dogs! Give crowns like pins! Have we not$NEWLINE$Hiren here?
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Let men die like dogs! Give away kings' crowns like they’re nothing! Isn’t this a sword we have here?

paragraphs.original: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$O' my word, captain, there’s none such here. What the good-$NEWLINE$year, do you think I would deny her? For God’s sake, be$NEWLINE$quiet.
paragraphs.translated:
MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$My
word of honor, captain, there’s no such thing here! For goodness sake! Do you think I’d say she’s not if she were? For God’s sake, be quiet!$NEWLINE$word of honor$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Then feed and be fat, my fair Calipolis. Come, give ’s some$NEWLINE$sack. Si fortune me tormente, sperato me contento. Fear we$NEWLINE$Si fortune me tormente, sperato me contento.$NEWLINE$broadsides? No, let the fiend give fire. Give me some sack,$NEWLINE$and, sweetheart, lie thou there. (lays down his sword) Come$NEWLINE$(lays down his sword)$NEWLINE$we to full points here? And are etceteras nothing?
paragraphs.translated:
PISTOL$NEWLINE$Then eat and grow fat, my sweet lady! Come, bring me some wine. Si
fortuna me tormente, sperato me contento. Are we scared of an attack? No! Let the devil open fire. Give me some wine, and darling, lie there. (he lays his sword down) Is the party over? What about the rest of it, the
et ceteras?$NEWLINE$Si$NEWLINE$fortuna me tormente$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$sperato me contento.$NEWLINE$(he lays his sword down)$NEWLINE$et ceteras$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Pistol, I would be quiet.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Pistol, I’d be quiet if I were you.

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Sweet knight, I kiss thy neaf. What, we have seen the seven$NEWLINE$stars.
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Sweet knight, I kiss your fist. Look! It’s so late—we can see the Big Dipper out.

paragraphs.original: DOLL TEARSHEET$NEWLINE$For God’s sake, thrust him downstairs. I cannot endure such$NEWLINE$a fustian rascal.
paragraphs.translated: DOLL TEARSHEET$NEWLINE$For God’s sake, throw him down the stairs. I can’t stand such a worthless jerk.

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$“Thrust him downstairs”? Know we not Galloway nags?
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Throw him down the stairs? Don’t we know a common prostitute when we see one?

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Quoit him down, Bardolph, like a shove-groat shilling. Nay,$NEWLINE$an he do nothing but speak nothing, he shall be nothing here.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Toss him down, Bardolph, like a coin on a game board. He does nothing but talk a bunch of nothing, so he’s going to count for nothing here.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Come, get you downstairs.
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Come on. Get downstairs.

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$What! shall we have incision? Shall we imbrue? (snatches up his sword) Then death rock me asleep, abridge my doleful$NEWLINE$(snatches up his sword)$NEWLINE$days. Why then, let grievous, ghastly, gaping wounds$NEWLINE$untwine the Sisters Three. Come, Atropos, I say.
paragraphs.translated:
PISTOL$NEWLINE$What? Is there going to be
cutting now? Shall we be soaked in blood? (he grabs his sword) Then let death sing me a lullaby; let him end my melancholy days! Let grievous, ghastly, gaping wounds unravel the thread of my life, spun by those three sisters of fate! Come, Atropos, cut off my thread!$NEWLINE$cutting$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$(he grabs his sword)

paragraphs.original: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$Here’s goodly stuff toward!
paragraphs.translated: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$This ought to be good.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Give me my rapier, boy.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Give me my sword, boy.

paragraphs.original: DOLL TEARSHEET$NEWLINE$I pray thee, Jack, I pray thee do not draw.
paragraphs.translated: DOLL TEARSHEET$NEWLINE$Please, Jack, please; don’t fight!

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Get you downstairs. (drawing and driving PISTO out)$NEWLINE$(drawing and driving$NEWLINE$out)
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Get downstairs! (he draws his sword and chases PISTOL)$NEWLINE$(he draws his sword and chases$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$Here’s a goodly tumult. I’ll forswear keeping house afore$NEWLINE$I’ll be in these tirrits and frights. So, murder, I warrant now.$NEWLINE$Alas, alas, put up your naked weapons, put up your naked$NEWLINE$weapons.
paragraphs.translated: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$This is going to be some fight! I would sooner close this bar than put up with terrors and fits. It’s murder, I swear! Oh my! Oh my! Put away your naked weapons! Put away your naked weapons!

paragraphs.original: Exeunt PISTOL pursued by BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$PISTOL$NEWLINE$BARDOLPH
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL exits, pursued by BARDOLPH.$NEWLINE$PISTOL$NEWLINE$BARDOLPH

paragraphs.original: DOLL TEARSHEET$NEWLINE$I pray thee, Jack, be quiet. The rascal’s gone. Ah, you$NEWLINE$whoreson little valiant villain, you.
paragraphs.translated: DOLL TEARSHEET$NEWLINE$Please, Jack, calm down; the jerk’s gone. Oh you son-of-a-bitch, brave little bastard, you!

paragraphs.original: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$Are you not hurt i' the groin? Methought he made a shrewd thrust at your belly.
paragraphs.translated: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$Did he hurt you in the groin? I thought he got in a good shot at your belly.

paragraphs.original: Enter BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$BARDOLPH
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH enters.$NEWLINE$BARDOLPH

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Have you turned him out o' doors?
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Did you kick him out of here?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Yea, sir. The rascal’s drunk. You have hurt him, sir, i' the shoulder.
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Yup! The jerk’s drunk. You hurt his shoulder.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$A rascal to brave me!
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$That jerk! How dare he challenge me!
