paragraphs.original: DOLL TEARSHEET$NEWLINE$Ah, you sweet little rogue, you. Alas, poor ape, how thou$NEWLINE$sweat’st! Come, let me wipe thy face. Come on, you$NEWLINE$whoreson chops. Ah, rogue, i' faith, I love thee. Thou art as$NEWLINE$valorous as Hector of Troy, worth five of Agamemnon, and$NEWLINE$ten times better than the Nine Worthies. Ah, villain!
paragraphs.translated:
DOLL TEARSHEET$NEWLINE$Oh, you sweet little rogue, you! Oh my, you poor monkey, you’re sweating! Come, let me wipe your face. Come on, you fat bastard. Oh, you rogue! I swear, I love you. You’re as brave as
Hector of Troy, you’re worth five Agamemnons, and you’re ten times better than the nine wonders of the world! Oh, you villain!$NEWLINE$Hector of Troy$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Ah, rascally slave! I will toss the rogue in a blanket.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$The no-good jerk! I’ll wrap the rogue in a blanket, the way they punish cowards.

paragraphs.original: DOLL TEARSHEET$NEWLINE$Do, an thou darest for thy heart. An thou dost, I’ll canvass$NEWLINE$thee between a pair of sheets.
paragraphs.translated: DOLL TEARSHEET$NEWLINE$Do it, if you dare. If you do, I’ll toss you between a pair of sheets!

paragraphs.original: Enter musicians
paragraphs.translated: The musicians enter.

paragraphs.original: PAGE$NEWLINE$The music is come, sir.
paragraphs.translated: PAGE$NEWLINE$The music is here, sir.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Let them play.—Play, sirs.—Sit on my knee, Doll. A rascal$NEWLINE$bragging slave! The rogue fled from me like quicksilver.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Let them play. Play, sirs. Sit on my knee, Doll. A no-good, bragging jerk! The fool ran from me like quicksilver.

paragraphs.original: DOLL TEARSHEET$NEWLINE$I' faith, and thou followed’st him like a church. Thou$NEWLINE$whoreson little tidy Bartholomew boar-pig, when wilt thou$NEWLINE$leave fighting a-days and foining a-nights and begin to patch$NEWLINE$up thine old body for heaven?
paragraphs.translated: DOLL TEARSHEET$NEWLINE$Truly, and you chased him like a church—slowly. You rotten little fat roasting pig! When will you stop fighting all day and thrusting all night, and start to get your body ready for its final resting place?

paragraphs.original: Enter, behind, PRINCE HENRY and POINS, disguised as drawers$NEWLINE$PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$POINS
paragraphs.translated: Unseen, PRINCE HENRY and POINS enter, disguised as drawers.$NEWLINE$PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$POINS

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Peace, good Doll. Do not speak like a death’s-head; do not bid$NEWLINE$me remember mine end.
paragraphs.translated:
FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Quiet, Doll. Don’t talk like a
death’s-head. Don’t make me think of my own end.$NEWLINE$death’s-head$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: DOLL TEARSHEET$NEWLINE$Sirrah, what humor’s the Prince of?
paragraphs.translated:
DOLL TEARSHEET$NEWLINE$Sirrah, what’s the
Prince like?$NEWLINE$Prince$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$A good shallow young fellow, he would have made a good$NEWLINE$pantler; he would a' chipped bread well.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$He’s a shallow youngster. He would have made a good pantry servant: he would have been great at trimming the crusts off bread.

paragraphs.original: DOLL TEARSHEET$NEWLINE$They say Poins has a good wit.
paragraphs.translated: DOLL TEARSHEET$NEWLINE$They say Poins is smart.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$He a good wit? Hang him, baboon. His wit’s as thick as$NEWLINE$Tewksbury mustard. There’s no more conceit in him than is$NEWLINE$in a mallet.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Him, smart? Hang him, he’s a baboon! He’s as thick as mustard, and no smarter than a sledgehammer.

paragraphs.original: DOLL TEARSHEET$NEWLINE$Why does the Prince love him so then?
paragraphs.translated: DOLL TEARSHEET$NEWLINE$Then why does the Prince love him?

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Because their legs are both of a bigness, and he plays at$NEWLINE$quoits well, and eats conger and fennel, and drinks off$NEWLINE$candles' ends for flap-dragons, and rides the wild mare with$NEWLINE$the boys, and jumps upon joint stools, and swears with a$NEWLINE$good grace, and wears his boots very smooth, like unto the$NEWLINE$sign of the Leg, and breeds no bate with telling of discreet$NEWLINE$stories, and such other gambol faculties he has that show a$NEWLINE$weak mind and an able body, for the which the Prince admits$NEWLINE$him; for the Prince himself is such another. The weight of a$NEWLINE$hair will turn the scales between their avoirdupois.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Because their legs are the same size, and he likes to play the game of quoits and eat fatty foods; and he’ll play drinking games, like dropping burning candle ends into his drinks. He plays on the see-saw with the boys, and pulls crazy stunts, and curses nicely. And his boots fit nice and smooth, just like the ones painted on the shoe store’s signs. And he doesn’t cause trouble by spilling secrets. He has all kinds of qualities associated with weak minds and healthy bodies, and that’s why the Prince keeps him around: because the Prince is exactly the same. There’s not a hair’s difference between the two of them.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$(to POINS) Would not this nave of a wheel have his ears cut off?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$(to POINS) We should cut this fatso’s ears off.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: POINS$NEWLINE$Let’s beat him before his whore.
paragraphs.translated: POINS$NEWLINE$Let’s beat him in front of his whore.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Look whe'er the withered elder hath not his poll clawed like$NEWLINE$a parrot.
paragraphs.translated:
PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Look at that old
geezer having his head scratched like a parrot.$NEWLINE$geezer$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: POINS$NEWLINE$Is it not strange that desire should so many years outlive$NEWLINE$performance?
paragraphs.translated: POINS$NEWLINE$Isn’t it odd that desire lasts so much longer than the ability to perform?

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Kiss me, Doll.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Kiss me, Doll.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Saturn and Venus this year in conjunction! What says th'$NEWLINE$almanac to that?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Saturn and Venus must be aligned this year! What do you think the astrological tables have to say about that?$NEWLINE$Saturn and Venus$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: POINS$NEWLINE$And look whether the fiery trigon, his man, be not lisping to$NEWLINE$his master’s old tables, his notebook, his counsel keeper.
paragraphs.translated: POINS$NEWLINE$And look. That fiery-faced Bardolph is whispering sweet nothings to Quickly, his master’s old confidante.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$(to DOLL) Thou dost give me flattering busses.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$(to DOLL) You flatter me with your kisses.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: DOLL TEARSHEET$NEWLINE$By my troth, I kiss thee with a most constant heart.
paragraphs.translated: DOLL TEARSHEET$NEWLINE$I swear, my kisses are heartfelt.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$I am old, I am old.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$I’m old. I’m old.

paragraphs.original: DOLL TEARSHEET$NEWLINE$I love thee better than I love e'er a scurvy young boy of them$NEWLINE$all.
paragraphs.translated: DOLL TEARSHEET$NEWLINE$I love you more than I could love any ridiculous young man in the world.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$What stuff wilt have a kirtle of? I shall receive money o'$NEWLINE$Thursday; shalt have a cap tomorrow. A merry song! Come,$NEWLINE$it grows late. We’ll to bed. Thou 'lt forget me when I am$NEWLINE$gone.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$What fabric do you want a new skirt made out of? I’ll get paid on Thursday, so you’ll get a new hat tomorrow. Let’s have a happy song. It’s getting late; let’s go to bed. You’ll forget me when I’m gone.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: DOLL TEARSHEET$NEWLINE$By my troth, thou 'lt set me a-weeping an thou sayest so.$NEWLINE$Prove that ever I dress myself handsome till thy return. Well,$NEWLINE$harken a' th' end.
paragraphs.translated: DOLL TEARSHEET$NEWLINE$I swear, you’ll make me cry if you talk like that. I won’t wear any beautiful clothing till you return. Well, we’ll see what happens.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Some sack, Francis.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Some wine, Francis.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY AND POINS$NEWLINE$Anon, anon, sir.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY AND POINS$NEWLINE$Right away, sir!

paragraphs.original: Coming forward
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY and POINS reveal themselves.$NEWLINE$PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$POINS

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Ha? A bastard son of the King’s?—And art not thou$NEWLINE$Poins his brother?
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$What! A bastard son of the King? And aren’t you Poins, his brother?

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Why, thou globe of sinful continents, what a life dost thou$NEWLINE$lead?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Your globe, covered with continents of sin! What kind of life are you leading?

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$A better than thou. I am a gentleman. Thou art a drawer.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$A better life than you. I’m a gentleman and you’re just a drawer.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Very true, sir, and I come to draw you out by the ears.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$That’s right, sir. And I’m going to draw you out of this room by the ears.

paragraphs.original: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$O, the Lord preserve thy good Grace! By my troth, welcome$NEWLINE$to London. Now the Lord bless that sweet face of thine. O$NEWLINE$Jesu, are you come from Wales?
paragraphs.translated: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$Oh, may God bless you, sir. I swear, welcome to London. God bless that sweet face of yours! Oh Jesus! Have you come from Wales?

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Thou whoreson mad compound of majesty, (indicating$NEWLINE$(indicating$NEWLINE$DOLL) by this light flesh and corrupt blood, thou art welcome.$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$You son of a bitch, you insane block of royalty! (indicating DOLL) I swear on this piece of weak flesh and corrupt blood that you’re welcome here!$NEWLINE$(indicating$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: DOLL TEARSHEET$NEWLINE$How? You fat fool, I scorn you.
paragraphs.translated: DOLL TEARSHEET$NEWLINE$What? You fat fool! The hell with you!

paragraphs.original: POINS$NEWLINE$My lord, he will drive you out of your revenge and turn all$NEWLINE$to a merriment, if you take not the heat.
paragraphs.translated: POINS$NEWLINE$My lord, if you don’t strike while the iron’s hot, he’ll turn everything into a joke and rob you of your chance for revenge.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$You whoreson candle-mine, you how vilely did you speak of$NEWLINE$me even now before this honest, virtuous, civil$NEWLINE$gentlewoman!
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$You son of a whore, you giant piece of candle wax, you said such horrible things about me just now, in front of this honest, upstanding and well-behaved lady.

paragraphs.original: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$God’s blessing of your good heart, and so she is, by my troth.
paragraphs.translated: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$May God bless your good heart! She is all that, I swear.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Didst thou hear me?
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Did you hear me?

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Yea, and you knew me, as you did when you ran away by$NEWLINE$Gad’s Hill. You knew I was at your back, and spoke it on$NEWLINE$purpose to try my patience.
paragraphs.translated:
PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Yes. And you knew I was there, right? It’s just like when you ran away at
Gad’s Hill : you knew I was the one who beat you, and you made up some story just to irritate me.$NEWLINE$Gad’s Hill$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$No, no, no; not so. I did not think thou wast within hearing.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$No, no, no. Not at all. I had no idea you were there.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$I shall drive you, then, to confess the wilfull abuse, and then$NEWLINE$I know how to handle you.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Then I’m going to make you confess that you deliberately slandered me. And then I’ll know what to do next.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$No abuse, Hal, o' mine honor, no abuse.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$No slander, Hal. On my honor, no slander.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Not to dispraise me and call me pantier and bread-chipper$NEWLINE$and I know not what?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$No? To malign me, and call me a pantry servant and a bread-trimmer, and I don’t know what else?

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$No abuse, Hal.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$No slander, Hal.

paragraphs.original: POINS$NEWLINE$No abuse?
paragraphs.translated: POINS$NEWLINE$No slander?

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$No abuse, Ned, i' th' world, honest Ned, none. I dispraised$NEWLINE$him before the wicked, that the wicked might not fall in love$NEWLINE$with thee; in which doing, I have done the part of a careful$NEWLINE$friend and a true subject, and thy father is to give me thanks$NEWLINE$for it. No abuse, Hal.—None, Ned, none. No, faith, boys, none.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$No slander, Ned, in the world, honest Ned, none. I maligned him only to the wicked, so that the wicked wouldn’t fall in love with him. And by doing that, I’ve acted like a good friend and loyal subject, and your father should thank me for it. No slander, Hal, none, Ned. No, truly boys, none.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$See now whether pure fear and entire cowardice doth not$NEWLINE$make thee wrong this virtuous gentlewoman to close with$NEWLINE$us. Is she of the wicked, is thine hostess here of the wicked,$NEWLINE$or is thy boy of the wicked, or honest Bardolph, whose zeal$NEWLINE$burns in his nose, of the wicked?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Now your absolute fear and utter cowardliness has made you wrong this good lady in order to make peace with us. Is she wicked? Is this hostess here wicked? Is your boy here wicked? Or honest Bardolph, whose piety burns in his face? Is he wicked?

paragraphs.original: POINS$NEWLINE$Answer, thou dead elm, answer.
paragraphs.translated: POINS$NEWLINE$Answer, you withered old trunk, answer.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$The fiend hath pricked down Bardolph irrecoverable, and$NEWLINE$his face is Lucifer’s privy kitchen, where he doth nothing but$NEWLINE$roast malt-worms. For the boy, there is a good angel about$NEWLINE$him, but the devil outbids him too.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$The devil has marked Bardolph as long gone, and his face is Lucifer’s kitchen, where only drunks are served. As for the boy, he may have a good spirit on one shoulder, but the devil on the other is stronger.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$For the women?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$And the women?

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$For one of them, she’s in hell already and burns poor souls.$NEWLINE$For the other, I owe her money, and whether she be damned$NEWLINE$for that I know not.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$One of them is in hell already, where she gets poor souls hot. As for the other, I owe her money. If she’s damned for that, I have no idea.

paragraphs.original: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$No, I warrant you.
paragraphs.translated: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$I’m not, I promise you that.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$No, I think thou art not; I think thou art quit for that. Marry,$NEWLINE$there is another indictment upon thee for suffering flesh to$NEWLINE$be eaten in thy house contrary to the law, for the which I$NEWLINE$think thou wilt howl.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$No, I think you’re not. I think you’ve been excused for that. But there’s another charge against you. You serve flesh in this place, and that’s against the law. You’re going to hell for that.

paragraphs.original: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$All vitlars do so. What’s a joint of mutton or two in a whole$NEWLINE$Lent?
paragraphs.translated: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$Everybody who serves food does that. What’s wrong with a bite or two of meat during Lent?

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$You, gentlewoman.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$You, good lady—

paragraphs.original: DOLL TEARSHEET$NEWLINE$What says your Grace?
paragraphs.translated: DOLL TEARSHEET$NEWLINE$What is it, gracious sir?

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$His grace says that which his flesh rebels against.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$He may speak to you graciously, but his body feels otherwise.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Knocking within
paragraphs.translated: Knocking is heard offstage.

paragraphs.original: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$Who knocks so loud at door? Look to th' door there, Francis.
paragraphs.translated: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$Who’s knocking so loudly on the door? Francis, go see.

paragraphs.original: Enter PETO$NEWLINE$PETO
paragraphs.translated: PETO enters.$NEWLINE$PETO

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Peto, how now, what news?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Peto, how are you? What’s going on?

paragraphs.original: PETO$NEWLINE$The King your father is at Westminster,$NEWLINE$And there are twenty weak and wearied posts$NEWLINE$Come from the north, and as I came along$NEWLINE$I met and overtook a dozen captains,$NEWLINE$Bareheaded, sweating, knocking at the taverns$NEWLINE$And asking everyone for Sir John Falstaff.
paragraphs.translated: PETO$NEWLINE$Your father the King is in Westminster. Twenty exhausted messengers have arrived from the north. And, on my way here, I met a dozen captains, hustling and working hard, knocking on the door of every tavern and searching for Sir John Falstaff.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$By heaven, Poins, I feel me much to blame$NEWLINE$So idly to profane the precious time$NEWLINE$When tempest of commotion, like the south$NEWLINE$Borne with black vapour, doth begin to melt$NEWLINE$And drop upon our bare unarmèd heads.—$NEWLINE$Give me my sword and cloak.—Falstaff, good night.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$My God, Poins, I feel terrible wasting precious time on this idleness when a huge black storm is brewing, soon to open up on our bare, vulnerable heads. Give me my coat and my sword. Good night, Falstaff.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt PRINCE HENRY, POINS, PETO and BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$POINS$NEWLINE$PETO$NEWLINE$BARDOLPH
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY, POINS, PETO, and BARDOLPH exit.$NEWLINE$PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$POINS$NEWLINE$PETO$NEWLINE$BARDOLPH

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Now comes in the sweetest morsel of the night, and we must hence and leave it unpicked.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Now’s the sweetest part of the night, and we have to leave without enjoying it.

paragraphs.original: Knocking within
paragraphs.translated: Knocking is heard offstage.

paragraphs.original: More knocking at the door?
paragraphs.translated: More knocking!

paragraphs.original: Enter BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$BARDOLPH
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH enters.$NEWLINE$BARDOLPH

paragraphs.original: How now, what’s the matter?
paragraphs.translated: What’s going on? What’s the matter?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$You must away to court, sir, presently.$NEWLINE$A dozen captains stay at door for you.
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$You have to go to the royal court immediately, sir. A dozen captains are at the door waiting for you.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$(to the PAGE) Pay the musicians, sirrah.—Farewell,$NEWLINE$(to the$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$hostess.—Farewell, Doll. You see, my good wenches, how$NEWLINE$men of merit are sought after. The undeserver may sleep$NEWLINE$when the man of action is called on. Farewell, good$NEWLINE$wenches. If I be not sent away post, I will see you again ere$NEWLINE$I go.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$(to the PAGE) Pay the musicians, Sirrah. Goodbye, waitress. Goodbye, Doll. See, wenches, how wanted we valuable men are? The good-for-nothing may sleep when the man of action is needed. Farewell, good wenches. If I’m not sent away immediately, I’ll come see you again before I go.$NEWLINE$(to the$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: DOLL TEARSHEET$NEWLINE$I cannot speak. If my heart be not ready to burst—well,$NEWLINE$sweet Jack, have a care of thyself.
paragraphs.translated: DOLL TEARSHEET$NEWLINE$I can’t speak; my heart is ready to burst. Well, sweet Jack, take care of yourself.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Farewell, farewell.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Farewell, farewell.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt FALSTAFF, BARDOLPH, PAGE, and musicians$NEWLINE$FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$PAGE
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF and BARDOLPH exit.$NEWLINE$FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$BARDOLPH

paragraphs.original: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$Well, fare thee well. I have known thee these twenty-nine$NEWLINE$years, come peascod time, but an honester and truer-hearted$NEWLINE$man—well, fare thee well.
paragraphs.translated: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$Well, goodbye. I’ve known you twenty-nine years this June. But a more honest, more good-hearted man—well, fare you well.

paragraphs.original: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$(within) Mistress Tearsheet!$NEWLINE$(within)
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$(offstage) Mistress Tearsheet!$NEWLINE$(offstage)

paragraphs.original: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$What’s the matter?
paragraphs.translated: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$What’s the matter?

paragraphs.original: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$(within) Bid Mistress Tearsheet come to my master.$NEWLINE$(within)
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$(offstage) Mistress Tearsheet, come to my master.$NEWLINE$(offstage)

paragraphs.original: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$O, run, Doll, run, run, good Doll. Come.—She comes$NEWLINE$blubbered.—Yea! Will you come, Doll?
paragraphs.translated: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$O, run, Doll, run; run, good Doll. Come.—She’s coming, all crying and blubbering.—Will you come, Doll?

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter KING Henry in his nightgown, with a page$NEWLINE$KING
paragraphs.translated: KING Henry enters, wearing his nightgown. A page follows.$NEWLINE$KING

paragraphs.original: KING$NEWLINE$Go call the Earls of Surrey and of Warwick;$NEWLINE$But, ere they come, bid them o'erread these letters$NEWLINE$And well consider of them. Make good speed.
paragraphs.translated: KING$NEWLINE$Call the earls of Surrey and Warwick. Tell them to read over these letters before they come, and to think carefully about them. Hurry.

paragraphs.original: Exit page
paragraphs.translated: The page exits.

paragraphs.original: How many thousand of my poorest subjects$NEWLINE$Are at this hour asleep! O sleep, O gentle sleep,$NEWLINE$Nature’s soft nurse, how have I frighted thee,$NEWLINE$That thou no more wilt weigh my eyelids down$NEWLINE$And steep my senses in forgetfulness?$NEWLINE$Why rather, sleep, liest thou in smoky cribs,$NEWLINE$Upon uneasy pallets stretching thee$NEWLINE$And hushed with buzzing night-flies to thy slumber,$NEWLINE$Than in the perfumed chambers of the great,$NEWLINE$Under the canopies of costly state,$NEWLINE$And lull’d with sound of sweetest melody?$NEWLINE$O thou dull god, why liest thou with the vile$NEWLINE$In loathsome beds and leavest the kingly couch$NEWLINE$A watch-case or a common 'larum bell?$NEWLINE$Wilt thou upon the high and giddy mast$NEWLINE$Seal up the shipboy’s eyes, and rock his brains$NEWLINE$In cradle of the rude imperious surge$NEWLINE$And in the visitation of the winds,$NEWLINE$Who take the ruffian billows by the top,$NEWLINE$Curling their monstrous heads and hanging them$NEWLINE$With deafening clamor in the slippery clouds$NEWLINE$That with the hurly death itself awakes?$NEWLINE$Canst thou, O partial sleep, give thy repose$NEWLINE$To the wet sea-boy in an hour so rude,
paragraphs.translated: Thousands of even my poorest subjects are sleeping right now. Oh sleep! Oh sweet sleep, nature’s gentle healer, what have I done to frighten you? You won’t weigh down my eyelids anymore, or dull my mind to make me forget. Sleep, why do you lie in filthy hovels, stretched out on uncomfortable cots, where insects' buzzing is the lullaby? Why don’t you lie in the sweet-smelling bedrooms of kings, under opulent canopies, lulled with soft and beautiful music? You drowsy god, why do you lie with the common people in their loathsome beds, leaving the royal bed lonely like a sentry post, or a bell tower?$NEWLINE$Will you even close the eyes of a ship boy, high up on the whirling mast, and rock him gently in a cradle made of rough, tossing seas and howling winds—winds which take the waves and, curling them over, crashes them through the air with such a deafening noise that they wake death itself? Can you, oh unfair sleep, give rest to a drenched little sailor in the midst of such roughness, and yet deny it to a king?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: And, in the calmest and most stillest night,$NEWLINE$With all appliances and means to boot,$NEWLINE$Deny it to a king? Then, happy low, lie down.$NEWLINE$Uneasy lies the head that wears a crown.
paragraphs.translated: A king on the calmest, stillest night, with everything available for sleep? Then, you happy commoners, put yourselves to bed. The head that wears the crown sleeps uneasily.

paragraphs.original: Enter WARWICK and SURREY$NEWLINE$WARWICK$NEWLINE$SURREY
paragraphs.translated: WARWICK and SURREY enter.$NEWLINE$WARWICK$NEWLINE$SURREY

paragraphs.original: WARWICK$NEWLINE$Many good morrows to your Majesty.
paragraphs.translated: WARWICK$NEWLINE$Good morning, your highness.

paragraphs.original: KING$NEWLINE$Is it good morrow, lords?
paragraphs.translated: KING$NEWLINE$Is it morning, lords?

paragraphs.original: WARWICK$NEWLINE$'Tis one o'clock, and past.
paragraphs.translated: WARWICK$NEWLINE$It’s after one o'clock.

paragraphs.original: KING$NEWLINE$Why then, good morrow to you all, my lords.$NEWLINE$Have you read o'er the letter that I sent you?
paragraphs.translated: KING$NEWLINE$Well, then, good morning to you all, my lords. Have you read the letters I sent you?

paragraphs.original: WARWICK$NEWLINE$We have, my liege.
paragraphs.translated: WARWICK$NEWLINE$We have, your highness.

paragraphs.original: KING$NEWLINE$Then you perceive the body of our kingdom$NEWLINE$How foul it is, what rank diseases grow$NEWLINE$And with what danger near the heart of it.
paragraphs.translated: KING$NEWLINE$Then you can tell how sick the kingdom is. There are serious diseases spreading through its body, very near its heart.

paragraphs.original: WARWICK$NEWLINE$It is but as a body yet distempered,$NEWLINE$Which to his former strength may be restored$NEWLINE$With good advice and little medicine.$NEWLINE$My Lord Northumberland will soon be cooled.
paragraphs.translated: WARWICK$NEWLINE$The body’s only out of sorts. It can be brought back to full health through good care and some medicine. Northumberland will soon be suppressed.

paragraphs.original: KING$NEWLINE$O God, that one might read the book of fate$NEWLINE$And see the revolution of the times$NEWLINE$Make mountains level, and the continent,$NEWLINE$Weary of solid firmness, melt itself$NEWLINE$Into the sea, and other times to see$NEWLINE$The beachy girdle of the ocean$NEWLINE$Too wide for Neptune’s hips; how chance’s mocks$NEWLINE$And changes fill the cup of alteration
paragraphs.translated: KING$NEWLINE$Oh God! If only we could read the book of destiny! We’d see how time changes everything, bringing mountains low and melting the land—which is tired of being solid and firm—into the sea. We’d see how the beach is sometimes too wide for even the tide to conquer. We’d see how blind luck can make mockeries of men, and how change can affect you in countless ways.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: With divers liquors! O, if this were seen,$NEWLINE$The happiest youth, viewing his progress through,$NEWLINE$What perils past, what crosses to ensue,$NEWLINE$Would shut the book, and sit him down and die.$NEWLINE$'Tis not ten years gone$NEWLINE$Since Richard and Northumberland, great friends,$NEWLINE$Did feast together, and in two years after$NEWLINE$Were they at wars. It is but eight years since$NEWLINE$This Percy was the man nearest my soul,$NEWLINE$Who like a brother toiled in my affairs$NEWLINE$And laid his love and life under my foot,$NEWLINE$Yea, for my sake, even to the eyes of Richard$NEWLINE$Gave him defiance. But which of you was by—$NEWLINE$(to WARWICK) You, cousin Nevil, as I may remember—$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$When Richard, with his eye brimful of tears,$NEWLINE$Then checked and rated by Northumberland,$NEWLINE$Did speak these words, now proved a prophecy?$NEWLINE$“Northumberland, thou ladder by the which$NEWLINE$My cousin Bolingbroke ascends my throne”—$NEWLINE$Though then, God knows, I had no such intent,$NEWLINE$But that necessity so bowed the state$NEWLINE$That I and greatness were compelled to kiss—$NEWLINE$“The time shall come,” thus did he follow it,$NEWLINE$“The time will come that foul sin, gathering head,$NEWLINE$Shall break into corruption”—so went on,$NEWLINE$Foretelling this same time’s condition$NEWLINE$And the division of our amity.
paragraphs.translated: If even the happiest youth could read this book, he’d look at the course of his life—the dangers he’s endured, the challenges that still lie ahead—and he’d shut that book, sit down and die. It was less than ten years ago that Richard and Northumberland loved each other. Then two years later, they were at war. Just eight years ago, Northumberland was the man closest to my heart. Like a brother, he devoted himself to me, dedicating both life and limb to my cause. He even challenged Richard on my behalf. But which of you was there—$NEWLINE$I think it was you, Warwick—when Richard, his eyes brimming with tears because of Northumberland’s rebellion, spoke these words that now seem prophetic: “Northumberland, you are the ladder that Bolingbroke has climbed to get to the throne.” Although, God knows, it wasn’t my intention then to become king. But the country needed it so badly, I was forced to rise up and become great. “The time will come,” Richard continued, “when this terrible sin, growing in size, will break out into corruption.” That’s how he went on. He predicted our current condition, and the collapse of our alliances.

paragraphs.original: WARWICK$NEWLINE$There is a history in all men’s lives$NEWLINE$Figuring the nature of the times deceased,$NEWLINE$The which observed, a man may prophesy,$NEWLINE$With a near aim, of the main chance of things$NEWLINE$As yet not come to life, which in their seeds$NEWLINE$And weak beginnings lie intreasurèd.$NEWLINE$Such things become the hatch and brood of time,$NEWLINE$And by the necessary form of this,
paragraphs.translated: WARWICK$NEWLINE$There is a chronicle for every man’s life, which shows what happened to him in times now past. If you study that chronicle, you can prophecy what lies ahead with some accuracy. The seeds of things to come are buried in the things that have already happened. These seeds grow, and become the children of time.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: King Richard might create a perfect guess$NEWLINE$That great Northumberland, then false to him,$NEWLINE$Would of that seed grow to a greater falseness,$NEWLINE$Which should not find a ground to root upon$NEWLINE$Unless on you.
paragraphs.translated: King Richard could look at the pattern of what had gone before and predict perfectly that Northumberland’s betrayal—then still a seed—would someday grow larger, if it could find suitable soil to root in. And you’re the only soil it could have found.

paragraphs.original: KING$NEWLINE$Are these things then necessities?$NEWLINE$Then let us meet them like necessities.$NEWLINE$And that same word even now cries out on us.$NEWLINE$They say the Bishop and Northumberland$NEWLINE$Are fifty thousand strong.
paragraphs.translated: KING$NEWLINE$Were these things necessary, then? Then we’ll treat them like necessities, even though the very word “necessities” cries out against us. They say the Archbishop and Northumberland have fifty thousand men in their army.

paragraphs.original: WARWICK$NEWLINE$It cannot be, my lord.$NEWLINE$Rumor doth double, like the voice and echo,$NEWLINE$The numbers of the feared. Please it your Grace$NEWLINE$To go to bed. Upon my soul, my lord,$NEWLINE$The powers that you already have sent forth$NEWLINE$Shall bring this prize in very easily.$NEWLINE$To comfort you the more, I have received$NEWLINE$A certain instance that Glendower is dead.$NEWLINE$Your Majesty hath been this fortnight ill,$NEWLINE$And these unseasoned hours perforce must add$NEWLINE$Unto your sickness.
paragraphs.translated: WARWICK$NEWLINE$That can’t be, my lord. Rumor, like an echo, doubles the size of our enemy’s army. Please, your highness, go to bed. I swear on my soul that the army you’ve already sent out can win this battle easily. And here’s more good news: I’ve heard for sure that Glendower is dead. You’ve been ill for two weeks now, your majesty. Keeping such irregular hours will surely make things worse.

paragraphs.original: KING$NEWLINE$I will take your counsel.$NEWLINE$And were these inward wars once out of hand,$NEWLINE$We would, dear lords, unto the Holy Land.
paragraphs.translated: KING$NEWLINE$I’ll listen to your advice. And once we’ve got this civil war in hand, we will, my friends, march to the Holy Land.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter Justice SHALLOW and Justice SILENCE, with MOULDY, SHADOW, WART, FEEBLE, BULLCALF, and a servant or two$NEWLINE$SHALLOW$NEWLINE$SILENCE$NEWLINE$MOULDY$NEWLINE$SHADOW$NEWLINE$WART$NEWLINE$FEEBLE$NEWLINE$BULLCALF
paragraphs.translated: Justice SHALLOW and Justice SILENCE enter. They are followed by MOULDY, SHADOW, WART, FEEBLE, BULLCALF, and a servant or two.$NEWLINE$SHALLOW$NEWLINE$SILENCE$NEWLINE$MOULDY$NEWLINE$SHADOW$NEWLINE$WART$NEWLINE$FEEBLE$NEWLINE$BULLCALF

paragraphs.original: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Come on, come on, come on. Give me your hand, sir, give$NEWLINE$me your hand, sir. An early stirrer, by the rood. And how$NEWLINE$doth my good cousin Silence?
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Come on, come on, come on, sir. Shake my hand, sir, shake my hand. You’re an early riser, I swear. How are you, cousin Silence?

paragraphs.original: SILENCE$NEWLINE$Good morrow, good cousin Shallow.
paragraphs.translated: SILENCE$NEWLINE$Good morning, cousin Shallow.

paragraphs.original: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$And how doth my cousin your bedfellow? And your fairest$NEWLINE$daughter and mine, my goddaughter Ellen?
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$And how’s my cousin, your wife? And your prettiest daughter, my fair god-daughter Ellen?

paragraphs.original: SILENCE$NEWLINE$Alas, a black ousel, cousin Shallow.
paragraphs.translated:
SILENCE$NEWLINE$I’m afraid she’s got
dark hair, cousin Shallow!$NEWLINE$dark hair$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$By yea and no, sir. I dare say my cousin William is become$NEWLINE$a good scholar. He is at Oxford still, is he not?
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$By gum, I bet William’s become a real scholar. He’s still at Oxford, right?

paragraphs.original: SILENCE$NEWLINE$Indeed, sir, to my cost.
paragraphs.translated: SILENCE$NEWLINE$He sure is, and I’m the one who’s paying for it.

paragraphs.original: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$He must then to the Inns o' Court shortly. I was once of$NEWLINE$Clement’s Inn, where I think they will talk of mad Shallow$NEWLINE$yet.
paragraphs.translated:
SHALLOW$NEWLINE$He’ll be going to law school soon. I studied law at
Clement’s Inn, where I think they still talk about crazy old Shallow.$NEWLINE$Clement’s Inn$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: SILENCE$NEWLINE$You were called “Lusty Shallow” then, cousin.
paragraphs.translated: SILENCE$NEWLINE$You were known as lusty Shallow back then, cousin.

paragraphs.original: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$By the Mass, I was called anything, and I would have done$NEWLINE$anything indeed too, and roundly too. There was I, and little$NEWLINE$John Doit of Staffordshire, and black George Barnes, and$NEWLINE$Francis Pickbone, and Will Squele, a Cotswold man. You$NEWLINE$had not four such swinge-bucklers in all the Inns o' Court
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$I was known as anything, I swear. And I would have done anything too, and all the way, too. I was there, and little John Doit from Staffordshire, and black-haired George Barnes, and Francis Pickbone, and Will Squele, from the Cotswolds. Since then, no law college

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$again. And I may say to you, we knew where the bona robas$NEWLINE$were and had the best of them all at commandment. Then$NEWLINE$was Jack Falstaff, now Sir John, a boy, and page to Thomas$NEWLINE$Mowbray, Duke of Norfolk.
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$in the world has seen four swashbucklers like us. And let me tell you this: we knew where to find the highest-quality whores, and the best of them were at our beck and call. At that time, Jack Falstaff, now Sir John, was just a boy. He worked as a page for Thomas Mowbray, the Duke of Norfolk.

paragraphs.original: SILENCE$NEWLINE$This Sir John, cousin, that comes hither anon about soldiers?
paragraphs.translated: SILENCE$NEWLINE$Do you mean the same Sir John that’s coming here soon to recruit soldiers?

paragraphs.original: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$The same Sir John, the very same. I see him break Scoggin’s$NEWLINE$head at the court gate, when he was a crack not thus high; and$NEWLINE$the very same day did I fight with one Sampson Stockfish,$NEWLINE$a fruiterer, behind Grey’s Inn. Jesu, Jesu, the mad days that$NEWLINE$I have spent! And to see how many of my old acquaintance$NEWLINE$are dead.
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$The same Sir John, the very same. I saw him beat Skogan upon the head when he was a little tyke, not this high. The same day, I had a fight with a guy named Sampson Stockfish. He sold fruit behind Gray’s Inn. Jesus, Jesus! I’ve had some crazy times! To think that so many of my old pals are dead!

paragraphs.original: SILENCE$NEWLINE$We shall all follow, cousin.
paragraphs.translated: SILENCE$NEWLINE$We’ll all follow them, cousin.

paragraphs.original: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Certain, ’tis certain; very sure, very sure. Death, as the$NEWLINE$Psalmist saith, is certain to all. All shall die. How a good$NEWLINE$yoke of bullocks at Stamford Fair?
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Right you are, very right. That’s for sure, that’s for sure. Death, as the Psalms say, is certain. Everyone dies. How much are they getting for good young bulls at the Stamford county fair?

paragraphs.original: SILENCE$NEWLINE$By my troth, cousin, I was not there.
paragraphs.translated: SILENCE$NEWLINE$Truly, I wasn’t there.

paragraphs.original: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Death is certain. Is old Dooble of your town living yet?
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Death is certain. Is old Double from your hometown still alive?

paragraphs.original: SILENCE$NEWLINE$Dead, sir.
paragraphs.translated: SILENCE$NEWLINE$Dead, sir.

paragraphs.original: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Jesu, Jesu, dead! He drew a good bow, and dead? He shot a$NEWLINE$fine shoot. John o' Gaunt loved him well, and betted much$NEWLINE$money on his head. Dead! He would have clapped i' th'$NEWLINE$clout at twelve score, and carried you a forehand shaft a$NEWLINE$fourteen and fourteen and a half, that it would have done a$NEWLINE$man’s heart good to see. How a score of ewes now?
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Jesus, Jesus, dead! He was a good archer, and dead! He could fire one heck of a shot. John of Gaunt loved him, and used to wager on his shooting. Dead! He could hit a target from two hundred and forty yards, and he could shoot a straight arrow two hundred and eighty yards—maybe even two hundred and ninety. That was something to see. How much are they getting for twenty ewes?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: SILENCE$NEWLINE$Thereafter as they be, a score of good ewes may be worth ten$NEWLINE$pounds.
paragraphs.translated: SILENCE$NEWLINE$Depends on the quality. Twenty good ewes could be worth ten pounds.

paragraphs.original: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$And is old Dooble dead?
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$And old Double’s dead?

paragraphs.original: SILENCE$NEWLINE$Here come two of Sir John Falstaff’s men, as I think.
paragraphs.translated: SILENCE$NEWLINE$Here come two of Sir John Falstaff’s men, I think.

paragraphs.original: Enter BARDOLPH and one with him$NEWLINE$BARDOLPH
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH and another man enter.$NEWLINE$BARDOLPH

paragraphs.original: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Good morrow, honest gentlemen.
paragraphs.translated: Good morning, gentlemen.

paragraphs.original: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$I beseech you, which is Justice Shallow?
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$If you don’t mind, which of you is Judge Shallow?

paragraphs.original: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$I am Robert Shallow, sir, a poor esquire of this county and$NEWLINE$one of the King’s justices of the peace. What is your good$NEWLINE$pleasure with me?
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$I’m Robert Shallow, sir, a poor landowner in this county, and one of the King’s justices of the peace. How can I help you?

paragraphs.original: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$My captain, sir, commends him to you, my captain, Sir John$NEWLINE$Falstaff, a tall gentleman, by heaven, and a most gallant$NEWLINE$leader.
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$My captain sends his regards. My captain, Sir John Falstaff. He’s a valiant gentleman, I swear, and a brave leader.

paragraphs.original: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$He greets me well, sir. I knew him a good backsword man.$NEWLINE$How doth the good knight? May I ask how my lady his wife$NEWLINE$doth?
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$It’s great to hear from him. I knew him to be a good fencer. How’s the good knight doing? And, if you don’t mind my asking, how’s his wife?

paragraphs.original: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Sir, pardon. A soldier is better accommodated than with a$NEWLINE$wife.
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$I beg your pardon, sir. A soldier has no need for a wife; he is well enough accommodated.

paragraphs.original: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$It is well said, in faith, sir, and it is well said indeed too.$NEWLINE$“Better accommodated.” It is good, yea, indeed, is it. Good$NEWLINE$phrases are surely, and ever were, very commendable.
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Well said, I swear, sir. Well said. “Well enough accommodated!” That’s good. That’s very good. Good turns

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: “Accommodated.” It comes of accommodo. Very good, a good phrase.$NEWLINE$accommodo
paragraphs.translated: of phrase deserve to be praised. “Accommodated!” It comes from the Latin, “accommodo.” Very good. That’s a good turn of phrase.$NEWLINE$accommodo

paragraphs.original: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Pardon, sir; I have heard the word—“phrase” call you it? By$NEWLINE$this day, I know not the phrase, but I will maintain the word$NEWLINE$with my sword to be a soldierlike word, and a word of$NEWLINE$exceeding good command, by heaven. “Accommodated,”$NEWLINE$that is when a man is, as they say, accommodated, or when$NEWLINE$a man is being whereby he may be thought to be$NEWLINE$accommodated, which is an excellent thing.
paragraphs.translated:
BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Excuse me, sir. I’ve heard the word. You call it a turn of phrase? I don’t know anything about phrases, but I’ll fight for the word. It’s a good, soldier-like word; a word with many uses, to be sure. “Accommodated.” You can say that a man is accommodated when he has been furnished with supplies. And you can also say that a man is being accommodated when he’s, you know,
being accommodated. Which is an excellent thing.$NEWLINE$being accommodated$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: Enter FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$FALSTAFF
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF enters.$NEWLINE$FALSTAFF

paragraphs.original: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$It is very just. Look, here comes good Sir John.—Give me$NEWLINE$your good hand, give me your Worship’s good hand. By my$NEWLINE$troth, you like well and bear your years very well. Welcome,$NEWLINE$good Sir John.
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$It certainly is. Look, here comes good Sir John. Let me shake your hand; let me shake your hand, sir. I swear, you look good, like you haven’t aged a day. Welcome, good Sir John.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$I am glad to see you well, good Master Robert Shallow.—$NEWLINE$Master Sure-card, as I think?
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$I’m glad to see you’re well, Master Robert Shallow. And this is Master Surecard, isn’t it?

paragraphs.original: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$No, Sir John. It is my cousin Silence, in commission with me.
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$No, Sir John. It’s my cousin Silence. Like me, he’s also a justice of the peace.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Good Master Silence, it well befits you should be of the$NEWLINE$peace.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Master Silence. Your name suits a justice of “the peace.”

paragraphs.original: SILENCE$NEWLINE$Your good Worship is welcome.
paragraphs.translated: SILENCE$NEWLINE$Welcome, sir.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Fie, this is hot weather, gentlemen. Have you provided me$NEWLINE$here half a dozen sufficient men?
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Damn! It’s hot out, gentlemen. Have you found half a dozen able-bodied men for me?

paragraphs.original: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Marry, have we, sir. Will you sit?
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Yes sir, we have. Won’t you sit?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Let me see them, I beseech you.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Let me see them, please.

paragraphs.original: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Where’s the roll? Where’s the roll? Where’s the roll? Let me$NEWLINE$see, let me see, let me see. So, so, so, so, so. So, so. Yea,$NEWLINE$marry, sir.—Rafe Mouldy!—Let them appear as I call, let$NEWLINE$them do so, let them do so. Let me see, where is Mouldy?
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Where’s the list? Where’s the list? Where’s the list? Let’s see, let’s see, let’s see. Right, right. Yes, sir: Ralph Mouldy! Let them come when I call. Let them do that, let them do that. Let’s see. Where’s Mouldy?

paragraphs.original: MOULDY$NEWLINE$Here, an it please you.
paragraphs.translated: MOULDY$NEWLINE$Here, sir.

paragraphs.original: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$What think you, Sir John? A good-limbed fellow; young,$NEWLINE$strong, and of good friends.
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$What do you think, Sir John? He’s got good muscles. Young, strong, and well-connected.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Is thy name Mouldy?
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Are you Mouldy?

paragraphs.original: MOULDY$NEWLINE$Yea, an ’t please you.
paragraphs.translated: MOULDY$NEWLINE$Yes, sir.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$'Tis the more time thou wert used.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Well then, it’s about time you were put to use.

paragraphs.original: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Ha, ha, ha, most excellent, i' faith! Things that are mouldy$NEWLINE$lack use. Very singular good, in faith. Well said, Sir John,$NEWLINE$very well said.
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Ha, ha, ha! Excellent, I swear! Things that don’t get used enough do indeed become moldy. Good one, I swear. Well said, Sir John, very well said.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Prick him.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Prick him.$NEWLINE$Prick$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: MOULDY$NEWLINE$I was pricked well enough before, an you could have let me$NEWLINE$alone. My old dame will be undone now for one to do her$NEWLINE$husbandry and her drudgery. You need not to have pricked$NEWLINE$me. There are other men fitter to go out than I.
paragraphs.translated:
MOULDY$NEWLINE$I’ve already been
pricked well enough, thanks. You could have left me alone. My old lady’s in trouble now: she won’t have anyone to do her husbandry or her housework. You didn’t have to prick me; there are
abler men than me.$NEWLINE$pricked$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$abler men$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Go to. Peace, Mouldy. You shall go. Mouldy, it is time you were$NEWLINE$spent.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$That’s enough; quiet, Mouldy. You’re going. Mouldy, it’s time you were put to use.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: MOULDY$NEWLINE$Spent?
paragraphs.translated: MOLDY$NEWLINE$Put to use?

paragraphs.original: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Peace, fellow, peace. Stand aside. Know you where you$NEWLINE$are?—For th' other, Sir John. Let me see.—Simon Shadow!
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Quiet, man, quiet. Step aside. Don’t you know where you are? Now the next, Sir John. Let’s see. Simon Shadow!

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Yea, marry, let me have him to sit under. He’s like to be a$NEWLINE$cold soldier.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Now you’re talking. I’d like to sit under him. He’ll be a cool soldier.

paragraphs.original: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Where’s Shadow?
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Where’s Shadow?

paragraphs.original: SHADOW$NEWLINE$Here, sir.
paragraphs.translated: SHADOW$NEWLINE$Here, sir.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Shadow, whose son art thou?
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Shadow, whose son are you?

paragraphs.original: SHADOW$NEWLINE$My mother’s son, sir.
paragraphs.translated: SHADOW$NEWLINE$My mother’s son, sir.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Thy mother’s son! Like enough, and thy father’s shadow. So$NEWLINE$the son of the female is the shadow of the male. It is often$NEWLINE$so, indeed, but much of the father’s substance.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Your mother’s son? Probably, and you got your father’s name. The woman’s son is a portrait of the father; yes, that’s usually the case, though the son is little more than a dim copy, without any of the father’s true substance.

paragraphs.original: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Do you like him, Sir John?
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Do you like him, Sir John?

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Shadow will serve for summer. Prick him, for we have a$NEWLINE$number of shadows to fill up the muster book.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Shadow will be useful in the summer. Prick him, too. We’ll need him, for there are a lot of shadows filling up this roster.$NEWLINE$Shadow$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Thomas Wart!
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Thomas Wart!

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Where’s he?
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Where’s he?

paragraphs.original: WART$NEWLINE$Here, sir.
paragraphs.translated: WART$NEWLINE$Here, sir.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Is thy name Wart?
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Is your name Wart?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: WART$NEWLINE$Yea, sir.
paragraphs.translated: WART$NEWLINE$Yup.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Thou art a very ragged wart.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$You’re a pretty ragged wart.

paragraphs.original: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Shall I prick him down, Sir John?
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Should I prick him on the list, Sir John?

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$It were superfluous, for his apparel is built upon his back,$NEWLINE$and the whole frame stands upon pins. Prick him no more.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Not necessary. For look: his clothing is just a bunch of pieces sewn together, and his whole body rests on legs as skinny as pins. He’s been pricked enough by pins and needles—don’t prick him anymore.

paragraphs.original: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Ha, ha, ha. You can do it, sir, you can do it. I commend you$NEWLINE$well.—Francis Feeble!
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Ha, ha, ha! You are funny, sir. You are funny. I’ve got to hand it to you. Francis Feeble!

paragraphs.original: FEEBLE$NEWLINE$Here, sir.
paragraphs.translated: FEEBLE$NEWLINE$Here, sir.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$What trade art thou, Feeble?
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$What kind of work do you do, Feeble?

paragraphs.original: FEEBLE$NEWLINE$A woman’s tailor, sir.
paragraphs.translated: FEEBLE$NEWLINE$I’m a woman’s tailor, sir.

paragraphs.original: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Shall I prick him, sir?
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Should I prick him, sir?

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$You may, but if he had been a man’s tailor, he’d ha' pricked$NEWLINE$you.—Wilt thou make as many holes in an enemy’s battle as$NEWLINE$thou hast done in a woman’s petticoat?
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$You might as well. But if he had been a man’s tailor, he would have already pricked you with his pins. Will you make as many holes in the enemy’s armor as you have in women’s underwear?

paragraphs.original: FEEBLE$NEWLINE$I will do my good will, sir. You can have no more.
paragraphs.translated: FEEBLE$NEWLINE$I’ll do my best, sir. I can’t do any more.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Well said, good woman’s tailor, well said, courageous$NEWLINE$Feeble. Thou wilt be as valiant as the wrathful dove or most$NEWLINE$magnanimous mouse.—Prick the woman’s tailor well,$NEWLINE$Master Shallow, deep, Master Shallow.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Well said, good woman’s tailor! Well said, courageous Feeble! You’ll be as brave as the angriest dove or the most valiant mouse. Prick the woman’s tailor. A big one, Master Shallow; a deep one, Master Shallow.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: FEEBLE$NEWLINE$I would Wart might have gone, sir.
paragraphs.translated: FEEBLE$NEWLINE$I wish Wart were going, sir.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$I would thou wert a man’s tailor, that thou mightst mend him$NEWLINE$and make him fit to go. I cannot put him to a private soldier$NEWLINE$that is the leader of so many thousands. Let that suffice, most$NEWLINE$forcible Feeble.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$And I wish you were a man’s tailor. You could have mended his clothes and made him fit to go. I can’t make him a private soldier when he’s already the leader of thousands—of lice, that is. But never mind, oh forcible Feeble.

paragraphs.original: FEEBLE$NEWLINE$It shall suffice, sir.
paragraphs.translated: FEEBLE$NEWLINE$Never mind, sir.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$I am bound to thee, reverend Feeble.—Who is next?
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$I like you, good Feeble. Who’s next?

paragraphs.original: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Peter Bullcalf o' th' green.
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Peter Bullcalf from the village green!

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Yea, marry, let’s see Bullcalf.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Oh yeah. Let’s see Bullcalf.

paragraphs.original: BULLCALF$NEWLINE$Here, sir.
paragraphs.translated: BULLCALF$NEWLINE$Here, sir!

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Fore God, a likely fellow. Come, prick me Bullcalf till he$NEWLINE$roar again.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$My God! What a great man! Prick Bullcalf until he shouts again.

paragraphs.original: BULLCALF$NEWLINE$O Lord, good my lord captain—
paragraphs.translated: BULLCALF$NEWLINE$Oh Lord! My lord, good Captain—

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$What, dost thou roar before thou art pricked?
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$What, you’re yelling before you’ve even been pricked?

paragraphs.original: BULLCALF$NEWLINE$O Lord, sir, I am a diseased man.
paragraphs.translated: BULLCALF$NEWLINE$Oh Lord, sir! I’m a sick man.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$What disease hast thou?
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$What disease do you have?

paragraphs.original: BULLCALF$NEWLINE$A whoreson cold, sir, a cough, sir, which I caught with$NEWLINE$ringing in the King’s affairs upon his coronation day, sir.
paragraphs.translated: BULLCALF$NEWLINE$A nasty cold, sir. A cough, sir. I caught it when I was ringing the church bells in honor of the King’s coro-nation.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Come, thou shalt go to the wars in a gown. We will have$NEWLINE$away thy cold, and I will take such order that my friends$NEWLINE$shall ring for thee.— (to SHALLOW) Is here all?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Then you’ll go to war in a dressing gown. We’ll get rid of your cold, and I’ll give orders for some of my men to ring the bells for you while you’re away. (to SHALLOW) Is this everybody?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Here is two more called than your number. You must have$NEWLINE$but four here, sir, and so I pray you go in with me to dinner.
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$We’ve got two more here than you need. You can have four, sir. Now, come inside and eat lunch with me.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Come, I will go drink with you, but I cannot tarry dinner. I$NEWLINE$am glad to see you, by my troth, Master Shallow.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$I’ll have a drink with you, but I can’t stay to eat. But I’m truly glad to see you, Master Shallow.

paragraphs.original: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$O, Sir John, do you remember since we lay all night in the$NEWLINE$windmill in Saint George’s Field?
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Oh, Sir John, do you remember the time we spent all night in the windmill in St. George’s field?

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$No more of that, good Master Shallow, no more of that.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Don’t go there, Master Shallow. Don’t go there.

paragraphs.original: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Ha, ’twas a merry night. And is Jane Nightwork alive?
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Ha! That was a fun night. Is Jane Nightwork still alive?

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$She lives, Master Shallow.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$She’s alive, Master Shallow.

paragraphs.original: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$She never could away with me.
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$She never could stand me.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Never, never; she would always say she could not abide$NEWLINE$Master Shallow.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Never, never. She always said she couldn’t stand Master Shallow.

paragraphs.original: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$By the Mass, I could anger her to th' heart. She was then a$NEWLINE$bona roba. Doth she hold her own well?
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Truly, I could anger her to the core. She was a good-looking wench then. Does she still look good?

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Old, old, Master Shallow.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Old, old, Master Shallow.

paragraphs.original: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Nay, she must be old. She cannot choose but be old. Certain,$NEWLINE$she’s old, and had Robin Nightwork by old Nightwork$NEWLINE$before I came to Clement’s Inn.
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Well, she must be old. She’s got no choice but to be old. Of course she’s old. She gave birth to Robin Nightwork, the son of old man Nightwork, before I even got to Clement’s Inn.

paragraphs.original: SILENCE$NEWLINE$That’s fifty-five year ago.
paragraphs.translated: SILENCE$NEWLINE$That’s fifty-five years ago.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Ha, cousin Silence, that thou hadst seen that that this knight$NEWLINE$and I have seen!—Ha, Sir John, said I well?
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Ha, cousin Silence, if only you’d seen what this knight and I have seen! Ha! Am I right, Sir John?

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$We have heard the chimes at midnight, Master Shallow.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$We’ve seen the clock strike midnight, Master Shallow.

paragraphs.original: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$That we have, that we have, that we have. In faith, Sir John,$NEWLINE$we have. Our watchword was “Hem, boys.” Come, let’s to$NEWLINE$dinner; come, let’s to dinner. Jesus, the days that we have$NEWLINE$seen! Come, come.
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$We sure have, we sure have, we sure have. I swear, Sir John, we sure have. Our slogan was “Down the hatch, boys!” Come, let’s have lunch, let’s have lunch. Jesus, the things we’ve seen! Come, come.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt FALSTAFF, SHALLOW, and SILENCE$NEWLINE$FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$SHALLOW$NEWLINE$SILENCE
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF, SHALLOW, and SILENCE exit.$NEWLINE$FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$SHALLOW$NEWLINE$SILENCE

paragraphs.original: BULLCALF$NEWLINE$Good Master Corporate Bardolph, stand my friend, and$NEWLINE$here’s four Harry ten-shillings in French crowns for you. In$NEWLINE$very truth, sir, I had as lief be hanged, sir, as go. And yet, for$NEWLINE$mine own part, sir, I do not care, but rather because I am$NEWLINE$unwilling, and, for mine own part, have a desire to stay with$NEWLINE$my friends. Else, sir, I did not care, for mine own part, so much.
paragraphs.translated:
BULLCALF$NEWLINE$Good Master
Corporate Bardolph, be my friend. Here are some French crowns for you, worth four
Harry ten shillings.$NEWLINE$Corporate$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$Harry ten shillings$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$I’m telling you, sir, I’d just as soon be hanged as go fight. It’s not that I care about my well-being. It’s just that I’m not willing to go, and furthermore, I’d like to stay here with my friends. But really, I don’t care about myself.

paragraphs.original: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Go to. Stand aside.
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Whatever. Stand over there.

paragraphs.original: MOULDY$NEWLINE$And, good Master Corporal Captain, for my old dame’s$NEWLINE$sake, stand my friend. She has nobody to do anything about$NEWLINE$her when I am gone, and she is old and cannot help herself:$NEWLINE$You shall have forty, sir.
paragraphs.translated: MOULDY$NEWLINE$And, good Master Corporal Captain, for my old lady’s sake, be my friend. She has nobody here to help her do anything once I’m gone. She’s old and can’t do much by herself. I’ll give you forty shillings, sir.

paragraphs.original: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Go to. Stand aside.
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Whatever. Stand over there.

paragraphs.original: FEEBLE$NEWLINE$By my troth, I care not. A man can die but once. We owe God$NEWLINE$a death. I’ll ne'er bear a base mind. An ’t be my destiny, so;$NEWLINE$an ’t be not, so. No man’s too good to serve ’s prince, and let$NEWLINE$it go which way it will, he that dies this year is quit for the$NEWLINE$next.
paragraphs.translated: FEEBLE$NEWLINE$I’ll tell you the truth: I don’t care one way or the other. You only die once, and we all owe God a death. I won’t do anything underhanded. If it’s my fate, it’s my fate. If not, not. No man is too good to serve his country. Whatever happens, happens. If you die this year, you’re paid up for next year.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Well said. Th' art a good fellow.
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Well said. You’re a good man.

paragraphs.original: FEEBLE$NEWLINE$Faith, I’ll bear no base mind.
paragraphs.translated: FEEBLE$NEWLINE$I’m telling you. I won’t do anything underhanded.

paragraphs.original: Enter FALSTAFF, SHALLOW, and SILENCE$NEWLINE$FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$SHALLOW$NEWLINE$SILENCE
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF, SHALLOW and SILENCE enter.$NEWLINE$FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$SHALLOW$NEWLINE$SILENCE

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Come, sir, which men shall I have?
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$All right, sir. Which men can I have?

paragraphs.original: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Four of which you please.
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Any four you choose.

paragraphs.original: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Sir, a word with you. (aside to FALSTAFF) I have three pound$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$to free Mouldy and Bullcalf.
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Sir, may I have a word with you? (whispers to FALSTAFF) I’ve gotten three pounds to free Mouldy and Bullcalf.$NEWLINE$(whispers to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Go to, well.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$No kidding. Great.

paragraphs.original: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Come, Sir John, which four will you have?
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Come on, Sir John, which four do you want?

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Do you choose for me.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$You pick.

paragraphs.original: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Marry, then, Mouldy, Bullcalf, Feeble, and Shadow.
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$All right, then. Mouldy, Bullcalf, Feeble, and Shadow.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Mouldy and Bullcalf! For you, Mouldy, stay at home till you$NEWLINE$are past service.—And for your part, Bullcalf, grow till you$NEWLINE$come unto it. I will none of you.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Mouldy and Bullcalf. Mouldy, you stay home till you’re too old to fight. And as for you, Bullcalf, wait till you’ve reached fighting age. I don’t want either of you.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt MOULDY and BULLCALF$NEWLINE$MOULDY$NEWLINE$BULLCALF
paragraphs.translated: MOULDY and BULLCALF exit.$NEWLINE$MOULDY$NEWLINE$BULLCALF

paragraphs.original: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Sir John, Sir John, do not yourself wrong. They are your$NEWLINE$likeliest men, and I would have you served with the best.
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Sir John, Sir John. Don’t make a mistake. They’re the best men of the bunch, and I want you to have only the best.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Will you tell me, Master Shallow, how to choose a man?$NEWLINE$Care I for the limb, the thews, the stature, bulk, and big$NEWLINE$assemblance of a man? Give me the spirit, Master Shallow.$NEWLINE$Here’s Wart. You see what a ragged appearance it is. He shall
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Master Shallow, are you going to tell me how to choose a soldier? Do you think I care about a man’s body,

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: charge you and discharge you with the motion of a$NEWLINE$pewterer’s hammer, come off and on swifter than he that$NEWLINE$gibbets on the brewer’s bucket. And this same half-faced$NEWLINE$fellow, Shadow, give me this man. He presents no mark to$NEWLINE$the enemy. The foeman may with as great aim level at the$NEWLINE$edge of a penknife. And for a retreat, how swiftly will this$NEWLINE$Feeble the woman’s tailor, run off! O, give me the spare$NEWLINE$men, and spare me the great ones.—Put me a caliver into$NEWLINE$Wart’s hand, Bardolph.
paragraphs.translated: strength, height, bulk, and overall size? Give me his spirit, Master Shallow! Take a look at Wart. You see how ragged he looks? He can load and fire steadily—as steadily as a tinsmith’s hammer. He can advance and regroup fast—faster than a brewer’s delivery pail can be refilled. And this skinny guy, Shadow—give me this man. He offers no target to the enemy. The enemy might as well try aiming at a knife’s edge. And as for retreating, Feeble, the woman’s tailor, will run faster than you can imagine. Oh, give me the spare men and spare me the great ones! Bardolph, give Wart a musket.

paragraphs.original: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Hold, Wart. Traverse. Thas, thas, thas.
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Here you go, Wart. Present arms! Right shoulder, arms! Left shoulder, arms!

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Come, manage me your caliver: so, very well, go to, very$NEWLINE$good, exceeding good. O, give me always a little, lean, old,$NEWLINE$chopped, bald shot. Well said, i' faith, Wart. Th' art a good$NEWLINE$scab. Hold, there’s a tester for thee.
paragraphs.translated:
FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Come on, handle your weapon. Yes, good. Very good. Very, very good. Oh, give me a little, skinny, old, dried-out, bald rifleman any day. Good job, Wart. You’re a good scab of a guy. Wait, here’s a
tester for you.$NEWLINE$tester$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$He is not his craft’s master. He doth not do it right. I$NEWLINE$remember at Mile End Green, when I lay at Clement’s Inn—$NEWLINE$I was then Sir Dagonet in Arthur’s show—there was a little$NEWLINE$quiver fellow, and he would manage you his piece thus. And$NEWLINE$he would about and about, and come you in, and come you$NEWLINE$in. “Rah, tah, tah,” would he say. “Bounce,” would he say,$NEWLINE$and away again would he go, and again would he come. I$NEWLINE$shall ne'er see such a fellow.
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$He’s no expert. He’s not doing it right. I remember up at Mile-End Park, when I was at Clement’s Inn—I played the fool in the archery pageant. There was a nimble little guy, and he would handle his weapon like this, and he would run all over the place, and he’d charge and charge. “Rat-a-tat tat,” he’d say. “Bang!” he’d say. Then he’d run away, then come back. I never saw anybody like him.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$These fellows will do well, Master Shallow.—God keep$NEWLINE$you, Master Silence. I will not use many words with you.$NEWLINE$Fare you well, gentlemen both. I thank you. I must a dozen$NEWLINE$mile to-night.—Bardolph, give the soldiers coats.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$These guys will be fine, Master Shallow. God bless you, Master Silence—I won’t say much to you. Farewell, gentlemen, and thank you. I have to march twelve miles tonight. Bardolph, give the soldiers uniforms.

paragraphs.original: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Sir John, the Lord bless you. God prosper your affairs. God$NEWLINE$send us peace. At your return, visit our house. Let our old
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$God bless you, Sir John. May God bring you good luck, and bring us peace. When you come back, pay us

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: acquaintance be renewed. Peradventure I will with you to$NEWLINE$the court.
paragraphs.translated: a visit. Let’s renew our old friendship. Maybe I’ll even come with you to the royal court!

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Fore God, would you would, Master Shallow.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$I swear, I wish you would, Master Shallow.

paragraphs.original: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Go to. I have spoke at a word. God keep you.
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$I meant what I said. May God keep you.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Fare you well, gentle gentlemen.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Farewell, gentle gentlemen.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt SHALLOW and SILENCE$NEWLINE$SHALLOW$NEWLINE$SILENCE
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW and SILENCE exit.$NEWLINE$SHALLOW$NEWLINE$SILENCE

paragraphs.original: On, Bardolph. Lead the men away.
paragraphs.translated: March, Bardolph. Lead the men away.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt BARDOLPH and the recruits$NEWLINE$BARDOLPH
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH and the recruits exit.$NEWLINE$BARDOLPH

paragraphs.original: As I return, I will fetch off these justices. I do see the bottom$NEWLINE$of Justice Shallow. Lord, Lord, how subject we old men are$NEWLINE$to this vice of lying. This same starved justice hath done$NEWLINE$nothing but prate to me of the wildness of his youth and the$NEWLINE$feats he hath done about Turnbull Street, and every third$NEWLINE$word a lie, duer paid to the hearer than the Turk’s tribute. I$NEWLINE$do remember him at Clement’s Inn, like a man made after$NEWLINE$supper of a cheese paring. When he was naked, he was, for$NEWLINE$all the world, like a forked radish with a head fantastically$NEWLINE$carved upon it with a knife. He was so forlorn that his$NEWLINE$dimensions to any thick sight were invincible. He was the$NEWLINE$very genius of famine, yet lecherous as a monkey, and the$NEWLINE$whores called him “mandrake.” He came ever in the$NEWLINE$rearward of the fashion, and sung those tunes to the$NEWLINE$overscutched huswives that he heard the carmen whistle,$NEWLINE$and swore they were his fancies or his good-nights.$NEWLINE$And now is this Vice’s dagger become a squire, and talks as$NEWLINE$familiarly of John o' Gaunt as if he had been sworn brother$NEWLINE$to him, and I’ll be sworn he ne'er saw him but once in the
paragraphs.translated:
When I come back, I’ll expose these judges for the frauds that they are. I can see through this Judge Shallow. Lord, Lord; we old men sure know how to tell lies! This dried-up old judge has done nothing but go on and on to me about how wild he was when he was as a youth, and how many stunts he pulled in the seedy parts of town. Every third word he speaks is a lie, and he’ll tell lies quicker than a Turk will scramble to pay the sultan. I remember him at Clement’s Inn: he looked like a man someone carved after dinner out of a scrap of cheese. When he was naked he looked like a
mandrake root, with a fanciful head someone had carved in with a knife. He was so skinny that he was invisible to any man with imperfect vision; he truly was the embodiment of starvation. But he was as horny as a monkey: the whores called him “mandrake,” because mandrake stimulates the sex drive. He was always a little bit behind the times. He would hear the wagon drivers sing their songs, and then he’d go to his worn-out whores and sing them what he’d heard, pretending he had written them himself. And now this vile stick has become a landowner, and he talks about John of Gaunt like he was his own brother. I swear, he only saw Gaunt$NEWLINE$mandrake root$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: tilt-yard, and then he burst his head for crowding among the$NEWLINE$Marshal’s men. I saw it and told John o' Gaunt he beat his$NEWLINE$own name, for you might have thrust him and all his apparel$NEWLINE$into an eel-skin; the case of a treble hautboy was a mansion$NEWLINE$for him, a court. And now has he land and beefs. Well, I’ll$NEWLINE$be acquainted with him, if I return, and ’t shall go hard but$NEWLINE$I’ll make him a philosopher’s two stones to me. If the young$NEWLINE$dace be a bait for the old pike, I see no reason in the law of$NEWLINE$nature but I may snap at him. Let time shape, and there an$NEWLINE$end.
paragraphs.translated: once, and that was in the arena at the jousting tournament; John of Gaunt cut Shallow’s head with his sword. I saw it all, and I told John of Gaunt that he had beaten his own name, since Shallow was such a gaunt man back then. You could fit him and all his clothes into the skin an eel sheds. An instrument case was as huge as a mansion to him, as big as a courtroom. Now he has land and livestock. Well, I’ll be his friend if I come back. He won’t like it, but I’ll turn him into an unending source of wealth for myself. If small fish can be bait for big fish, I see no reason why I can’t snap my jaws at Shallow. Time will tell, and that’s all I have to say about that.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter the ARCHBISHOP of York, MOWBRAY, HASTINGS, and others$NEWLINE$ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$MOWBRAY$NEWLINE$HASTINGS
paragraphs.translated: ARCHBISHOP of York, MOWBRAY, HASTINGS, and others enter.$NEWLINE$ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$MOWBRAY$NEWLINE$HASTINGS

paragraphs.original: ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$What is this forest called?
paragraphs.translated: ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$What’s the name of this forest?

paragraphs.original: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$'Tis Gaultree Forest, an ’t shall please your Grace.
paragraphs.translated: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$Gaultree Forest, your grace.

paragraphs.original: ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$Here stand, my lords, and send discoverers forth$NEWLINE$To know the numbers of our enemies.
paragraphs.translated: ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$Stop here, sirs. Send out scouts to find out how many soldiers our enemy has.

paragraphs.original: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$We have sent forth already.
paragraphs.translated: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$We’ve already done that.

paragraphs.original: ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$'Tis well done.$NEWLINE$My friends and brethren in these great affairs,$NEWLINE$I must acquaint you that I have received$NEWLINE$New-dated letters from Northumberland,$NEWLINE$Their cold intent, tenor, and substance, thus:$NEWLINE$Here doth he wish his person, with such powers$NEWLINE$As might hold sortance with his quality,$NEWLINE$The which he could not levy; whereupon$NEWLINE$He is retired, to ripe his growing fortunes,$NEWLINE$To Scotland, and concludes in hearty prayers$NEWLINE$That your attempts may overlive the hazard$NEWLINE$And fearful melting of their opposite.
paragraphs.translated: ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$Well done. My friends and brothers in this great undertaking, I have to share with you that I’ve received new letters from Northumberland. They have a chilling purpose, tone, and content. He says that he wishes he could be here in person, with an army as strong someone of his rank should have, but he couldn’t raise one. So he’s going to go to Scotland to increase his power. He prays that your armies will prevail against the terrible power of the enemy.

paragraphs.original: MOWBRAY$NEWLINE$Thus do the hopes we have in him touch ground$NEWLINE$And dash themselves to pieces.
paragraphs.translated: MOWBRAY$NEWLINE$And with that, any hope we had for him is thrown to the ground and dashed to pieces.

paragraphs.original: Enter a MESSENGER$NEWLINE$MESSENGER
paragraphs.translated: A MESSENGER enters.$NEWLINE$MESSENGER

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$Now, what news?
paragraphs.translated: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$What’s happening?
