paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$West of this forest, scarcely off a mile,$NEWLINE$In goodly form comes on the enemy,$NEWLINE$And, by the ground they hide, I judge their number$NEWLINE$Upon or near the rate of thirty thousand.
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$The enemy is west of this forest, and less than a mile away. They look powerful, and, from the amount of space they’re taking up, I’d say they have close to thirty thousand soldiers.

paragraphs.original: MOWBRAY$NEWLINE$The just proportion that we gave them out.$NEWLINE$Let us sway on and face them in the field.
paragraphs.translated: MOWBRAY$NEWLINE$That’s exactly the number we thought they had. Let’s march ahead and engage them in battle.

paragraphs.original: Enter WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$WESTMORELAND
paragraphs.translated: WESTMORELAND enters.$NEWLINE$WESTMORELAND

paragraphs.original: ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$What well-appointed leader fronts us here?
paragraphs.translated: ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$Who’s this well-equipped leader coming here to confront us?

paragraphs.original: MOWBRAY$NEWLINE$I think it is my Lord of Westmoreland.
paragraphs.translated: MOWBRAY$NEWLINE$I think it’s Lord Westmoreland.

paragraphs.original: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$Health and fair greeting from our general,$NEWLINE$The Prince Lord John and Duke of Lancaster.
paragraphs.translated: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$Our general, the Prince Lord John of Lancaster, sends greetings and wishes you good health.

paragraphs.original: ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$Say on, my Lord of Westmoreland, in peace,$NEWLINE$What doth concern your coming.
paragraphs.translated: ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$Speak in peace, Lord Westmoreland. What’s the reason you’ve come here?

paragraphs.original: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$Then, my lord,$NEWLINE$Unto your Grace do I in chief address$NEWLINE$The substance of my speech. If that rebellion$NEWLINE$Came like itself, in base and abject routs,$NEWLINE$Led on by bloody youth, guarded with rage,$NEWLINE$And countenanced by boys and beggary—$NEWLINE$I say, if damn’d commotion so appeared$NEWLINE$In his true, native, and most proper shape,$NEWLINE$You, reverend father, and these noble lords$NEWLINE$Had not been here to dress the ugly form$NEWLINE$Of base and bloody insurrection
paragraphs.translated: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$The most important part of my message is for you, your grace. You, who are a holy man, and these good gentlemen as well—you would not be here, lending dignity to this bloody insurrection, if it appeared as rebellion normally does: like a lowborn mob, led by bloody youths uniformed in rags, and supported by boys and beggars.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: With your fair honors. You, Lord Archbishop,$NEWLINE$Whose see is by a civil peace maintained,$NEWLINE$Whose beard the silver hand of peace hath touched,$NEWLINE$Whose learning and good letters peace hath tutored,$NEWLINE$Whose white investments figure innocence,$NEWLINE$The dove and very blessèd spirit of peace,$NEWLINE$Wherefore do you so ill translate yourself$NEWLINE$Out of the speech of peace, that bears such grace,$NEWLINE$Into the harsh and boist'rous tongue of war,$NEWLINE$Turning your books to graves, your ink to blood,$NEWLINE$Your pens to lances, and your tongue divine$NEWLINE$To a trumpet and a point of war?
paragraphs.translated: You, Lord Archbishop—whose diocese is peaceful and law-abiding; whose beard has turned white, signifying a peaceful life; whose education and learning are the products of peaceful times; who is the dove and very blessed embodiment of peace—why are you translating yourself from the graceful language of peace into the harsh, violent language of war? You’re turning your books into coffins, your ink into blood, your pens into swords, and your holy words into a trumpet that sounds a call to arms.

paragraphs.original: ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$Wherefore do I this? So the question stands.$NEWLINE$Briefly, to this end: we are all diseased,$NEWLINE$And with our surfeiting and wanton hours$NEWLINE$Have brought ourselves into a burning fever,$NEWLINE$And we must bleed for it; of which disease$NEWLINE$Our late King Richard, being infected, died.$NEWLINE$But, my most noble Lord of Westmoreland,$NEWLINE$I take not on me here as a physician,$NEWLINE$Nor do I as an enemy to peace$NEWLINE$Troop in the throngs of military men,$NEWLINE$But rather show awhile like fearful war$NEWLINE$To diet rank minds sick of happiness$NEWLINE$And purge th' obstructions which begin to stop$NEWLINE$Our very veins of life. Hear me more plainly.$NEWLINE$I have in equal balance justly weighed$NEWLINE$What wrongs our arms may do, what wrongs we suffer,$NEWLINE$And find our griefs heavier than our offenses.$NEWLINE$We see which way the stream of time doth run$NEWLINE$And are enforced from our most quiet there$NEWLINE$By the rough torrent of occasion,$NEWLINE$And have the summary of all our griefs,$NEWLINE$When time shall serve, to show in articles;$NEWLINE$Which long ere this we offered to the King
paragraphs.translated: ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$Why am I doing this? That is the question. The short answer is this: we’re all sick. We’ve eaten and drunk too much and stayed up all night, and now we have a burning fever whose only cure is bloodletting. Richard, our late King, was infected with this disease and died from it. But, my good Lord Westmoreland, I’m not here as a physician, nor am I marching with this army as an enemy of peace. What I’m doing is making a frightening show of war, to stop people from indulging all their vices. This will clear the hardening of the arteries which threatens to kill us all. Let me speak more plainly. I’ve carefully considered the options, weighing the harm our armies are likely to cause against the harm we’re already suffering, and I find that our grievances are stronger than our offenses. We can see where things are headed, and the rough times ahead leave us with no choice but to step away from our quiet lives. We have a list of grievances which we can publish at the appropriate time. We offered that list to the King a long time ago, but we could never get an audience with him.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: And might by no suit gain our audience.$NEWLINE$When we are wronged and would unfold our griefs,$NEWLINE$We are denied access unto his person$NEWLINE$Even by those men that most have done us wrong.$NEWLINE$The dangers of the days but newly gone,$NEWLINE$Whose memory is written on the earth$NEWLINE$With yet appearing blood, and the examples$NEWLINE$Of every minute’s instance, present now,$NEWLINE$Hath put us in these ill-beseeming arms,$NEWLINE$Not to break peace or any branch of it,$NEWLINE$But to establish here a peace indeed,$NEWLINE$Concurring both in name and quality.
paragraphs.translated: We were wronged, and when we tried to speak to the King about it, we were denied access to him by the very men who had wronged us most. We’re in this seemingly unbefitting armor because of the terrible recent violence—the bloodshed from which is still visible on the ground—and because of the terrible things happening now, every minute. We don’t want to harm peace in any way. We want instead to establish a peace that’s real and meaningful.

paragraphs.original: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$When ever yet was your appeal denied?$NEWLINE$Wherein have you been gallèd by the King?$NEWLINE$What peer hath been suborned to grate on you,$NEWLINE$That you should seal this lawless bloody book$NEWLINE$Of forged rebellion with a seal divine$NEWLINE$And consecrate commotion’s bitter edge?
paragraphs.translated: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$When was your request to see the King denied? How has the king harmed you? What lord in the King’s court has been sent out to do you wrong? And why would you put your holy stamp of approval on an illegal uprising and give religious blessing to a violent civil war?

paragraphs.original: ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$My brother general, the commonwealth,$NEWLINE$To brother born an household cruelty,$NEWLINE$I make my quarrel in particular.
paragraphs.translated:
ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$The
grievances borne by my fellow Englishmen, and the cruel murder of Scroop, my own brother: these are the reasons I’ve made this fight my own.$NEWLINE$grievances$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$There is no need of any such redress,$NEWLINE$Or if there were, it not belongs to you.
paragraphs.translated: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$There’s no need for any repayment like that; and even if there were, you should not be the person to benefit.

paragraphs.original: MOWBRAY$NEWLINE$Why not to him in part, and to us all$NEWLINE$That feel the bruises of the days before$NEWLINE$And suffer the condition of these times$NEWLINE$To lay a heavy and unequal hand$NEWLINE$Upon our honors?
paragraphs.translated: MOWBRAY$NEWLINE$Why shouldn’t he benefit at least a little? Why shouldn’t we all benefit, who suffered in these recent battles, and who have allowed our honor to be damaged by the terrible things happening now?

paragraphs.original: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$O, my good Lord Mowbray,$NEWLINE$Construe the times to their necessities,
paragraphs.translated: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$Oh, my good Lord Mowbray, if you think about what is necessary in times of war, you’ll see that it is the situation

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: And you shall say indeed it is the time,$NEWLINE$And not the King, that doth you injuries.$NEWLINE$Yet for your part, it not appears to me$NEWLINE$Either from the King or in the present time$NEWLINE$That you should have an inch of any ground$NEWLINE$To build a grief on. Were you not restored$NEWLINE$To all the Duke of Norfolk’s seigniories,$NEWLINE$Your noble and right well remembered father’s?
paragraphs.translated: that harms you, and not the King himself. But as for you in particular, it seems to me that you have no foundation on which to build a quarrel with either the King or your current situation. Wasn’t the entire estate of the Duke of Norfolk, your father, just given back to you?

paragraphs.original: MOWBRAY$NEWLINE$What thing, in honor, had my father lost,$NEWLINE$That need to be revived and breathed in me?$NEWLINE$The King that loved him, as the state stood then,$NEWLINE$Was force perforce compelled to banish him,$NEWLINE$And then that Harry Bolingbroke and he,$NEWLINE$Being mounted and both rousèd in their seats,$NEWLINE$Their neighing coursers daring of the spur,$NEWLINE$Their armèd staves in charge, their beavers down,$NEWLINE$Their eyes of fire sparking through sights of steel$NEWLINE$And the loud trumpet blowing them together,$NEWLINE$Then, then, when there was nothing could have stayed$NEWLINE$My father from the breast of Bolingbroke,$NEWLINE$O, when the King did throw his warder down—$NEWLINE$His own life hung upon the staff he threw—$NEWLINE$Then threw he down himself and all their lives$NEWLINE$That by indictment and by dint of sword$NEWLINE$Have since miscarried under Bolingbroke.
paragraphs.translated:
MOWBRAY$NEWLINE$What did my father lose that I now need to restore? Richard, the King at the time, loved my father, but given what was happening he had no choice but to banish him. And then, at Coventry, my father and Harry Bolingbroke met in a formal
challenge. They were both mounted on their horses and ready to charge. Their horses were neighing, anxiously waiting for their riders' spurs to drive them forward. Their steel-tipped lances were ready for the attack. The visors of their helmets were down. Their eyes were on fire behind the steel slits. The trumpet sounded, and then—when there was nothing that could have stopped my father from killing Bolingbroke—the King prevented the fight by throwing down his royal scepter. That scepter was a symbol of his life; when he threw it down, he threw down his life and the lives of every man that has since died at war under the leadership of Bolingbroke.$NEWLINE$challenge$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$You speak, Lord Mowbray, now you know not what.$NEWLINE$The Earl of Hereford was reputed then$NEWLINE$In England the most valiant gentleman.$NEWLINE$Who knows on whom fortune would then have smiled?$NEWLINE$But if your father had been victor there,$NEWLINE$He ne'er had borne it out of Coventry;$NEWLINE$For all the country in a general voice$NEWLINE$Cried hate upon him; and all their prayers and love
paragraphs.translated: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$You don’t know what you’re talking about, Lord Mowbray. Bolingbroke at the time was considered the bravest gentleman in England. Who knows who would have won that fight? But even if your father had won, he never would have made it out of Coventry. The whole country hated him, and they loved and prayed for Bolingbroke.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Were set on Hereford, whom they doted on$NEWLINE$And blessed and graced, indeed more than the King.$NEWLINE$But this is mere digression from my purpose.$NEWLINE$Here come I from our princely general$NEWLINE$To know your griefs, to tell you from his Grace$NEWLINE$That he will give you audience; and wherein$NEWLINE$It shall appear that your demands are just,$NEWLINE$You shall enjoy them, everything set off$NEWLINE$That might so much as think you enemies.
paragraphs.translated: They blessed him and adored him even more than the King. But I digress. I was sent here by our general, the Prince, to hear your grievances, and to tell you that he’s prepared to listen to you. If it appears that your demands are legitimate, he’ll give you what you want—except for those things which might suggest that you’re his enemies.

paragraphs.original: MOWBRAY$NEWLINE$But he hath forced us to compel this offer;$NEWLINE$And it proceeds from policy, not love.
paragraphs.translated: MOWBRAY$NEWLINE$But he’s made us force him to listen to us. His offer isn’t motivated by love; it’s a political move.

paragraphs.original: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$Mowbray, you overween to take it so.$NEWLINE$This offer comes from mercy, not from fear.$NEWLINE$For, lo, within a ken our army lies,$NEWLINE$Upon mine honor, all too confident$NEWLINE$To give admittance to a thought of fear.$NEWLINE$Our battle is more full of names than yours,$NEWLINE$Our men more perfect in the use of arms,$NEWLINE$Our armor all as strong, our cause the best.$NEWLINE$Then reason will our hearts should be as good.$NEWLINE$Say you not then our offer is compelled.
paragraphs.translated: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$Mowbray, you’re out of line to think that. His offer is made out of mercy, not fear. Just look, you can see our army from here. I give you my word of honor: that army is so confident, it won’t even allow the thought of fear to enter. Our army has more important people than yours, and better soldiers; our armor is every bit as strong as yours, and our cause is better. It’s only logical that we should be as courageous as you are. So don’t say you’ve forced the Prince to do anything at all.

paragraphs.original: MOWBRAY$NEWLINE$Well, by my will, we shall admit no parley.
paragraphs.translated: MOWBRAY$NEWLINE$Well, I say we won’t agree to any conference.

paragraphs.original: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$That argues but the shame of your offense.$NEWLINE$A rotten case abides no handling.
paragraphs.translated: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$That just proves that what you’re doing here is shameful. A rotten container falls apart at the touch; likewise, a rotten cause cannot withstand scrutiny and argument.

paragraphs.original: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$Hath the Prince John a full commission,$NEWLINE$In very ample virtue of his father,$NEWLINE$To hear and absolutely to determine$NEWLINE$Of what conditions we shall stand upon?
paragraphs.translated: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$Has the King given Prince John his full authorization to listen to our complaint, and address it in any way the Prince sees fit?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$That is intended in the General’s name.$NEWLINE$I muse you make so slight a question.
paragraphs.translated: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$That goes without saying. I’m amazed you’d even ask such a foolish question.

paragraphs.original: ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$Then take, my Lord of Westmoreland, this schedule,$NEWLINE$For this contains our general grievances.$NEWLINE$Each several article herein redressed,$NEWLINE$All members of our cause, both here and hence,$NEWLINE$That are insinewed to this action,$NEWLINE$Acquitted by a true substantial form$NEWLINE$And present execution of our wills$NEWLINE$To us and to our purposes confined,$NEWLINE$We come within our awful banks again$NEWLINE$And knit our powers to the arm of peace.
paragraphs.translated: ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$Then, Lord Westmoreland, take this document. It lists our grievances. If each complaint listed here is addressed, and if everyone on our side, both here and elsewhere, is granted a full pardon and immediate satisfaction of our demands, then we’ll return to our own boundaries again and work together for the cause of peace.

paragraphs.original: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$This will I show the General. Please you, lords,$NEWLINE$In sight of both our battles we may meet,$NEWLINE$And either end in peace, which God so frame,$NEWLINE$Or to the place of difference call the swords$NEWLINE$Which must decide it.
paragraphs.translated: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$I’ll show this to the general. Please, let’s meet at a place where both our armies can see us. Then either let our talks end in peace—God willing!—or let us take the fight to the battlefield where it will be decided.

paragraphs.original: ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$My lord, we will do so.
paragraphs.translated: ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$My lord, we will do so.

paragraphs.original: Exit WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$WESTMORELAND
paragraphs.translated: WESTMORELAND exits.$NEWLINE$WESTMORELAND

paragraphs.original: MOWBRAY$NEWLINE$There is a thing within my bosom tells me$NEWLINE$That no conditions of our peace can stand.
paragraphs.translated: MOWBRAY$NEWLINE$Something in my heart tells me that no peace we agree to could possibly last.

paragraphs.original: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$Fear you not that. If we can make our peace$NEWLINE$Upon such large terms and so absolute$NEWLINE$As our conditions shall consist upon,$NEWLINE$Our peace shall stand as firm as rocky mountains.
paragraphs.translated: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$Don’t worry about that. If we can come to terms that are as comprehensive as the ones we’re insisting upon, then the peace will be as durable as rocky mountains.

paragraphs.original: MOWBRAY$NEWLINE$Yea, but our valuation shall be such$NEWLINE$That every slight and false-derivèd cause,$NEWLINE$Yea, every idle, nice, and wanton reason,$NEWLINE$Shall to the King taste of this action,
paragraphs.translated: MOWBRAY$NEWLINE$Yes, but in the future the King will think so poorly of us that every little slight, every false accusation, every tiny, silly, frivolous thing will seem to him to be a revival of this rebellion. Even if we were as devoted to the King as martyrs are to their causes, he’ll regard us so skeptically that even the good things we do for him

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: That, were our royal faiths martyrs in love,$NEWLINE$We shall be winnowed with so rough a wind$NEWLINE$That even our corn shall seem as light as chaff$NEWLINE$And good from bad find no partition.
paragraphs.translated: won’t count; he won’t be able to distinguish them from the bad.

paragraphs.original: ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$No, no, my lord. Note this: the King is weary$NEWLINE$Of dainty and such picking grievances,$NEWLINE$For he hath found to end one doubt by death$NEWLINE$Revives two greater in the heirs of life;$NEWLINE$And therefore will he wipe his tables clean$NEWLINE$And keep no telltale to his memory$NEWLINE$That may repeat and history his loss$NEWLINE$To new remembrance. For full well he knows$NEWLINE$He cannot so precisely weed this land$NEWLINE$As his misdoubts present occasion;$NEWLINE$His foes are so enrooted with his friends$NEWLINE$That, plucking to unfix an enemy,$NEWLINE$He doth unfasten so and shake a friend;$NEWLINE$So that this land, like an offensive wife$NEWLINE$That hath enraged him on to offer strokes,$NEWLINE$As he is striking holds his infant up$NEWLINE$And hangs resolved correction in the arm$NEWLINE$That was upreared to execution.
paragraphs.translated: ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$No, no, sir. Listen, the king is tired of getting upset over every little thing. He’s discovered that ending one problem by killing someone only creates two bigger problems in the people left alive. So from now on, he’ll wipe his memory clean, and forget anything that might remind him of the bad things from his past. He knows that he can’t just eliminate every single opponent who crops up.$NEWLINE$His enemies are rooted in with his friends, to the extent that, if he tries to pull up an enemy, he’ll also uproot and discard a friend. This country’s like a misbehaving wife, who, just when her husband is about to hit her, holds his baby up, and freezes the intended punishment in the very arm that was poised to apply it.

paragraphs.original: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$Besides, the King hath wasted all his rods$NEWLINE$On late offenders, that he now doth lack$NEWLINE$The very instruments of chastisement,$NEWLINE$So that his power, like to a fangless lion,$NEWLINE$May offer but not hold.
paragraphs.translated: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$Besides, the King has expended all his energy for punishment on the recent rebellion. He has nothing left to punish with. His power is like a lion with no teeth: it can threaten, but it can’t do any harm.

paragraphs.original: ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$'Tis very true,$NEWLINE$And therefore be assured, my good Lord Marshal,$NEWLINE$If we do now make our atonement well,$NEWLINE$Our peace will, like a broken limb united,$NEWLINE$Grow stronger for the breaking.
paragraphs.translated: ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$That’s true. Rest assured, my good Lord Marshal, if our reconciliation is sincere, then peace will be like a broken bone, which grows stronger for having once been broken.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: MOWBRAY$NEWLINE$Be it so.$NEWLINE$Here is returned my Lord of Westmoreland.
paragraphs.translated: MOWBRAY$NEWLINE$I hope so. Lord Westmoreland is back.

paragraphs.original: Enter WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$WESTMORELAND
paragraphs.translated: WESTMORELAND enters.$NEWLINE$WESTMORELAND

paragraphs.original: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$The Prince is here at hand. Pleaseth your lordship$NEWLINE$To meet his Grace just distance ’tween our armies.
paragraphs.translated: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$The Prince is nearby. If you will, please meet him at a spot halfway between our two armies.

paragraphs.original: MOWBRAY$NEWLINE$Your Grace of York, in God’s name then set forward.
paragraphs.translated: MOWBRAY$NEWLINE$Your grace, Archbishop of York, go forward in God’s name.

paragraphs.original: ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$Before, and greet his Grace.—(to WESTMORELAND) My lord,$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$we come.
paragraphs.translated: ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$Lead on, and greet his highness. (to WESTMORELAND) Sir, we’re on our way.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: The ARCHBISHOP, MOWBRAY, YORK, HASTINGS and the others go forward$NEWLINE$ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$MOWBRAY$NEWLINE$YORK$NEWLINE$HASTINGS
paragraphs.translated: The ARCHBISHOP, MOWBRAY, YORK, HASTINGS, and the others cross the stage.$NEWLINE$ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$MOWBRAY$NEWLINE$YORK$NEWLINE$HASTINGS

paragraphs.original: Enter Prince John of LANCASTER and officers with him$NEWLINE$LANCASTER
paragraphs.translated: Prince John of LANCASTER enters, with officers.$NEWLINE$LANCASTER

paragraphs.original: LANCASTER$NEWLINE$You are well encountered here, my cousin Mowbray.—$NEWLINE$Good day to you, gentle Lord Archbishop,—$NEWLINE$And so to you, Lord Hastings, and to all.—$NEWLINE$My Lord of York, it better showed with you$NEWLINE$When that your flock, assembled by the bell,$NEWLINE$Encircled you to hear with reverence$NEWLINE$Your exposition on the holy text$NEWLINE$Than now to see you here, an iron man talking,$NEWLINE$Cheering a rout of rebels with your drum,$NEWLINE$Turning the word to sword, and life to death.$NEWLINE$That man that sits within a monarch’s heart$NEWLINE$And ripens in the sunshine of his favor,$NEWLINE$Would he abuse the countenance of the King,$NEWLINE$Alack, what mischiefs might he set abroach$NEWLINE$In shadow of such greatness! With you, Lord Bishop,
paragraphs.translated: LANCASTER$NEWLINE$I’m glad to see you, my cousin Mowbray. Good day to you, gentle Archbishop, and to you, Lord Hastings, and to all. Lord Archbishop, it was better to see you when worshippers—called together by the church bell—surrounded you to hear Biblical sermons than it is to see you here, in armor; cheering a mob of rebels with your war drums, turning your words to weapons, and your life into death.$NEWLINE$When a man is close to the King’s heart, and grows strong under the King’s protection, only to turn against him—alas! What evils that man will unleash, hidden from view by the King’s own reputation! This is exactly how it is with you, Lord Bishop.$NEWLINE$Who hasn’t heard how profound your religious knowledge is? To us, you were our representative in God’s own parliament. To us, you might as well have been

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: It is even so. Who hath not heard it spoken$NEWLINE$How deep you were within the books of God,$NEWLINE$To us the speaker in His parliament,$NEWLINE$To us th' imagined voice of God himself,$NEWLINE$The very opener and intelligencer$NEWLINE$Between the grace, the sanctities, of heaven,$NEWLINE$And our dull workings? O, who shall believe$NEWLINE$But you misuse the reverence of your place,$NEWLINE$Employ the countenance and grace of heaven$NEWLINE$As a false favorite doth his prince’s name,$NEWLINE$In deeds dishonorable? You have ta'en up,$NEWLINE$Under the counterfeited zeal of God,$NEWLINE$The subjects of His substitute, my father,$NEWLINE$And both against the peace of heaven and him$NEWLINE$Have here up-swarmed them.
paragraphs.translated: God’s own voice: the interpreter and ambassador between God’s heavenly ways and our own dull, mortal actions. And now, who would say anything but that you are abusing the holiness of your position, using the outward show of godliness to do terrible things, like a treacherous courtier uses the King’s good name? You have pretended to be acting in God’s name as you encourage the subjects of God’s deputy, my father, to rise up against the peace of both heaven and the King.

paragraphs.original: ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$Good my Lord of Lancaster,$NEWLINE$I am not here against your father’s peace,$NEWLINE$But, as I told my Lord of Westmoreland,$NEWLINE$The time misordered doth, in common sense,$NEWLINE$Crowd us and crush us to this monstrous form$NEWLINE$To hold our safety up. I sent your Grace$NEWLINE$The parcels and particulars of our grief,$NEWLINE$The which hath been with scorn shoved from the court,$NEWLINE$Whereon this Hydra son of war is born,$NEWLINE$Whose dangerous eyes may well be charmed asleep$NEWLINE$With grant of our most just and right desires,$NEWLINE$And true obedience, of this madness cured,$NEWLINE$Stoop tamely to the foot of majesty.
paragraphs.translated:
ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$Good Lord of Lancaster, I am not here as an enemy your father’s peace. But, as I told Westmoreland, these tumultuous times have forced us to behave in these monstrous ways, out of common sense and a regard for our own safety. I sent you a detailed list of our grievances, but you angrily shoved it aside. That’s why this
Hydra of a war has broken out. You can get rid of it by agreeing to the just and right things we demand. If you do that, this disease of war will be cured, and the monster will bow at your feet, tame and obedient.$NEWLINE$Hydra of a war$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: MOWBRAY$NEWLINE$If not, we ready are to try our fortunes$NEWLINE$To the last man.
paragraphs.translated: MOWBRAY$NEWLINE$If you don’t, we’re ready to fight to the last man.

paragraphs.original: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$And though we here fall down,$NEWLINE$We have supplies to second our attempt;$NEWLINE$If they miscarry, theirs shall second them,
paragraphs.translated: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$And if those of us who are here should fail, we have reinforcements standing by. If they fail, they have reinforcements to back them up,

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: And so success of mischief shall be born,$NEWLINE$And heir from heir shall hold this quarrel up$NEWLINE$Whiles England shall have generation.
paragraphs.translated: and in this way the fight will go on from father to son for all time until England itself has no more new generations.

paragraphs.original: LANCASTER$NEWLINE$You are too shallow, Hastings, much too shallow$NEWLINE$To sound the bottom of the after-times.
paragraphs.translated: LANCASTER$NEWLINE$You’re not wise enough, Hastings, not wise enough at all to see into eternity.

paragraphs.original: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$Pleaseth your Grace to answer them directly$NEWLINE$How far forth you do like their articles.
paragraphs.translated: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$Your highness, why not tell them directly what you think of their list of grievances.

paragraphs.original: LANCASTER$NEWLINE$I like them all, and do allow them well,$NEWLINE$And swear here by the honor of my blood,$NEWLINE$My father’s purposes have been mistook,$NEWLINE$And some about him have too lavishly$NEWLINE$Wrested his meaning and authority.$NEWLINE$(to ARCHBISHOP) My lord, these griefs shall be with speed redressed;$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Upon my soul, they shall. If this may please you,$NEWLINE$Discharge your powers unto their several counties,$NEWLINE$As we will ours, and here, between the armies,$NEWLINE$Let’s drink together friendly and embrace,$NEWLINE$That all their eyes may bear those tokens home$NEWLINE$Of our restorèd love and amity.
paragraphs.translated: LANCASTER$NEWLINE$I agree with all of them, and I admit that they’re legitimate. I swear, on my family’s honor: my father’s intentions have been misunderstood, and some of his subordinates have overstepped their authority in executing his orders.$NEWLINE$(to ARCHBISHOP) Sir, we will make good on the wrongs that have been done to you, I swear on my soul. If this pleases you, then disperse your armies and send them back where they came from; we shall do the same. And here, where both armies can see us, we’ll embrace and drink a friendly toast to one another. The soldiers will go home with evidence that we’re friends once again.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$I take your princely word for these redresses.
paragraphs.translated: ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$I’ll take your word as a prince that you’ll make good on these things.

paragraphs.original: LANCASTER$NEWLINE$I give it you, and will maintain my word,$NEWLINE$And thereupon I drink unto your Grace.
paragraphs.translated: LANCASTER$NEWLINE$I give you my word, and I’ll keep it. And with that, I drink a toast to you.

paragraphs.original: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$Go, captain, and deliver to the army$NEWLINE$This news of peace. Let them have pay, and part.$NEWLINE$I know it will well please them. Hie thee, captain.
paragraphs.translated: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$Go, captain. Tell the army this news of peace. Pay them, and send them away. I know it will make them happy. Hurry, captain.

paragraphs.original: Exit officer
paragraphs.translated: An officer exits.

paragraphs.original: ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$To you, my noble Lord of Westmoreland.
paragraphs.translated: ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$Here’s to you, good Lord Westmoreland.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$I pledge your Grace, and if you knew what pains$NEWLINE$I have bestowed to breed this present peace,$NEWLINE$You would drink freely. But my love to you$NEWLINE$Shall show itself more openly hereafter.
paragraphs.translated: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$I drink to your grace. If you knew how hard I’ve worked to bring about this peaceful resolution, you’d really drink up. But my love for you will be more apparent from now on.

paragraphs.original: ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$I do not doubt you.
paragraphs.translated: ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$I don’t doubt it.

paragraphs.original: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$I am glad of it.—$NEWLINE$Health to my lord and gentle cousin, Mowbray.
paragraphs.translated: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$I’m glad. And here’s to your health, my gentle cousin Lord Mowbray.

paragraphs.original: MOWBRAY$NEWLINE$You wish me health in very happy season,$NEWLINE$For I am on the sudden something ill.
paragraphs.translated: MOWBRAY$NEWLINE$You wish me good health at a very good moment, because for some reason I’m suddenly feeling ill.

paragraphs.original: ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$Against ill chances men are ever merry,$NEWLINE$But heaviness foreruns the good event.
paragraphs.translated: ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$Men are always merry in the face of bad situations, but a heavy heart predicts a happy event.

paragraphs.original: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$Therefore be merry, coz; since sudden sorrow$NEWLINE$Serves to say thus: “Some good thing comes tomorrow.”
paragraphs.translated: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$So be happy, kinsman. A sudden feeling of melancholy is just a sign that says, “Something good is coming tomorrow.”

paragraphs.original: ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$Believe me, I am passing light in spirit.
paragraphs.translated: ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$Believe me, I’m in really good spirits.

paragraphs.original: MOWBRAY$NEWLINE$So much the worse if your own rule be true.
paragraphs.translated: MOWBRAY$NEWLINE$Which is not a good thing, if your own rule is correct.

paragraphs.original: Shouts within
paragraphs.translated: Shouts are heard offstage.

paragraphs.original: LANCASTER$NEWLINE$The word of peace is rendered. Hark how they shout.
paragraphs.translated: LANCASTER$NEWLINE$The news of peace has been announced. Listen to them shout!

paragraphs.original: MOWBRAY$NEWLINE$This had been cheerful after victory.
paragraphs.translated: MOWBRAY$NEWLINE$They sound like they are cheering a victory.

paragraphs.original: ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$A peace is of the nature of a conquest,$NEWLINE$For then both parties nobly are subdued,$NEWLINE$And neither party loser.
paragraphs.translated: ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$Peace is a victory of sorts: both sides stop fighting honorably, but neither loses.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: LANCASTER$NEWLINE$Go, my lord,$NEWLINE$And let our army be dischargèd too.
paragraphs.translated: LANCASTER$NEWLINE$Go and disperse our army, too, Lord Westmoreland.

paragraphs.original: Exit WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$WESTMORELAND
paragraphs.translated: WESTMORELAND exits.$NEWLINE$WESTMORELAND

paragraphs.original: And, good my lord, so please you, let our trains$NEWLINE$March by us, that we may peruse the men$NEWLINE$We should have coped withal.
paragraphs.translated: Good Archbishop, let’s have both our troops march past us here so that we can see the men we would have fought against.

paragraphs.original: ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$Go, good Lord Hastings,$NEWLINE$And ere they be dismissed, let them march by.
paragraphs.translated: ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$Go, Lord Hastings, and have them march past before they’re dismissed.

paragraphs.original: Exit HASTINGS$NEWLINE$HASTINGS
paragraphs.translated: HASTINGS exits.$NEWLINE$HASTINGS

paragraphs.original: LANCASTER$NEWLINE$I trust, lords, we shall lie tonight together.
paragraphs.translated: LANCASTER$NEWLINE$I hope, sirs, that we’ll spend tonight in the same camp.

paragraphs.original: Enter WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$WESTMORELAND
paragraphs.translated: WESTMORELAND enters.$NEWLINE$WESTMORELAND

paragraphs.original: Now, cousin, wherefore stands our army still?
paragraphs.translated: Cousin, why is our army still standing?

paragraphs.original: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$The leaders, having charge from you to stand,$NEWLINE$Will not go off until they hear you speak.
paragraphs.translated: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$The leaders have orders from you to stand fast, and they won’t disperse until they hear you give the order.

paragraphs.original: LANCASTER$NEWLINE$They know their duties.
paragraphs.translated: LANCASTER$NEWLINE$They know how to follow orders.

paragraphs.original: Enter HASTINGS$NEWLINE$HASTINGS
paragraphs.translated: HASTINGS enters.$NEWLINE$HASTINGS

paragraphs.original: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$My lord, our army is dispersed already.$NEWLINE$Like youthful steers unyoked, they take their courses$NEWLINE$East, west, north, south, or, like a school broke up,$NEWLINE$Each hurries toward his home and sporting-place.
paragraphs.translated: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$Our army is already dispersed. They’ve headed off to the east, west, north, and south like young bulls whose yokes have been removed. The men are like children after school, each hurrying toward their homes or the playground.

paragraphs.original: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$Good tidings, my Lord Hastings, for the which$NEWLINE$I do arrest thee, traitor, of high treason.—$NEWLINE$And you, Lord Archbishop, and you, Lord Mowbray,$NEWLINE$Of capital treason I attach you both.
paragraphs.translated: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$That’s good news, Lord Hastings. And hearing it, I now arrest you, traitor, for high treason. And you, Archbishop, and you, Lord Mowbray. I arrest you both for capital treason.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: MOWBRAY$NEWLINE$Is this proceeding just and honorable?
paragraphs.translated: MOWBRAY$NEWLINE$Is this action just and honorable?

paragraphs.original: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$Is your assembly so?
paragraphs.translated: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$Was your rebellion just and honorable?

paragraphs.original: ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$Will you thus break your faith?
paragraphs.translated: ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$Will you break faith with us like this?

paragraphs.original: LANCASTER$NEWLINE$I pawned thee none.$NEWLINE$I promised you redress of these same grievances$NEWLINE$Whereof you did complain, which, by mine honor,$NEWLINE$I will perform with a most Christian care.$NEWLINE$But for you rebels, look to taste the due$NEWLINE$Meet for rebellion and such acts as yours.$NEWLINE$Most shallowly did you these arms commence,$NEWLINE$Fondly brought here, and foolishly sent hence.—$NEWLINE$Strike up our drums; pursue the scattered stray.$NEWLINE$God, and not we, hath safely fought today.—$NEWLINE$Some guard these traitors to the block of death,$NEWLINE$Treason’s true bed and yielder-up of breath.
paragraphs.translated: LANCASTER$NEWLINE$I never promised you my faith. I promised to make good on the grievances you complained of. And, on my honor, I will do that as carefully as possible. But now, you rebels will get exactly what you deserve for the things you’ve done. You raised armies over nothing, brought them here stupidly, and then foolishly sent them away. Bang on our drums! Capture the soldiers who are scattering away. God, not we, has fought today and won. Guards, escort these traitors to the place of their death. That’s where treason belongs, and where they’ll draw their last breath.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Alarum. Excursions. Enter FALSTAFF and COLEVILE, meeting$NEWLINE$FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$COLEVILE
paragraphs.translated: Calls to arms are sounded. Soldiers cross the stage. FALSTAFF and COLEVILE enter and confront one another.$NEWLINE$FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$COLEVILE

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$What’s your name, sir? Of what condition are you, and of$NEWLINE$what place, I pray?
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$What’s your name, sir? What’s your rank, and where are you from?

paragraphs.original: COLEVILE$NEWLINE$I am a knight, sir, and my name is Colevile of the Dale.
paragraphs.translated: COLEVILLE$NEWLINE$I am a knight, sir. My name is Coleville of the Valley.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Well, then, Colevile is your name, a knight is your degree,$NEWLINE$and your place the Dale. Colevile shall be still your name, a$NEWLINE$traitor your degree, and the dungeon your place, a place deep$NEWLINE$enough so shall you be still Colevile of the Dale.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Well, then, Coleville is your name, your rank is knight, and the valley is where you’re from. Coleville will still be your name now that “traitor” is your rank, and the dungeon is where you’ll be. It’s a place so deep that you’ll still be in a kind of valley.

paragraphs.original: COLEVILE$NEWLINE$Are not you Sir John Falstaff?
paragraphs.translated: COLEVILLE$NEWLINE$Aren’t you Sir John Falstaff?

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$As good a man as he, sir, whoe'er I am. Do ye yield, sir, or$NEWLINE$shall I sweat for you? If I do sweat, they are the drops of thy$NEWLINE$lovers and they weep for thy death. Therefore rouse up fear$NEWLINE$and trembling, and do observance to my mercy.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$I’m as good a man as Falstaff, whoever I am. Will you surrender? Or am I going to have to break a sweat making you surrender? If I sweat, the drops will be the tears of your loved ones, weeping over your death. So you’d better get scared and start to shake, and start praying to me for mercy.

paragraphs.original: COLEVILE$NEWLINE$I think you are Sir John Falstaff, and in that thought yield$NEWLINE$me.
paragraphs.translated: COLEVILLE$NEWLINE$I think you are Sir John Falstaff, and so I surrender.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$I have a whole school of tongues in this belly of mine, and not a tongue of them all speaks any other word but my name. An I had but a belly of any indifferency, I were simply the most active fellow in Europe. My womb, my womb, my womb undoes me. Here comes our general.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$My enormous belly can speak in many languages, and each language proclaims my name and my name alone. If I had a moderately sized belly, all I’d be is an anonymous but very successful soldier. But my belly, my belly, my belly blows my cover. Here comes the general.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter Prince John of LANCASTER, WESTMORELAND, BLUNT, and others$NEWLINE$LANCASTER$NEWLINE$WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$BLUNT
paragraphs.translated: John of LANCASTER, WESTMORELAND, BLUNT, and others enter.$NEWLINE$LANCASTER$NEWLINE$WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$BLUNT

paragraphs.original: LANCASTER$NEWLINE$The heat is past. Follow no further now.
paragraphs.translated: LANCASTER$NEWLINE$The danger’s over: let’s stop here.

paragraphs.original: A retreat is sounded.
paragraphs.translated: The trumpets sound a retreat.

paragraphs.original: Call in the powers, good cousin Westmoreland.
paragraphs.translated: Call off the operation, Westmoreland.

paragraphs.original: Exit WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$WESTMORELAND
paragraphs.translated: WESTMORELAND exits.$NEWLINE$WESTMORELAND

paragraphs.original: Now, Falstaff, where have you been all this while?$NEWLINE$When everything is ended, then you come.$NEWLINE$These tardy tricks of yours will, on my life,$NEWLINE$One time or other break some gallows' back.
paragraphs.translated: Falstaff, where have you been all this time? When everything is over, that’s when you start. This habit of laziness of yours will bust a gallows to bits one of these days, mark my words.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$I would be sorry, my lord, but it should be thus. I never knew$NEWLINE$yet but rebuke and check was the reward of valor. Do you$NEWLINE$think me a swallow, an arrow, or a bullet? Have I in my poor$NEWLINE$and old motion the expedition of thought? I have speeded$NEWLINE$hither with the very extremest inch of possibility. I have$NEWLINE$foundered ninescore and odd posts, and here, travel-tainted$NEWLINE$as I am, have in my pure and immaculate valor taken Sir$NEWLINE$John Colevile of the Dale, a most furious knight and$NEWLINE$valorous enemy. But what of that? He saw me and yielded,$NEWLINE$that I may justly say, with the hook-nosed fellow of Rome,$NEWLINE$“There, cousin, I came, saw, and overcame.”
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$I’m sorry to hear you say that: I never realized that brave behavior should be rewarded with scolding and admonishing. Do you think I’m a bird, or an arrow, or a bullet? With this old, broken-down body, do you think I can move as fast as thought? I’ve gotten here as fast as humanly possible. I’ve burned out more than 180 horses, and—even though I’m spent from all that travel—I’ve managed, with my extraordinary bravery, to capture Sir John Coleville of the Valley, a brave knight and terrible enemy. But so what? He simply saw me and surrendered. So I can say, just like Julius Caesar, that “I came, I saw, I conquered.”

paragraphs.original: LANCASTER$NEWLINE$It was more of his courtesy than your deserving.
paragraphs.translated: LANCASTER$NEWLINE$He was just being polite; it’s not as if you did something to deserve it.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$I know not. Here he is, and here I yield him. And I beseech$NEWLINE$your Grace let it be booked with the rest of this day’s deeds,$NEWLINE$or, by the Lord, I will have it in a particular ballad else, with$NEWLINE$mine own picture on the top on ’t, Colevile kissing my foot;$NEWLINE$to the which course if I be enforced, if you do not all show
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$I don’t know about that. Here he is: I turn him over to you. Please, sir, have it added to the record of things accomplished today. If you don’t, I’ll have a ballad printed about it, with a picture of Coleville kissing my foot on the cover. And if I’m forced to do that, and I

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: like gilt twopences to me, and I in the clear sky of fame o'ershine you as much as the full moon doth the cinders of the element (which show like pins' heads to her), believe not the word of the noble. Therefore let me have right, and let desert mount.
paragraphs.translated: don’t make you look like counterfeits next to me, and if my fame doesn’t outshine yours like the full moon outshines the stars (which look like pin pricks in the sky next to the moon)—well then, you can call me a liar. Now give me what I deserve, and let my merits mount on top of each other, in a great pile.

paragraphs.original: LANCASTER$NEWLINE$Thine’s too heavy to mount.
paragraphs.translated: LANCASTER$NEWLINE$Your pile would be too heavy for me to bear.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Let it shine, then.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Let my merits shine, then.

paragraphs.original: LANCASTER$NEWLINE$Thine’s too thick to shine.
paragraphs.translated: LANCASTER$NEWLINE$You’re too dense to shine.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Let it do something, my good lord, that may do me good, and$NEWLINE$call it what you will.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Then let it do something that will do me good, whatever you want to call it.

paragraphs.original: LANCASTER$NEWLINE$Is thy name Colevile?
paragraphs.translated: LANCASTER$NEWLINE$Is your name Coleville?

paragraphs.original: COLEVILE$NEWLINE$It is, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: COLEVILLE$NEWLINE$It is, sir.

paragraphs.original: LANCASTER$NEWLINE$A famous rebel art thou, Colevile.
paragraphs.translated: LANCASTER$NEWLINE$You’re a famous rebel, Coleville.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$And a famous true subject took him.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$And a famous and loyal subject captured him.

paragraphs.original: COLEVILE$NEWLINE$I am, my lord, but as my betters are$NEWLINE$That led me hither. Had they been ruled by me,$NEWLINE$You should have won them dearer than you have.
paragraphs.translated: COLEVILLE$NEWLINE$I’m now in the same situation as my superiors, who led me here. But if I had been in charge, your victory would have cost you more than it has.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$I know not how they sold themselves, but thou, like a kind fellow, gavest thyself away gratis, and I thank thee for thee.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$I don’t know how much your superiors cost us, but you, like a generous man, gave yourself away for free, and I thank you for it.

paragraphs.original: Enter WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$WESTMORELAND
paragraphs.translated: WESTMORELAND enters.$NEWLINE$WESTMORELAND

paragraphs.original: LANCASTER$NEWLINE$Now, have you left pursuit?
paragraphs.translated: LANCASTER$NEWLINE$Have you called off the troops?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$Retreat is made and execution stayed.
paragraphs.translated: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$The order to pull back has been given, and the slaughter has been stopped.

paragraphs.original: LANCASTER$NEWLINE$Send Colevile with his confederates$NEWLINE$To York, to present execution.—$NEWLINE$Blunt, lead him hence, and see you guard him sure.
paragraphs.translated: LANCASTER$NEWLINE$Send Coleville and his confederates to York, to be put to death immediately. Blunt, lead him away, and guard him carefully.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt BLUNT with COLEVILE$NEWLINE$BLUNT$NEWLINE$COLEVILE
paragraphs.translated: BLUNT exits with COLEVILLE.$NEWLINE$BLUNT$NEWLINE$COLEVILLE

paragraphs.original: And now dispatch we toward the court, my lords.$NEWLINE$I hear the King my father is sore sick.$NEWLINE$Our news shall go before us to his Majesty,$NEWLINE$(to WESTMORELAND) Which, cousin, you shall bear to comfort$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$him,$NEWLINE$And we with sober speed will follow you.
paragraphs.translated: And now, let’s get going back to the royal court: I understand that the King, my father, is gravely ill. Send news of our victory ahead of us. (to WESTMORELAND) You, cousin, will bring him this news and comfort him with it. We’ll follow you as quickly as we can.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$My lord, I beseech you give me leave to go through$NEWLINE$Gloucestershire, and, when you come to court, stand my$NEWLINE$good lord, pray, in your good report.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Sir, please give me permission to go via Gloucestershire. When you get to the court, please vouch for my good work here.

paragraphs.original: LANCASTER$NEWLINE$Fare you well, Falstaff. I, in my condition,$NEWLINE$Shall better speak of you than you deserve.
paragraphs.translated: LANCASTER$NEWLINE$Goodbye, Falstaff. By speaking on your behalf as a prince, I’ll be speaking better of you than you deserve.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt all but FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$FALSTAFF
paragraphs.translated: Everyone exits except FALSTAFF.$NEWLINE$FALSTAFF

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$I would you had but the wit; ’twere better than your$NEWLINE$dukedom. Good faith, this same young sober-blooded boy$NEWLINE$doth not love me, nor a man cannot make him laugh. But$NEWLINE$that’s no marvel; he drinks no wine. There’s never none of$NEWLINE$these demure boys come to any proof, for thin drink doth so$NEWLINE$overcool their blood, and making many fish meals, that they$NEWLINE$fall into a kind of male green-sickness, and then, when they$NEWLINE$marry, they get wenches. They are generally fools and$NEWLINE$cowards, which some of us should be too, but for$NEWLINE$inflammation.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$I wish you had the wit to accomplish that: it would be worth all your land. My goodness, this young, serious-minded boy doesn’t like me, and no one can make him laugh. But I guess that’s not surprising; after all, he doesn’t drink any wine. None of those prim boys ever amount to anything: weak beer and too many fish dinners makes their blood cool. They all turn anemic, like young girls. And then, when they finally get married, they can only father girls because they don’t have the stuff to produce sons. Non-drinkers are all generally fools and cowards. The rest of us would probably be

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: A good sherris sack hath a two-fold operation in it. It$NEWLINE$ascends me into the brain, dries me there all the foolish and$NEWLINE$dull and crury vapors which environ it, makes it$NEWLINE$apprehensive, quick, forgetive, full of nimble, fiery, and$NEWLINE$delectable shapes, which, delivered o'er to the voice, the$NEWLINE$tongue, which is the birth, becomes excellent wit. The$NEWLINE$second property of your excellent sherris is the warming of$NEWLINE$the blood, which, before cold and settled, left the liver white$NEWLINE$and pale, which is the badge of pusillanimity and cowardice.$NEWLINE$But the sherris warms it and makes it course from the$NEWLINE$inwards to the parts' extremes. It illumineth the face, which$NEWLINE$as a beacon gives warning to all the rest of this little$NEWLINE$kingdom, man, to arm; and then the vital commoners and$NEWLINE$inland petty spirits muster me all to their captain, the heart,$NEWLINE$who, great and puffed up with this retinue, doth any deed of$NEWLINE$courage, and this valor comes of sherris. So that skill in the$NEWLINE$weapon is nothing without sack, for that sets it a-work; and$NEWLINE$learning a mere hoard of gold kept by a devil till sack$NEWLINE$commences it and sets it in act and use. Hereof comes it that$NEWLINE$Prince Harry is valiant, for the cold blood he did naturally$NEWLINE$inherit of his father he hath, like lean, sterile, and bare land,$NEWLINE$manured, husbanded, and tilled with excellent endeavor of$NEWLINE$drinking good and good store of fertile sherris, that he is$NEWLINE$become very hot and valiant. If I had a thousand sons, the$NEWLINE$first human principle I would teach them should be to$NEWLINE$forswear thin potations and to addict themselves to sack.
paragraphs.translated: the same way, except that we’re always drunk. A good sherry wine operates in two ways. First, it rises into the brain and dries out all the foolish, dull, clogged-up fogs that have gathered there. It makes the brain sharp, quick, and inventive; full of nimble, fiery, and beautiful ideas. The voice and tongue give birth to those ideas which, when they grow up, become excellent wit. The second power of good wine is the warming of the blood. Before wine, the blood is cold and sluggish, and this makes the liver—the organ of passion—chilly and pale. A chilly, pale liver is the sign of cowardice and faint-heartedness. But wine warms the blood, making it course from the inner organs to all the extremities. The blood brightens the face, and the rest of the body—which is like a little kingdom in itself—takes that brightening as a signal. Then the spirits of the blood and all the internal organs gather together behind their captain: the heart. The heart draws strength from these followers and, enlarged by them, can accomplish any courageous deed. This is the bravery that comes from wine. Without wine, skill in weaponry doesn’t matter. Wine is what sets that skill in motion. Education is nothing more than idle gold in the devil’s hands, until wine rouses it and puts it to good use. That’s how Prince Harry became valiant. He’s taken the cold blood he inherited from his father and—like unproductive farmland—he fertilized it, planted it, and cared for it, through the hard work of drinking vast amounts of good and potent wine. And so now, he’s become hot and courageous. If I had a thousand sons, the first rule of behavior I would teach them would be to avoid weak drinks, and get themselves addicted to wine.

paragraphs.original: Enter BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$BARDOLPH
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH enters.$NEWLINE$BARDOLPH

paragraphs.original: How now, Bardolph?
paragraphs.translated: What is it, Bardolph?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$The army is discharged all and gone.
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$The army is dismissed, and everyone’s gone.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Let them go. I’ll through Gloucestershire, and there will I$NEWLINE$visit Master Robert Shallow, Esquire. I have him already$NEWLINE$temp'ring between my finger and my thumb, and shortly$NEWLINE$will I seal with him. Come away.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Let them go. I’ll head to Gloucestershire. I’ll visit Master Robert Shallow, Esquire. I’ve already got him under my thumb, as soft as wax. Soon I’ll seal the deal. Let’s go.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter KING Henry, his sons Thomas Duke of CLARENCE and Humphrey Duke of GLOUCESTER, with WARWICK and others$NEWLINE$KING$NEWLINE$CLARENCE$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$WARWICK
paragraphs.translated: KING Henry, his sons Thomas Duke of CLARENCE and Humphrey Duke of GLOUCESTER, WARWICK, and others enter.$NEWLINE$KING$NEWLINE$CLARENCE$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$WARWICK

paragraphs.original: KING$NEWLINE$Now, lords, if God doth give successful end$NEWLINE$To this debate that bleedeth at our doors,$NEWLINE$We will our youth lead on to higher fields$NEWLINE$And draw no swords but what are sanctified.$NEWLINE$Our navy is addressed, our power collected,$NEWLINE$Our substitutes in absence well invested,$NEWLINE$And everything lies level to our wish.$NEWLINE$Only we want a little personal strength;$NEWLINE$And pause us till these rebels now afoot$NEWLINE$Come underneath the yoke of government.
paragraphs.translated: KING$NEWLINE$Now, my lords: if God grants us a victory in this violent civil war that bleeds at our very doorsteps, I will lead our young people in a greater cause, and fight nothing but holy wars. Our navy is ready, our army is assembled, the leaders who are my subordinates have their orders, and everything is standing by to achieve my main aim. The only drawback is that I’m feeling a little weak. So let’s wait a short while, until the rebels, now on the run, are brought back in line and are made obedient again.

paragraphs.original: WARWICK$NEWLINE$Both which we doubt not but your Majesty$NEWLINE$Shall soon enjoy.
paragraphs.translated: WARWICK$NEWLINE$We are sure that you’ll soon enjoy both good health and the rebels' defeat.

paragraphs.original: KING$NEWLINE$Humphrey, my son of Gloucester,$NEWLINE$Where is the Prince your brother?
paragraphs.translated: KING$NEWLINE$My son Humphrey of Gloucester, where is your brother, Prince Hal?

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$I think he’s gone to hunt, my lord, at Windsor.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$I think he’s gone hunting at Windsor.

paragraphs.original: KING$NEWLINE$And how accompanied?
paragraphs.translated: KING$NEWLINE$Who’s with him?

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$I do not know, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$I don’t know, father.

paragraphs.original: KING$NEWLINE$Is not his brother Thomas of Clarence with him?
paragraphs.translated: KING$NEWLINE$Isn’t his brother, Thomas of Clarence, with him?

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$No, my good lord, he is in presence here.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$No, father. He’s here.

paragraphs.original: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$What would my lord and father?
paragraphs.translated: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$What is it you’d like, father?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: KING$NEWLINE$Nothing but well to thee, Thomas of Clarence.$NEWLINE$How chance thou art not with the Prince thy brother?$NEWLINE$He loves thee, and thou dost neglect him, Thomas.$NEWLINE$Thou hast a better place in his affection$NEWLINE$Than all thy brothers. Cherish it, my boy,$NEWLINE$And noble offices thou mayst effect$NEWLINE$Of mediation, after I am dead,$NEWLINE$Between his greatness and thy other brethren.$NEWLINE$Therefore omit him not; blunt not his love,$NEWLINE$Nor lose the good advantage of his grace$NEWLINE$By seeming cold or careless of his will.$NEWLINE$For he is gracious if he be observed;$NEWLINE$He hath a tear for pity and a hand$NEWLINE$Open as day for melting charity;$NEWLINE$Yet notwithstanding, being incensed he is flint,$NEWLINE$As humorous as winter, and as sudden$NEWLINE$As flaws congealed in the spring of day.$NEWLINE$His temper therefore must be well observed.$NEWLINE$Chide him for faults, and do it reverently,$NEWLINE$When thou perceive his blood inclined to mirth;$NEWLINE$But, being moody, give him time and scope$NEWLINE$Till that his passions, like a whale on ground,$NEWLINE$Confound themselves with working. Learn this, Thomas,$NEWLINE$And thou shalt prove a shelter to thy friends,$NEWLINE$A hoop of gold to bind thy brothers in,$NEWLINE$That the united vessel of their blood,$NEWLINE$Mingled with venom of suggestion$NEWLINE$(As, force perforce, the age will pour it in),$NEWLINE$Shall never leak, though it do work as strong$NEWLINE$As aconitum or rash gunpowder.
paragraphs.translated: KING$NEWLINE$Only good things for you, Thomas. Why aren’t you with the Prince, your brother? He loves you and you are neglecting him. He cares more about you than any of his other brothers, Thomas; cherish that fact, my boy. After I’m dead, you’ll be in a strong position to help maintain good relations between Prince Hal and his brothers.$NEWLINE$So don’t ignore him. Don’t turn away his love, and don’t ruin your good relationship with him by seeming cold or distant. He’s kind if he gets his way; he has compassion for others, and he’s generous with charity. But despite all this, once he gets angry, he becomes like a stone. He can be as tempestuous as winter, and can change himself as suddenly as snowflakes at dawn can turn to hail. So watch his temper.$NEWLINE$When he does something wrong, let him know it—gently, and when he’s in a happy mood. But when he’s ornery, give him room. Wait till his bad mood works itself out, like a beached whale that kills itself by struggling to return to sea. If you can do this, you’ll be a shelter for your friends, and a golden chain that links your brothers together. Once they’re united, the poison of criticism and rumor—which in this day and age is sure to be aimed at them—can’t do them any harm, no matter how explosive and destructive it may be.

paragraphs.original: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$I shall observe him with all care and love.
paragraphs.translated: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$I’ll watch over him with as much care and love as possible.

paragraphs.original: KING$NEWLINE$Why art thou not at Windsor with him, Thomas?
paragraphs.translated: KING$NEWLINE$Then why aren’t you with him at Windsor?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$He is not there today; he dines in London.
paragraphs.translated: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$He’s not there today. He’s in London.

paragraphs.original: KING$NEWLINE$And how accompanied? Canst thou tell that?
paragraphs.translated: KING$NEWLINE$Who’s with him? Do you know?

paragraphs.original: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$With Poins and other his continual followers.
paragraphs.translated: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$Poins, and the usual suspects.

paragraphs.original: KING$NEWLINE$Most subject is the fattest soil to weeds,$NEWLINE$And he, the noble image of my youth,$NEWLINE$Is overspread with them; therefore my grief$NEWLINE$Stretches itself beyond the hour of death.$NEWLINE$The blood weeps from my heart when I do shape,$NEWLINE$In forms imaginary, th' unguided days$NEWLINE$And rotten times that you shall look upon$NEWLINE$When I am sleeping with my ancestors.$NEWLINE$For when his headstrong riot hath no curb,$NEWLINE$When rage and hot blood are his counsellors,$NEWLINE$When means and lavish manners meet together,$NEWLINE$O, with what wings shall his affections fly$NEWLINE$Towards fronting peril and opposed decay!
paragraphs.translated: KING$NEWLINE$Weeds grow best in the richest soil, and he—like myself at that age—is overrun by them. My sadness, then, cannot end with my death. When I imagine the lawless days and rotten times that you will face when I am dead and sleeping with my ancestors, the blood weeps from my heart.$NEWLINE$When Hal’s headstrong wildness has free rein; when aggression and passion are his advisors; when he has full opportunity to indulge in his riotous inclinations, then—Oh!—his criminal desires will fly like a bird towards danger and ruin.

paragraphs.original: WARWICK$NEWLINE$My gracious lord, you look beyond him quite.$NEWLINE$The Prince but studies his companions$NEWLINE$Like a strange tongue, wherein, to gain the language,$NEWLINE$'Tis needful that the most immodest word$NEWLINE$Be looked upon and learned; which, once attained,$NEWLINE$Your Highness knows, comes to no further use$NEWLINE$But to be known and hated. So, like gross terms,$NEWLINE$The Prince will, in the perfectness of time,$NEWLINE$Cast off his followers, and their memory$NEWLINE$Shall as a pattern or a measure live,$NEWLINE$By which his Grace must mete the lives of others,$NEWLINE$Turning past evils to advantages.
paragraphs.translated: WARWICK$NEWLINE$Your highness, you’ve got him all wrong. The Prince is only studying his criminal companions, the way one studies a foreign language. In order to truly learn a language, one must learn even the most immodest curse word—which, as you know, is only learned in order to be identified and, thereafter, avoided. So, like vulgar language, the Prince will get rid of his followers when the time is right. Then they’ll live on in his memory as guidelines, by which he’ll judge the conduct of others. In this sense, he’ll change his past bad deeds to good ends.

paragraphs.original: KING$NEWLINE$'Tis seldom when the bee doth leave her comb$NEWLINE$In the dead carrion.
paragraphs.translated: KING$NEWLINE$It’s rare that a bee builds its nest in a dead animal’s carcass. The Prince won’t leave his current company.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$WESTMORELAND
paragraphs.translated: WESTMORELAND enters.$NEWLINE$WESTMORELAND

paragraphs.original: Who’s here? Westmoreland?
paragraphs.translated: Who’s there? Westmoreland?

paragraphs.original: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$Health to my sovereign, and new happiness$NEWLINE$Added to that that I am to deliver.$NEWLINE$Prince John your son doth kiss your Grace’s hand.$NEWLINE$Mowbray, the Bishop Scroop, Hastings, and all$NEWLINE$Are brought to the correction of your law.$NEWLINE$There is not now a rebel’s sword unsheathed$NEWLINE$But peace puts forth her olive everywhere.$NEWLINE$The manner how this action hath been borne$NEWLINE$Here at more leisure may your Highness read$NEWLINE$With every course in his particular.
paragraphs.translated: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$I wish your highness good health, and happy news beyond the report I have to deliver! Prince John sends his respects: Mowbray, the Archbishop, Hastings and the rest are under arrest. There are no more rebels anywhere; the olive branch of peace has been extended everywhere.$NEWLINE$Here’s a letter explaining what happened. When you have time, you can read it and learn every detail.

paragraphs.original: KING$NEWLINE$O Westmoreland, thou art a summer bird,$NEWLINE$Which ever in the haunch of winter sings$NEWLINE$The lifting up of day.
paragraphs.translated: KING$NEWLINE$Oh Westmoreland; you’re like a summer bird, which sings the dawn in as winter ends.

paragraphs.original: Enter HARCOURT$NEWLINE$HARCOURT
paragraphs.translated: HARCOURT enters.$NEWLINE$HARCOURT

paragraphs.original: Here comes more news.
paragraphs.translated: Look, here’s more news.

paragraphs.original: HARCOURT$NEWLINE$From enemies heaven keep your Majesty,$NEWLINE$And when they stand against you, may they fall$NEWLINE$As those that I am come to tell you of.$NEWLINE$The Earl Northumberland and the Lord Bardolph,$NEWLINE$With a great power of English and of Scots,$NEWLINE$Are by the shrieve of Yorkshire overthrown.$NEWLINE$The manner and true order of the fight$NEWLINE$This packet, please it you, contains at large.
paragraphs.translated: HARCOURT$NEWLINE$May heaven protect your highness from all enemies—and when they do rise up, may they fall just like the ones I’ve come to tell you about. The Earl of Northumberland and Lord Bardolph, with their mighty armies of Englishmen and Scotsmen, were defeated by the Sheriff of Yorkshire. This letter will tell you the details.

paragraphs.original: KING$NEWLINE$And wherefore should these good news make me sick?$NEWLINE$Will fortune never come with both hands full,$NEWLINE$But write her fair words still in foulest letters?$NEWLINE$She either gives a stomach and no food—
paragraphs.translated: KING$NEWLINE$Why am I sick at this good news? Why can’t life ever bring you things with their appropriate complements? Why is good news so often conveyed in ugly terms? Life either gives you hunger but no food—which is the

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Such are the poor, in health—or else a feast$NEWLINE$And takes away the stomach—such are the rich,$NEWLINE$That have abundance and enjoy it not.$NEWLINE$I should rejoice now at this happy news,$NEWLINE$And now my sight fails, and my brain is giddy.$NEWLINE$O, me! Come near me, now I am much ill.
paragraphs.translated: experience of poor, healthy people—or it gives you a feast with no appetite—which is how the rich live, who have wealth and abundance but cannot enjoy it. I should be celebrating this good news, and yet my eyesight is failing, and my brain is delirious. Oh God! Come to me, I’m very sick.

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Comfort, your Majesty.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Take care, your highness!

paragraphs.original: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$O, my royal father!
paragraphs.translated: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$Oh, my royal father!

paragraphs.original: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$My sovereign lord, cheer up yourself, look up.
paragraphs.translated: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$My lord, feel better; take courage.

paragraphs.original: WARWICK$NEWLINE$Be patient, princes. You do know these fits$NEWLINE$Are with his Highness very ordinary.$NEWLINE$Stand from him, give him air. He’ll straight be well.
paragraphs.translated: WARWICK$NEWLINE$Wait a minute, princes. You know his highness has these episodes all the time. Move away from him. Give him air; he’ll be all right soon.

paragraphs.original: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$No, no, he cannot long hold out these pangs.$NEWLINE$Th' incessant care and labor of his mind$NEWLINE$Hath wrought the mure that should confine it in$NEWLINE$So thin that life looks through and will break out.
paragraphs.translated: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$No, no, he can’t survive these attacks much longer. His mind’s endless worry and concern have so shaken his body that it can barely hold together.

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$The people fear me, for they do observe$NEWLINE$Unfathered heirs and loathly births of nature.$NEWLINE$The seasons change their manners, as the year$NEWLINE$Had found some months asleep and leapt them over.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$The people are frightening me. They’ve seen terrible omens: children who seem to have supernatural fathers, and gruesomely deformed infants. The weather is in disarray, as if the calendar discovered some months were fast asleep, and decided to skip over them.

paragraphs.original: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$The river hath thrice flowed, no ebb between,$NEWLINE$And the old folk, time’s doting chronicles,$NEWLINE$Say it did so a little time before$NEWLINE$That our great-grandsire, Edward, sicked and died.
paragraphs.translated: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$The river has flooded three times, without receding between floods. The old people—those living history books—say that the last time this happened was when our great-grandfather, King Edward, fell ill and died.

paragraphs.original: WARWICK$NEWLINE$Speak lower, princes, for the King recovers.
paragraphs.translated: WARWICK$NEWLINE$Speak more softly, princes: the King is recovering.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$This apoplexy will certain be his end.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$These attacks will be the death of him.

paragraphs.original: KING$NEWLINE$I pray you, take me up and bear me hence$NEWLINE$Into some other chamber. Softly, pray.
paragraphs.translated: KING$NEWLINE$Please, carry me into another room. Quietly. Please.

paragraphs.original: They carry the KING to a bed.$NEWLINE$KING
paragraphs.translated: They carry the KING to a bed.$NEWLINE$KING

paragraphs.original: Let there be no noise made, my gentle friends,$NEWLINE$Unless some dull and favorable hand$NEWLINE$Will whisper music to my weary spirit.
paragraphs.translated: Please be silent, my friends, unless someone can play some restful, whispering music for my exhausted spirit.

paragraphs.original: WARWICK$NEWLINE$Call for the music in the other room.
paragraphs.translated: WARWICK$NEWLINE$Call the musicians in from the other room.

paragraphs.original: KING$NEWLINE$Set me the crown upon my pillow here.
paragraphs.translated: KING$NEWLINE$Put the crown here on my pillow.

paragraphs.original: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$His eye is hollow, and he changes much.
paragraphs.translated: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$His eyes are sunken, and he seems very pale.

paragraphs.original: WARWICK$NEWLINE$Less noise, less noise.
paragraphs.translated: WARWICK$NEWLINE$Less noise, less noise!

paragraphs.original: Enter PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$PRINCE HENRY
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY enters.$NEWLINE$PRINCE HENRY

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Who saw the Duke of Clarence?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Has anybody seen the Duke of Clarence?

paragraphs.original: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$I am here, brother, full of heaviness.
paragraphs.translated: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$I’m here, brother, full of sadness.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$How now! Rain within doors, and none abroad?$NEWLINE$How doth the King?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$What’s going on? Raining inside while it’s dry outside? How’s the King?

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Exceeding ill.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Extremely sick.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Heard he the good news yet? Tell it him.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Has he heard the good news yet? Tell him.

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$He altered much upon the hearing it.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Yes, he heard it, and it affected him deeply.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$If he be sick with joy, he’ll recover without physic.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$If he’s sick from joy, then he’ll get better without medicine.

paragraphs.original: WARWICK$NEWLINE$Not so much noise, my lords.—Sweet Prince, speak low.$NEWLINE$The King your father is disposed to sleep.
paragraphs.translated: WARWICK$NEWLINE$Not so loud, sirs. Prince, speak more quietly. Your father the King is trying to sleep.

paragraphs.original: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$Let us withdraw into the other room.
paragraphs.translated: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$Let’s go into the other room.

paragraphs.original: WARWICK$NEWLINE$Will ’t please your Grace to go along with us?
paragraphs.translated: WARWICK$NEWLINE$Will you come with us?

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$No, I will sit and watch here by the King.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$No. I’ll stay here with the King.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt all but PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$PRINCE HENRY
paragraphs.translated: Everyone exits except PRINCE HENRY.$NEWLINE$PRINCE HENRY

paragraphs.original: Why doth the crown lie there upon his pillow,$NEWLINE$Being so troublesome a bedfellow?$NEWLINE$O polished perturbation, golden care,$NEWLINE$That keep’st the ports of slumber open wide$NEWLINE$To many a watchful night! sleep with it now;$NEWLINE$Yet not so sound and half so deeply sweet$NEWLINE$As he whose brow with homely biggen bound$NEWLINE$Snores out the watch of night. O majesty,$NEWLINE$When thou dost pinch thy bearer, thou dost sit$NEWLINE$Like a rich armor worn in heat of day,$NEWLINE$That scald’st with safety. By his gates of breath$NEWLINE$There lies a downy feather which stirs not;$NEWLINE$Did he suspire, that light and weightless down$NEWLINE$Perforce must move. My gracious lord, my father,$NEWLINE$This sleep is sound indeed. This is a sleep$NEWLINE$That from this golden rigol hath divorced$NEWLINE$So many English kings. Thy due from me$NEWLINE$Is tears and heavy sorrows of the blood,$NEWLINE$Which nature, love, and filial tenderness$NEWLINE$Shall, O dear father, pay thee plenteously.$NEWLINE$My due from thee is this imperial crown,$NEWLINE$Which, as immediate as thy place and blood,
paragraphs.translated: Why does the crown lie there on his pillow, when it’s such a troublesome bedfellow? Oh polished aggravation, golden anxiety! You keep the eyelids open wide, to face countless sleepless nights. You sleep with the crown now, father, but you don’t sleep as soundly, or half so deeply, as that man whose head is bound with nothing more than a cheap nightcap, who snores through the night. Oh, you crown! When you pinch the person wearing you, you’re like a great suit of armor worn on a hot day—you burn the person you’re protecting. There’s a feather near my father’s lips, and it’s not moving: if he were breathing, that light, weightless thing would move. My gracious lord! Father! This is a deep sleep indeed—this is a sleep that has removed the golden ring from the heads of many English kings. Father, I owe you tears and a deep grief, and my love, the bonds of family, and a son’s tender feelings will make sure that I pay you lavishly. Your debt to me is this kingly crown, which I am owed as your heir-apparent.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Derives itself to me. (he puts the crown on his head) Lo,$NEWLINE$(he puts the crown on his head)$NEWLINE$where it sits,$NEWLINE$Which God shall guard. And put the world’s whole strength$NEWLINE$Into one giant arm, it shall not force$NEWLINE$This lineal honor from me. This from thee$NEWLINE$Will I to mine leave, as ’tis left to me.
paragraphs.translated: (he puts the crown on his head) Look, here it sits, and God will guard it. Even if all the strength in the world were gathered into a single, giant arm, it wouldn’t be able to force this inherited honor from me. I will leave this to my son as you’ve left it to me.$NEWLINE$(he puts the crown on his head)

paragraphs.original: Exit PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$PRINCE HENRY
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY exits.$NEWLINE$PRINCE HENRY

paragraphs.original: KING$NEWLINE$(waking) Warwick! Gloucester! Clarence!$NEWLINE$(waking)
paragraphs.translated: KING$NEWLINE$(waking) Warwick! Gloucester! Clarence!$NEWLINE$(waking)

paragraphs.original: Enter WARWICK, GLOUCESTER, CLARENCE, and the rest$NEWLINE$WARWICK$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$CLARENCE
paragraphs.translated: WARWICK, GLOUCESTER, CLARENCE, and the rest enter.$NEWLINE$WARWICK$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$CLARENCE

paragraphs.original: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$Doth the King call?
paragraphs.translated: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$Did you call, sir?
