paragraphs.original: WARWICK$NEWLINE$What would your Majesty? How fares your Grace?
paragraphs.translated: WARWICK$NEWLINE$What can we do for you, your highness? How are you feeling?

paragraphs.original: KING$NEWLINE$Why did you leave me here alone, my lords?
paragraphs.translated: KING$NEWLINE$Why did you leave me alone, sirs?

paragraphs.original: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$We left the Prince my brother here, my liege,$NEWLINE$Who undertook to sit and watch by you.
paragraphs.translated: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$We left my brother, Prince Hal, here. He decided to sit with you.

paragraphs.original: KING$NEWLINE$The Prince of Wales? Where is he? Let me see him.$NEWLINE$He is not here.
paragraphs.translated: KING$NEWLINE$The Prince of Wales? Where is he? I want to see him. He’s not here.

paragraphs.original: WARWICK$NEWLINE$This door is open. He is gone this way.
paragraphs.translated: WARWICK$NEWLINE$This door’s open. He went this way.

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$He came not through the chamber where we stayed.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$He didn’t come through the room we were in.

paragraphs.original: KING$NEWLINE$Where is the crown? Who took it from my pillow?
paragraphs.translated: KING$NEWLINE$Where’s the crown? Who took it off my pillow?

paragraphs.original: WARWICK$NEWLINE$When we withdrew, my liege, we left it here.
paragraphs.translated: WARWICK$NEWLINE$When we left, sir, it was here.

paragraphs.original: KING$NEWLINE$The Prince hath ta'en it hence. Go seek him out.$NEWLINE$Is he so hasty that he doth suppose my sleep my death?$NEWLINE$Find him, my Lord of Warwick. Chide him hither.
paragraphs.translated: KING$NEWLINE$The Prince has taken it. Go, find him. Is he in such a hurry that he thinks my sleep is my death? Find him, Lord Warwick. Rebuke him, and bring him here.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Exit WARWICK$NEWLINE$WARWICK
paragraphs.translated: WARWICK exits.$NEWLINE$WARWICK

paragraphs.original: This part of his conjoins with my disease$NEWLINE$And helps to end me. See, sons, what things you are,$NEWLINE$How quickly nature falls into revolt$NEWLINE$When gold becomes her object!$NEWLINE$For this the foolish overcareful fathers$NEWLINE$Have broke their sleep with thoughts,$NEWLINE$Their brains with care, their bones with industry.$NEWLINE$For this they have engrossèd and piled up$NEWLINE$The canker’d heaps of strange-achievèd gold.$NEWLINE$For this they have been thoughtful to invest$NEWLINE$Their sons with arts and martial exercises—$NEWLINE$When, like the bee, tolling from every flower$NEWLINE$The virtuous sweets,$NEWLINE$Our thighs packed with wax, our mouths with honey,$NEWLINE$We bring it to the hive and, like the bees,$NEWLINE$Are murdered for our pains. This bitter taste$NEWLINE$Yield his engrossments to the ending father.
paragraphs.translated: Henry’s actions join forces with my illness, and together they will kill me. Sons, look at what things you are. See how quickly blood bonds are broken, once money’s involved. This is what happens to foolish, overly concerned fathers who ruin their sleep with worry, burden their minds with anxiety, and break their bodies with hard work. This is what happens to fathers who amass vast amounts of money, earned in unsavory ways. This is what happens to fathers who have taken care to give their sons good educations, and train them in matters of war. Fathers are like bees, collecting sweet pollen from all the flowers in the world. We pack our thighs full of wax and our mouths full of honey, only to be killed when we return to the hive. This is the bitter fate of the dying father, no matter what he has accumulated in his life.

paragraphs.original: Enter WARWICK$NEWLINE$WARWICK
paragraphs.translated: WARWICK enters.$NEWLINE$WARWICK

paragraphs.original: Now, where is he that will not stay so long$NEWLINE$Till his friend sickness hath determined me?
paragraphs.translated: Where is that impatient man who can’t even wait for his friend, sickness, to put an end to me?

paragraphs.original: WARWICK$NEWLINE$My lord, I found the Prince in the next room,$NEWLINE$Washing with kindly tears his gentle cheeks,$NEWLINE$With such a deep demeanor in great sorrow$NEWLINE$That tyranny, which never quaffed but blood,$NEWLINE$Would, by beholding him, have washed his knife$NEWLINE$With gentle eyedrops. He is coming hither.
paragraphs.translated: WARWICK$NEWLINE$Sir, I found the Prince in the next room, with tears flowing down his cheeks. He looked so sorrowful that a tyrant—who never drank anything but blood—would, upon seeing him, have washed the blood from his knife with tears. He’s on his way.

paragraphs.original: KING$NEWLINE$But wherefore did he take away the crown?
paragraphs.translated: KING$NEWLINE$But why did he take away the crown?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$PRINCE HENRY
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY enters.$NEWLINE$PRINCE HENRY

paragraphs.original: Lo where he comes.—Come hither to me, Harry.—$NEWLINE$Depart the chamber. Leave us here alone.
paragraphs.translated: Look, here he comes. Come here, Harry. (to the rest) Leave the room, and leave us here alone.$NEWLINE$(to the rest)

paragraphs.original: Exeunt all but the KING and PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$KING$NEWLINE$PRINCE HENRY
paragraphs.translated: Everyone leaves except the KING and PRINCE HENRY.$NEWLINE$KING$NEWLINE$PRINCE HENRY

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$I never thought to hear you speak again.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$I never thought I’d hear you speak again.

paragraphs.original: KING$NEWLINE$Thy wish was father, Harry, to that thought.$NEWLINE$I stay too long by thee; I weary thee.$NEWLINE$Dost thou so hunger for mine empty chair$NEWLINE$That thou wilt needs invest thee with my honors$NEWLINE$Before thy hour be ripe? O foolish youth,$NEWLINE$Thou seek’st the greatness that will overwhelm thee.$NEWLINE$Stay but a little, for my cloud of dignity$NEWLINE$Is held from falling with so weak a wind$NEWLINE$That it will quickly drop. My day is dim.$NEWLINE$Thou hast stol'n that which after some few hours$NEWLINE$Were thine without offense, and at my death$NEWLINE$Thou hast sealed up my expectation.$NEWLINE$Thy life did manifest thou loved’st me not,$NEWLINE$And thou wilt have me die assured of it.$NEWLINE$Thou hid’st a thousand daggers in thy thoughts,$NEWLINE$Which thou hast whetted on thy stony heart$NEWLINE$To stab at half an hour of my life.$NEWLINE$What, canst thou not forbear me half an hour?$NEWLINE$Then get thee gone and dig my grave thyself,$NEWLINE$And bid the merry bells ring to thine ear$NEWLINE$That thou art crownèd, not that I am dead.$NEWLINE$Let all the tears that should bedew my hearse$NEWLINE$Be drops of balm to sanctify thy head;$NEWLINE$Only compound me with forgotten dust.$NEWLINE$Give that which gave thee life unto the worms.$NEWLINE$Pluck down my officers, break my decrees,
paragraphs.translated: KING$NEWLINE$You thought that because you wished it to be true. I live too long for you; you’re tired of me. Are you so desperate for my throne that you would take the honors of kingship before it’s your time? Oh you foolish youth! You long for power that will end up overwhelming you. Wait a little while. What power I have left is held together so weakly that the lightest breeze would blow it away: my life is fading.$NEWLINE$You stole something from me that would freely have been yours in just a few hours. On my deathbed, you’ve confirmed all my expectations. All your life you showed that you didn’t love me, and now I will die certain of it. There are a thousand daggers in your thoughts, which you’ve sharpened on your stony heart with the hopes of stabbing me in the little time I have left. What? Couldn’t you endure me for half an hour? Then go and dig my grave yourself, and ring the bells to mark your coronation, not my death. Let all the tears that should be shed on my hearse be drops of holy water to bless your head.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: For now a time is come to mock at form.$NEWLINE$Harry the Fifth is crowned. Up, vanity,$NEWLINE$Down, royal state, all you sage counsillors, hence,$NEWLINE$And to the English court assemble now,$NEWLINE$From every region, apes of idleness.$NEWLINE$Now, neighbor confines, purge you of your scum.$NEWLINE$Have you a ruffian that will swear, drink, dance,$NEWLINE$Revel the night, rob, murder, and commit$NEWLINE$The oldest sins the newest kind of ways?$NEWLINE$Be happy, he will trouble you no more.$NEWLINE$England shall double gild his treble guilt.$NEWLINE$England shall give him office, honor, might,$NEWLINE$For the fifth Harry from curbed license plucks$NEWLINE$The muzzle of restraint, and the wild dog$NEWLINE$Shall flesh his tooth on every innocent.$NEWLINE$O my poor kingdom, sick with civil blows!$NEWLINE$When that my care could not withhold thy riots,$NEWLINE$What wilt thou do when riot is thy care?$NEWLINE$O, thou wilt be a wilderness again,$NEWLINE$Peopled with wolves, thy old inhabitants.
paragraphs.translated: Just mix me up with the forgotten dust, and give my body—which gave you life—to the worms. Fire my officers, undo my laws; for now the time has come to jeer at authority. Henry the Fifth is crowned: up with foolishness! Down with decorum! Be gone, all you wise advisers! Assemble lazy apes from every region, and make them the royal court of England! Now, you neighboring countries, get rid of your scum. Do you have a criminal who swears, drinks, dances, parties all night, robs, murders, and commits the oldest sins in the newest ways? Then be happy: that man won’t trouble you any longer. England will paint over his guilt with gold. England will give him a position, honor, power. Because Henry the Fifth has removed the barriers to anarchy: he’s taken the restraining muzzle off the dog of misbehavior, and that wild dog will sink his teeth into the flesh of every decent person. Oh my poor kingdom, sick from this civil war! When all my hard work couldn’t keep disorder at bay, what will you do when disorder becomes your caretaker? Oh, you’ll be a wilderness again, and all the wolves who lived here once will once again be your only citizens.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$O pardon me, my liege! But for my tears,$NEWLINE$The moist impediments unto my speech,$NEWLINE$I had forestalled this dear and deep rebuke$NEWLINE$Ere you with grief had spoke and I had heard$NEWLINE$The course of it so far. There is your crown,$NEWLINE$And He that wears the crown immortally$NEWLINE$Long guard it yours. If I affect it more$NEWLINE$Than as your honor and as your renown,$NEWLINE$Let me no more from this obedience rise,$NEWLINE$Which my most inward true and duteous spirit$NEWLINE$Teacheth this prostrate and exterior bending.$NEWLINE$God witness with me, when I here came in$NEWLINE$And found no course of breath within your Majesty,$NEWLINE$How cold it struck my heart! If I do feign,$NEWLINE$O, let me in my present wildness die
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Oh forgive me, your highness. If it weren’t for these tears—which are impeding my speech—I would have stopped this harsh scolding before you, in your grief, had spoken and before I had listened so long. There’s your crown. May God, who wears the crown eternally, guard it as yours for a long time. If I care for the crown in any way other than as a symbol of your honor and reputation, let me never rise from this kneeling position. It is my deepest and most dutiful feelings which teach my body to bend and bow to you, causing my outer body to reflect my inner feelings. May God be my witness: when I came in here and saw that you weren’t breathing, my blood ran cold. If I’m lying,

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: And never live to show th' incredulous world$NEWLINE$The noble change that I have purposèd.$NEWLINE$Coming to look on you, thinking you dead,$NEWLINE$And dead almost, my liege, to think you were,$NEWLINE$I spake unto this crown as having sense,$NEWLINE$And thus upbraided it: “The care on thee depending$NEWLINE$Hath fed upon the body of my father;$NEWLINE$Therefore thou best of gold art worst of gold.$NEWLINE$Other, less fine in carat, is more precious,$NEWLINE$Preserving life in med'cine potable;$NEWLINE$But thou, most fine, most honored, most renowned,$NEWLINE$Hast eat thy bearer up.” Thus, my most royal liege,$NEWLINE$Accusing it, I put it on my head$NEWLINE$To try with it, as with an enemy$NEWLINE$That had before my face murdered my father,$NEWLINE$The quarrel of a true inheritor.$NEWLINE$But if it did infect my blood with joy$NEWLINE$Or swell my thoughts to any strain of pride,$NEWLINE$If any rebel or vain spirit of mine$NEWLINE$Did with the least affection of a welcome$NEWLINE$Give entertainment to the might of it,$NEWLINE$Let God forever keep it from my head$NEWLINE$And make me as the poorest vassal is$NEWLINE$That doth with awe and terror kneel to it.
paragraphs.translated: may I die as the wild youth I was before, and never live to show the dubious world the transformation I have been planning.$NEWLINE$Coming to see you, thinking you were dead—and being nearly dead myself, just thinking that you were—I spoke to this crown as though it were alive. I scolded it like this: “The worry you’ve caused has eaten my father alive. So you, the best piece of gold, are actually the worst piece of gold. Other gold, perhaps worth less, is more precious, since it at least brings us health when mixed in our drinks. But you—the best, the most honored, the most famous—have consumed the person wearing you.” And as I accused it, I put it on my head, to fight against it as an enemy who’d killed my father before my very eyes. It was the fight of a loyal child.$NEWLINE$But may God keep it from me forever—making me like the poorest servant bowing down before it in awe and terror—if it in any way made me happy or arrogant, or if any part of me was the least bit pleased to welcome it and the power it brings.

paragraphs.original: KING$NEWLINE$O my son,$NEWLINE$God put it in thy mind to take it hence$NEWLINE$That thou mightst win the more thy father’s love,$NEWLINE$Pleading so wisely in excuse of it.$NEWLINE$Come hither, Harry, sit thou by my bed$NEWLINE$And hear, I think, the very latest counsel$NEWLINE$That ever I shall breathe. God knows, my son,$NEWLINE$By what bypaths and indirect crook’d ways$NEWLINE$I met this crown, and I myself know well$NEWLINE$How troublesome it sat upon my head.$NEWLINE$To thee it shall descend with better quiet,
paragraphs.translated: KING$NEWLINE$Oh my son, God made you take it from me so that, in pleading your case so beautifully, you would make me love you more! Come here, Harry. Sit by my bed and listen to what I think will be the last advice I ever give. God knows the unusual paths and indirect, crooked ways that led me to this crown.$NEWLINE$And I know very well how much anxiety it has caused as I’ve worn it. It will fall to you in bitter peace, with

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Better opinion, better confirmation,$NEWLINE$For all the soil of the achievement goes$NEWLINE$With me into the earth. It seemed in me$NEWLINE$But as an honor snatched with boist'rous hand,$NEWLINE$And I had many living to upbraid$NEWLINE$My gain of it by their assistances,$NEWLINE$Which daily grew to quarrel and to bloodshed,$NEWLINE$Wounding supposèd peace. All these bold fears$NEWLINE$Thou see’st with peril I have answerèd,$NEWLINE$For all my reign hath been but as a scene$NEWLINE$Acting that argument. And now my death$NEWLINE$Changes the mood, for what in me was purchased$NEWLINE$Falls upon thee in a more fairer sort.$NEWLINE$So thou the garland wear’st successively.$NEWLINE$Yet though thou stand’st more sure than I could do,$NEWLINE$Thou art not firm enough, since griefs are green,$NEWLINE$And all my friends, which thou must make thy friends,$NEWLINE$Have but their stings and teeth newly ta'en out,$NEWLINE$By whose fell working I was first advanced$NEWLINE$And by whose power I well might lodge a fear$NEWLINE$To be again displaced; which to avoid,$NEWLINE$I cut them off and had a purpose now$NEWLINE$To lead out many to the Holy Land,$NEWLINE$Lest rest and lying still might make them look$NEWLINE$Too near unto my state. Therefore, my Harry,$NEWLINE$Be it thy course to busy giddy minds$NEWLINE$With foreign quarrels; that action, hence borne out,$NEWLINE$May waste the memory of the former days.$NEWLINE$More would I, but my lungs are wasted so$NEWLINE$That strength of speech is utterly denied me.$NEWLINE$How I came by the crown, O God forgive,$NEWLINE$And grant it may with thee in true peace live.
paragraphs.translated: better support and stronger approval. The stain of its obtainment dies now, with me. On me, the crown seemed like an honor grabbed with a violent hand, and many people lived to remind me that they had helped me take it. Eventually, those daily reminders grew into war and bloodshed, doing damage to the peace. You can see how much pain it’s caused me as I’ve fought my foes. My entire reign has been like a play, in which we rehash that disagreement.$NEWLINE$Now my death changes the show. What I bought, you will inherit. You’ll wear the crown by right of succession. But even though you have a firmer claim to the crown than I had, it’s not firm enough. Anger is still fresh, and my former friends—whom you must make into your friends—have only recently been disarmed. It was their power that first got me the crown, and I feared that same power could take me down. To avoid that, I defeated their rebellion, and planned to lead an army to the Holy Land. I thought that, with nothing to occupy themselves, they’d start eyeing me and my crown.$NEWLINE$Therefore, my Harry, make it your policy to focus the distracted minds of the people with foreign wars. Military actions abroad will make people forget about troubling matters in the past. I’d say more, but my lungs are so worn out that I don’t have the strength to speak. God forgive me for how I came by the crown, and may he grant that you enjoy it in peace.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$My gracious liege,$NEWLINE$You won it, wore it, kept it, gave it me.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$My gracious lord, you won it, wore it, kept it, then gave it to me. My possession of it must therefore be honest

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Then plain and right must my possession be,$NEWLINE$Which I with more than with a common pain$NEWLINE$'Gainst all the world will rightfully maintain.
paragraphs.translated: and lawful. And I will work as hard as I can to defend this crown against any man.

paragraphs.original: Enter Lord John of LANCASTER$NEWLINE$LANCASTER
paragraphs.translated: Lord John of LANCASTER enters.$NEWLINE$LANCASTER

paragraphs.original: KING$NEWLINE$Look, look, here comes my John of Lancaster.
paragraphs.translated: KING$NEWLINE$Look, look, here comes my son, John of Lancaster.

paragraphs.original: LANCASTER$NEWLINE$Health, peace, and happiness to my royal father.
paragraphs.translated: LANCASTER$NEWLINE$Health, peace, and happiness to my royal father!

paragraphs.original: KING$NEWLINE$Thou bring’st me happiness and peace, son John,$NEWLINE$But health, alack, with youthful wings is flown$NEWLINE$From this bare withered trunk. Upon thy sight$NEWLINE$My worldly business makes a period.$NEWLINE$Where is my Lord of Warwick?
paragraphs.translated: KING$NEWLINE$You bring me happiness and peace, John. But health, unfortunately, has flown from this shrunken body. Now that I’ve seen you, I have nothing more to do in this world. Where is Lord Warwick?

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$My Lord of Warwick.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Lord Warwick!

paragraphs.original: Enter WARWICK and others$NEWLINE$WARWICK
paragraphs.translated: WARWICK and others enter.$NEWLINE$WARWICK

paragraphs.original: KING$NEWLINE$Doth any name particular belong$NEWLINE$Unto the lodging where I first did swoon?
paragraphs.translated: KING$NEWLINE$Does the room I first collapsed in have a name?

paragraphs.original: WARWICK$NEWLINE$'Tis called Jerusalem, my noble lord.
paragraphs.translated: WARWICK$NEWLINE$It’s called the Jerusalem Room, your highness.

paragraphs.original: KING$NEWLINE$Laud be to God! Even there my life must end.$NEWLINE$It hath been prophesied to me many years,$NEWLINE$I should not die but in Jerusalem,$NEWLINE$Which vainly I supposed the Holy Land.$NEWLINE$But bear me to that chamber; there I’ll lie.$NEWLINE$In that Jerusalem shall Harry die.
paragraphs.translated: KING$NEWLINE$Praise be to God! That’s where I must die. For years it’s been predicted that I would die in Jerusalem; I foolishly thought that meant the Holy Land. But carry me to that room, and there I’ll lie. In that Jerusalem will Harry die.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter SHALLOW, FALSTAFF, PAGE, and BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$SHALLOW$NEWLINE$FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$PAGE$NEWLINE$BARDOLPH
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW, FALSTAFF, BARDOLPH, and the PAGE enter.$NEWLINE$SHALLOW$NEWLINE$FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$PAGE

paragraphs.original: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$By cock and pie, sir, you shall not away tonight.—What,$NEWLINE$Davy, I say!
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$By gum, sir, you will not leave tonight. Hey, Davy!

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$You must excuse me, Master Robert Shallow.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Please excuse me, Master Robert Shallow.

paragraphs.original: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$I will not excuse you. You shall not be excused. Excuses$NEWLINE$shall not be admitted. There is no excuse shall serve. You$NEWLINE$shall not be excused.—Why, Davy!
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$I will not excuse you. You will not be excused. Excuses will not be allowed. No excuse will do. You will not be excused. Hey, Davy!

paragraphs.original: Enter DAVY$NEWLINE$DAVY
paragraphs.translated: DAVY enters.$NEWLINE$DAVY

paragraphs.original: DAVY$NEWLINE$Here, sir.
paragraphs.translated: DAVY$NEWLINE$Here, sir.

paragraphs.original: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Davy, Davy, Davy, Davy, let me see, Davy, let me see, Davy,$NEWLINE$let me see. Yea, marry, William cook, bid him come$NEWLINE$hither.—Sir John, you shall not be excused.
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Davy, Davy, Davy, Davy, let’s see, Davy, let’s see, Davy, let’s see. Oh yes, right: tell William the cook to come here. Sir John, you will not be excused.

paragraphs.original: DAVY$NEWLINE$Marry, sir, thus: those precepts cannot be served. And again,$NEWLINE$sir, shall we sow the hade land with wheat?
paragraphs.translated: DAVY$NEWLINE$Well sir, here’s the thing. Those warrants couldn’t be served. And once more, sir, should we plant wheat at the field’s edges?

paragraphs.original: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$With red wheat, Davy. But for William cook, are there no$NEWLINE$young pigeons?
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Plant red wheat, Davy. But as for William the cook—aren’t there any young pigeons?

paragraphs.original: DAVY$NEWLINE$Yes, sir. Here is now the smith’s note for shoeing and plow$NEWLINE$irons.
paragraphs.translated: DAVY$NEWLINE$Yes, sir. Here’s the bill from the blacksmith for horseshoes and plow blades.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Let it be cast and paid.—Sir John, you shall not be excused.
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Check the figures and then and pay it. Sir John, you will not be excused.

paragraphs.original: DAVY$NEWLINE$Now, sir, a new link to the bucket must needs be had. And,$NEWLINE$sir, do you mean to stop any of William’s wages about the$NEWLINE$sack he lost the other day at Hinckley Fair?
paragraphs.translated: DAVY$NEWLINE$Now, sir, we need some new chain for the bucket. And sir, do you plan to dock William’s pay for the wine he lost at the Hinckley fair?

paragraphs.original: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$He shall answer it. Some pigeons, Davy, a couple of short-$NEWLINE$legged hens, a joint of mutton, and any pretty little tiny kickshaws, tell William cook.
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$He’ll pay for that. Some pigeons, Davy; a couple of short-legged hens, a leg of lamb, and any fun little fancy dishes. Tell William the cook.

paragraphs.original: DAVY$NEWLINE$Doth the man of war stay all night, sir?
paragraphs.translated: DAVY$NEWLINE$Is the soldier staying all night?

paragraphs.original: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Yea, Davy. I will use him well. A friend i' th' court is better$NEWLINE$than a penny in purse. Use his men well, Davy, for they are$NEWLINE$arrant knaves and will backbite.
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Yes, Davy. I’ll take good care of him. A friend at court is better than money in your pocket. Take good care of his men, Davy. They’re good-for-nothings, and they’ll bite you.

paragraphs.original: DAVY$NEWLINE$No worse than they are back-bitten, sir, for they have$NEWLINE$marvellous foul linen.
paragraphs.translated: DAVY$NEWLINE$No worse than they’re bitten, sir. Their clothes are full of lice.

paragraphs.original: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Well-conceited, Davy. About thy business, Davy.
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Good one, Davy. Get on with your work, Davy.

paragraphs.original: DAVY$NEWLINE$I beseech you, sir, to countenance William Visor of Woncot$NEWLINE$against Clement Perkes o' th' hill.
paragraphs.translated: DAVY$NEWLINE$Please, sir, rule in favor of William Visor of Woncot in his lawsuit against Clement Perkes of the hill.

paragraphs.original: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$There is many complaints, Davy, against that Visor. That$NEWLINE$Visor is an arrant knave, on my knowledge.
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Davy, there are a lot of suits against that Visor. That Visor is a good-for-nothing, as best I can tell.

paragraphs.original: DAVY$NEWLINE$I grant your Worship that he is a knave, sir, but yet, God$NEWLINE$forbid, sir, but a knave should have some countenance at his$NEWLINE$friend’s request. An honest man, sir, is able to speak for$NEWLINE$himself when a knave is not. I have served your Worship$NEWLINE$truly, sir, this eight years; an if I cannot once or twice in a$NEWLINE$quarter bear out a knave against an honest man, I have
paragraphs.translated: DAVY$NEWLINE$I agree with your honor that he’s a good-for-nothing, but God forbid that a good-for-nothing should be denied a favor when his friend asks for one on his behalf. An honest man can speak for himself, but a good-for-nothing can’t. I’ve worked for you for eight years, sir. If I can’t get you to rule in favor of a good-

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: a very little credit with your Worship. The knave is mine$NEWLINE$honest friend, sir; therefore I beseech you let him be$NEWLINE$countenanced.
paragraphs.translated: for-nothing once in a while, then obviously you don’t think very much of me. That good-for-nothing is my good friend, sir. So I ask you, please: rule in his favor.

paragraphs.original: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Go to, I say he shall have no wrong. Look about, Davy.
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Stop now; I tell you he won’t be wronged. Now get going, Davy.

paragraphs.original: Exit DAVY$NEWLINE$DAVY
paragraphs.translated: DAVY exits.$NEWLINE$DAVY

paragraphs.original: Where are you, Sir John? Come, come, come, off with your$NEWLINE$boots.—Give me your hand, Master Bardolph.
paragraphs.translated: Where are you, Sir John? Come, come, come. Take$NEWLINE$your boots off. Let me shake your hand, Master$NEWLINE$Bardolph.

paragraphs.original: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$I am glad to see your Worship.
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$I’m glad to see you, your honor.

paragraphs.original: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$I thank thee with all my heart, kind Master Bardolph, (to the$NEWLINE$(to the$NEWLINE$PAGE) and welcome, my tall fellow.—Come, Sir John.$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$I thank you with all my heart, Master Bardolph. (to the PAGE) Welcome, you tall fellow. Come, Sir John.$NEWLINE$(to the$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$I’ll follow you, good Master Robert Shallow.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$I’ll be right behind you, Master Robert Shallow.

paragraphs.original: Exit SHALLOW$NEWLINE$SHALLOW
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW exits.$NEWLINE$SHALLOW

paragraphs.original: Bardolph, look to our horses.
paragraphs.translated: Bardolph, get our horses ready.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt BARDOLPH and PAGE$NEWLINE$BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$PAGE
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH and the PAGE exit.$NEWLINE$BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$PAGE

paragraphs.original: If I were sawed into quantities, I should make four dozen of$NEWLINE$such bearded hermits' staves as Master Shallow. It is a$NEWLINE$wonderful thing to see the semblable coherence of his men’s$NEWLINE$spirits and his. They, by observing of him, do bear$NEWLINE$themselves like foolish justices; he, by conversing with$NEWLINE$them, is turned into a justice-like servingman. Their spirits$NEWLINE$are so married in conjunction with the participation of$NEWLINE$society that they flock together in consent like so many wild$NEWLINE$geese. If I had a suit to Master Shallow, I would humor his$NEWLINE$men with the imputation of being near their master;if to his$NEWLINE$men, I would curry with Master Shallow that no man could$NEWLINE$better command his servants. It is certain that either wise$NEWLINE$bearing or ignorant carriage is caught, as men take diseases,$NEWLINE$one of another. Therefore let men take heed of their$NEWLINE$company. I will devise matter enough out of this Shallow to
paragraphs.translated: If I were cut into pieces, I’d make four dozen bearded broomsticks like this Master Shallow. It’s amazing to see the similarity between his men’s dispositions and his own. They watch him and behave like foolish judges, and he, by associating with them, turns into a judge-like workman. Their spirits are so closely joined by their intimate involvement, they’re like a flock of wild geese that fly in formation. If I needed a favor from Judge Shallow, I would make his men think that I’m a close friend of his. If I needed something from his men, I would flatter Shallow by telling him that no one commands servants better than he does. One thing’s for sure: the behavior of a wise man and that of an idiot are contagious, like diseases. They spread from person to person, which is why people must be careful about

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: keep Prince Harry in continual laughter the wearing out of six fashions, which is four terms, or two actions, and a' shall laugh without intervallums. O, it is much that a lie with a slight oath and a jest with a sad brow will do with a fellow that never had the ache in his shoulders. O, you shall see him laugh till his face be like a wet cloak ill laid up.
paragraphs.translated: the company they keep. I’ll come up with enough material about this Shallow to keep Prince Hal laughing nonstop for a year. That’s how much time it takes for the current fashion to change six times, or for two lawsuits to be completed. He’ll laugh with no intermission. Oh, a lie told with a measure of truth—or a joke told with a serious face—will go far with a young fellow, who has never had his shoulders weighed down by old age or worries. Oh, he’ll laugh until his face looks like a wet coat that was hung poorly—it’ll be all wrinkled from laughter.

paragraphs.original: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$(within) Sir John.$NEWLINE$(within)
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$(offstage) Sir John!$NEWLINE$(offstage)

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$I come, Master Shallow; I come, Master Shallow.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Coming, Master Shallow! Coming!

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter WARWICK and the Lord CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$WARWICK$NEWLINE$CHIEF JUSTICE
paragraphs.translated: WARWICK and the Lord CHIEF JUSTICE enter.$NEWLINE$WARWICK$NEWLINE$CHIEF JUSTICE

paragraphs.original: WARWICK$NEWLINE$How now, my Lord Chief Justice, whither away?
paragraphs.translated: WARWICK$NEWLINE$What’s happening, my Lord Chief Justice? Where are you going?

paragraphs.original: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$How doth the King?
paragraphs.translated: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$How’s the King doing?

paragraphs.original: WARWICK$NEWLINE$Exceeding well. His cares are now all ended.
paragraphs.translated: WARWICK$NEWLINE$Very well. All his worries are ended now.

paragraphs.original: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$I hope, not dead.
paragraphs.translated: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$Not dead, I hope.

paragraphs.original: WARWICK$NEWLINE$He’s walked the way of nature,$NEWLINE$And to our purposes he lives no more.
paragraphs.translated: WARWICK$NEWLINE$He’s gone down nature’s path; for our purposes, he is no longer living.

paragraphs.original: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$I would his Majesty had called me with him.$NEWLINE$The service that I truly did his life$NEWLINE$Hath left me open to all injuries.
paragraphs.translated: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$I wish his majesty had brought me with him. The work I did for him while he was alive makes me very vulnerable, now that he’s dead.

paragraphs.original: WARWICK$NEWLINE$Indeed, I think the young King loves you not.
paragraphs.translated: WARWICK$NEWLINE$Indeed, I think the young King has no love for you.

paragraphs.original: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$I know he doth not, and do arm myself$NEWLINE$To welcome the condition of the time,$NEWLINE$Which cannot look more hideously upon me$NEWLINE$Than I have drawn it in my fantasy.
paragraphs.translated: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$I know he doesn’t. I’m preparing myself to deal with whatever happens, which can’t be any worse than what I’ve imagined.

paragraphs.original: Enter LANCASTER, CLARENCE, GLOUCESTER, and others$NEWLINE$LANCASTER$NEWLINE$CLARENCE$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER
paragraphs.translated: LANCASTER, CLARENCE, GLOUCESTER, and others enter.$NEWLINE$LANCASTER$NEWLINE$CLARENCE$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER

paragraphs.original: WARWICK$NEWLINE$Here come the heavy issue of dead Harry.$NEWLINE$O, that the living Harry had the temper$NEWLINE$Of he the worst of these three gentlemen!$NEWLINE$How many nobles then should hold their places$NEWLINE$That must strike sail to spirits of vile sort!
paragraphs.translated: WARWICK$NEWLINE$Here come the heavy-hearted children of dead Harry. If only the living Harry had the character of the worst of these three young men. Then a lot of noblemen would remain secure, instead of having to step aside to make room for lowlifes.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$O God, I fear all will be overturned.
paragraphs.translated: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$Oh God! I’m afraid everything will be turned upside-down.

paragraphs.original: LANCASTER$NEWLINE$Good morrow, cousin Warwick, good morrow.
paragraphs.translated: LANCASTER$NEWLINE$Good morning, cousin Warwick, good morning.

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER AND CLARENCE$NEWLINE$Good morrow, cousin.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER AND CLARENCE$NEWLINE$Good morning, cousin.

paragraphs.original: LANCASTER$NEWLINE$We meet like men that had forgot to speak.
paragraphs.translated: LANCASTER$NEWLINE$We’re all like men who don’t remember how to speak.

paragraphs.original: WARWICK$NEWLINE$We do remember, but our argument$NEWLINE$Is all too heavy to admit much talk.
paragraphs.translated: WARWICK$NEWLINE$We remember how, but what we have to say is so sad that we cannot speak.

paragraphs.original: LANCASTER$NEWLINE$Well, peace be with him that hath made us heavy.
paragraphs.translated: LANCASTER$NEWLINE$Well, peace be with the man who has made us sad.

paragraphs.original: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$Peace be with us, lest we be heavier.
paragraphs.translated: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$Peace be with us, or else we’ll be even sadder!

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$O, good my lord, you have lost a friend indeed,$NEWLINE$And I dare swear you borrow not that face$NEWLINE$Of seeming sorrow; it is sure your own.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Oh, my good lord, you’ve lost a friend, indeed. I’m sure you’re not borrowing that sorrowful face; it’s certainly your own.

paragraphs.original: LANCASTER$NEWLINE$Though no man be assured what grace to find,$NEWLINE$You stand in coldest expectation.$NEWLINE$I am the sorrier; would ’twere otherwise.
paragraphs.translated: LANCASTER$NEWLINE$Even though no man can know what blessings will come his way, he must expect the worst. I am sorry; I wish it were otherwise.

paragraphs.original: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$Well, you must now speak Sir John Falstaff fair,$NEWLINE$Which swims against your stream of quality.
paragraphs.translated: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$Well, now you are only allowed to speak well of Sir John Falstaff, which goes against the nature of a man of your quality.

paragraphs.original: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$Sweet princes, what I did I did in honor,$NEWLINE$Led by th' impartial conduct of my soul;$NEWLINE$And never shall you see that I will beg$NEWLINE$A ragged and forestalled remission.$NEWLINE$If truth and upright innocency fail me,$NEWLINE$I’ll to the King my master that is dead$NEWLINE$And tell him who hath sent me after him.
paragraphs.translated: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$Sweet princes, what I did, I did honorably, impartially, and with a clear conscience. You won’t see me begging vilely for a pardon, which is sure to be withdrawn as soon as it is given. If truth and honest innocence don’t help me, then I’ll join my dead King and tell him who sent me.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: WARWICK$NEWLINE$Here comes the Prince.
paragraphs.translated: WARWICK$NEWLINE$Here comes the Prince.

paragraphs.original: Enter PRINCE HENRY (now King Henry V), attended$NEWLINE$PRINCE HENRY
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY (now King Henry V) enters, with attendants.$NEWLINE$PRINCE HENRY

paragraphs.original: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$Good morrow, and God save your Majesty.
paragraphs.translated: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$Good morning, and God save your majesty!

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$This new and gorgeous garment majesty$NEWLINE$Sits not so easy on me as you think.—$NEWLINE$Brothers, you mix your sadness with some fear.$NEWLINE$This is the English, not the Turkish court;$NEWLINE$Not Amurath an Amurath succeeds,$NEWLINE$But Harry Harry. Yet be sad, good brothers,$NEWLINE$For, by my faith, it very well becomes you.$NEWLINE$Sorrow so royally in you appears$NEWLINE$That I will deeply put the fashion on$NEWLINE$And wear it in my heart. Why then, be sad.$NEWLINE$But entertain no more of it, good brothers,$NEWLINE$Than a joint burden laid upon us all.$NEWLINE$For me, by heaven, I bid you be assured,$NEWLINE$I’ll be your father and your brother too.$NEWLINE$Let me but bear your love, I ’ll bear your cares.$NEWLINE$Yet weep that Harry’s dead, and so will I,$NEWLINE$But Harry lives that shall convert those tears$NEWLINE$By number into hours of happiness.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$This new and gorgeous robe of majesty doesn’t fit me as comfortably as you think. Brothers, your sadness is mixed with fear. This is the English court, not the Turkish one. I’m not Amurath, who had his brothers killed when he inherited his father King Amurath’s crown; I’m a Harry, following another Harry. But be sad, brothers, because truly, it suits you. You look so regal in your sorrow that I will solemnly put it on as well, and wear it in my heart. Be sad, but don’t let it be anything more than a burden we all share jointly. I want you to rest assured that as far as I’m concerned, I’ll be both your father and your brother now. Just trust me with your love, and you can trust me to care for you. Keep weeping for Harry, who is dead; I will, as well. But one Harry still lives, and he will convert those tears one by one into hours of happiness.

paragraphs.original: PRINCES$NEWLINE$We hope no otherwise from your Majesty.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCES$NEWLINE$We hope that’s exactly what you’ll do.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$You all look strangely on me. (to the CHIEF JUSTICE) And you$NEWLINE$(to the$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$most.$NEWLINE$You are, I think, assured I love you not.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$You’re all looking at me strangely. (to the CHIEF JUSTICE) You, most of all. I think you’re certain that I don’t love you.$NEWLINE$(to the$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$I am assured, if I be measured rightly,$NEWLINE$Your Majesty hath no just cause to hate me.
paragraphs.translated: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$I’m certain that, if my actions are fairly considered, your majesty will find no just reason to hate me.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$No?$NEWLINE$How might a prince of my great hopes forget$NEWLINE$So great indignities you laid upon me?$NEWLINE$What, rate, rebuke, and roughly send to prison$NEWLINE$Th' immediate heir of England? Was this easy?$NEWLINE$May this be washed in Lethe and forgotten?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$No? How can a great prince like me forget the terrible wrongs you did me? What were you thinking, to scold, punish, and violently imprison the heir to the English throne? Was this nothing? Should this be dipped in the river of forgetfulness and simply ignored?

paragraphs.original: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$I then did use the person of your father;$NEWLINE$The image of his power lay then in me.$NEWLINE$And in th' administration of his law,$NEWLINE$Whiles I was busy for the commonwealth,$NEWLINE$Your Highness pleasèd to forget my place,$NEWLINE$The majesty and power of law and justice,$NEWLINE$The image of the King whom I presented,$NEWLINE$And struck me in my very seat of judgment,$NEWLINE$Whereon, as an offender to your father,$NEWLINE$I gave bold way to my authority$NEWLINE$And did commit you. If the deed were ill,$NEWLINE$Be you contented, wearing now the garland,$NEWLINE$To have a son set your decrees at nought?$NEWLINE$To pluck down justice from your awful bench?$NEWLINE$To trip the course of law and blunt the sword$NEWLINE$That guards the peace and safety of your person?$NEWLINE$Nay more, to spurn at your most royal image$NEWLINE$And mock your workings in a second body?$NEWLINE$Question your royal thoughts, make the case yours;$NEWLINE$Be now the father and propose a son,$NEWLINE$Hear your own dignity so much profaned,$NEWLINE$See your most dreadful laws so loosely slighted,$NEWLINE$Behold yourself so by a son disdained,$NEWLINE$And then imagine me taking your part$NEWLINE$And in your power soft silencing your son.$NEWLINE$After this cold considerance, sentence me,$NEWLINE$And, as you are a king, speak in your state
paragraphs.translated: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$I acted with the authority of your father, whose power was vested in me. And when it came to the law—which I was busy enforcing, for the good of the country—you chose to ignore my rank, and the majesty and power of law and justice which I bore as a representative of the King. You struck me in the head, the very location of my judgment. With that action, you committed a crime against your father’s own laws. So I did what my power demanded, and imprisoned you. If that was wrong, then—now that you wear the crown—I hope you’ll someday be satisfied with a son who mocks your laws, who scorns the judges who rule in your authority, who disrupts the course of law, and blunts the swords that guard your personal peace and safety.$NEWLINE$No, even worse than that: a son who disrespects your deputies, and the officers you appoint in your name. Question yourself, and imagine being in your father’s position. Be a father, and imagine a son. Listen to your own dignity being profaned. Watch as your most solemn laws are laughed at so lightly. Behold yourself being so disdained by a son. And then imagine that I take your side, and that in your name I gently silence your son. Soberly consider this, and then pronounce my sentence. As king, tell me

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: What I have done that misbecame my place,$NEWLINE$My person, or my liege’s sovereignty.
paragraphs.translated: what I have done that was so unseemly for my station, myself, or my king’s authority.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$You are right, justice, and you weigh this well.$NEWLINE$Therefore still bear the balance and the sword.$NEWLINE$And I do wish your honors may increase$NEWLINE$Till you do live to see a son of mine$NEWLINE$Offend you and obey you as I did.$NEWLINE$So shall I live to speak my father’s words:$NEWLINE$“Happy am I that have a man so bold$NEWLINE$That dares do justice on my proper son;$NEWLINE$And not less happy, having such a son$NEWLINE$That would deliver up his greatness so$NEWLINE$Into the hands of justice.” You did commit me,$NEWLINE$For which I do commit into your hand$NEWLINE$Th' unstainèd sword that you have used to bear,$NEWLINE$With this remembrance: that you use the same$NEWLINE$With the like bold, just, and impartial spirit$NEWLINE$As you have done 'gainst me. There is my hand.$NEWLINE$You shall be as a father to my youth,$NEWLINE$My voice shall sound as you do prompt mine ear,$NEWLINE$And I will stoop and humble my intents$NEWLINE$To your well-practiced wise directions.—$NEWLINE$And, princes all, believe me, I beseech you:$NEWLINE$My father is gone wild into his grave,$NEWLINE$For in his tomb lie my affections,$NEWLINE$And with his spirit sadly I survive$NEWLINE$To mock the expectation of the world,$NEWLINE$To frustrate prophecies, and to raze out$NEWLINE$Rotten opinion, who hath writ me down$NEWLINE$After my seeming. The tide of blood in me$NEWLINE$Hath proudly flowed in vanity till now.$NEWLINE$Now doth it turn and ebb back to the sea,$NEWLINE$Where it shall mingle with the state of floods$NEWLINE$And flow henceforth in formal majesty.$NEWLINE$Now call we our high court of parliament,
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$You’re right, Chief Justice, and you have considered this well. Therefore, keep your position as judge and enforcer. I hope that your honors increase, and that you live to see a son of mine offend and then obey you, as I have. I will live to speak my father’s words: “I am a happy man, to have a man brave enough to punish my own son; and I’m no less happy to have a son that would surrender his greatness, and put himself in the hands of the law.”$NEWLINE$You imprisoned me, and for that I charge you to continue in my service, with this reminder: you must always be as courageous, just, and impartial as you were with me. Shake my hand. You’ll be like a father to me, and I will say whatever it is you whisper in my ear. I will bow to you, and keep myself humble in the face of your wisdom and experience. And princes, believe me, please: my father lies wild in his grave, for he took my recklessness with him when he died. His sober spirit survives in me, and I will flout the world’s expectations. I will prove their prophecies false, and flush out the rotten opinions of those who judged me based on what I once seemed to be.$NEWLINE$My behavior, the tide of my blood, used to flow proudly and vainly. But now, it ebbs and turns back toward the sea, where it will mingle with the ocean’s majesty and flow back through my body with formal dignity. Now I will assemble my parliament, and choose such noble officers and advisors that our great country will be able to march alongside the best governed nations. We’ll become acquainted and familiar

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: And let us choose such limbs of noble counsel$NEWLINE$That the great body of our state may go$NEWLINE$In equal rank with the best governed nation;$NEWLINE$That war, or peace, or both at once, may be$NEWLINE$As things acquainted and familiar to us,$NEWLINE$In which you, father, shall have foremost hand.$NEWLINE$Our coronation done, we will accite,$NEWLINE$As I before remembered, all our state.$NEWLINE$And, God consigning to my good intents,$NEWLINE$No prince nor peer shall have just cause to say$NEWLINE$God shorten Harry’s happy life one day.
paragraphs.translated: with the states of war, peace, or both at once; in this, Chief Justice, my new father, you will be my closest advisor.$NEWLINE$Once my coronation has been completed, I will, as I said before, summon all the nobility. And if God endorses my good intentions, no prince or lord will have reason to say that he wishes God would shorten my happy life by even a single day.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter FALSTAFF, SHALLOW, SILENCE, DAVY, BARDOLPH, and the PAGE$NEWLINE$FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$SHALLOW$NEWLINE$SILENCE$NEWLINE$DAVY$NEWLINE$BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$PAGE
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF, SHALLOW, SILENCE, DAVY, BARDOLPH, and the PAGE enter.$NEWLINE$FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$SHALLOW$NEWLINE$SILENCE$NEWLINE$DAVY$NEWLINE$BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$PAGE

paragraphs.original: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Nay, you shall see my orchard, where, in an arbor, we will$NEWLINE$eat a last year’s pippin of my own graffing, with a dish of$NEWLINE$caraways, and so forth.—Come, cousin Silence.—And then$NEWLINE$to bed.
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$No, you’re going to see my orchard. We’ll sit in an arbor and eat some of the pippin apples I cross-bred last season, along with some caraway seeds and so on. Come on, Silence. Then we’ll go to bed.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Fore God, you have here a goodly dwelling and a rich.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$I swear, you have a good-looking place here, and it’s fancy.

paragraphs.original: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Barren, barren, barren, beggars all, beggars all, Sir John.$NEWLINE$Marry, good air.—Spread, Davy, spread, Davy. Well said,$NEWLINE$Davy.
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Cheap, cheap, cheap. We’re broke, broke, Sir John. But one thing we do have is good air. Set the table, Davy, set the table. Good job, Davy.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$This Davy serves you for good uses. He is your servingman$NEWLINE$and your husband.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$This Davy does a lot for you. He’s your right-hand man as well as your steward.

paragraphs.original: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$A good varlet, a good varlet, a very good varlet, Sir John. By$NEWLINE$the Mass, I have drunk too much sack at supper. A good$NEWLINE$varlet. Now sit down, now sit down.—Come, cousin.
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$A good servant, a very good servant, Sir John. By God, I had too much wine with dinner. A good servant. Now sit down, sit down. Come on, cousin.

paragraphs.original: SILENCE$NEWLINE$Ah, sirrah, quoth he, we shall$NEWLINE$Do nothing but eat and make good cheer,$NEWLINE$(sings) And praise God for the merry year,$NEWLINE$(sings)$NEWLINE$When flesh is cheap and females dear,$NEWLINE$And lusty lads roam here and there$NEWLINE$So merrily,$NEWLINE$And ever among so merrily.
paragraphs.translated: SILENCE$NEWLINE$Ah, Sirrah, he said. We will:$NEWLINE$Do nothing but eat and celebrate,$NEWLINE$(sings) And praise God for this happy year,$NEWLINE$(sings)$NEWLINE$When flesh is cheap but women are costly,$NEWLINE$And lusty men roam here and there,$NEWLINE$So merrily,$NEWLINE$And always so merrily.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$There’s a merry heart!—Good Master Silence, I’ll give you$NEWLINE$a health for that anon.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$That’s a merry heart! Master Silence, I’ll drink a toast to you in a minute.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Give Master Bardolph some wine, Davy.
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Davy, get Master Bardolph some wine.

paragraphs.original: DAVY$NEWLINE$Sweet sir, sit. I’ll be with you anon. Most sweet sir, sit.$NEWLINE$Master page, good master page, sit. Proface. What you want$NEWLINE$in meat, we’ll have in drink, but you must bear. The heart’s$NEWLINE$all.
paragraphs.translated: DAVY$NEWLINE$Sit, kind sir; I’ll be with you in a second. Very kind sir, please sit. Here’s to you! What we lack in food, we make up for in drink. You must endure it; good intentions are what count.

paragraphs.original: Exit DAVY$NEWLINE$DAVY
paragraphs.translated: DAVY exits.$NEWLINE$DAVY

paragraphs.original: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Be merry, Master Bardolph. —And, my little soldier there,$NEWLINE$be merry.
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Enjoy yourself, Master Bardolph, and you, my little soldier, enjoy yourself.

paragraphs.original: SILENCE$NEWLINE$(sings) Be merry, be merry, my wife has all,$NEWLINE$(sings)$NEWLINE$For women are shrews, both short and tall.$NEWLINE$'Tis merry in hall when beards wag all,$NEWLINE$And welcome merry Shrovetide.$NEWLINE$Be merry, be merry.
paragraphs.translated:
SILENCE$NEWLINE$(sings) Enjoy, enjoy! My wife has it all,$NEWLINE$(sings)$NEWLINE$Women are shrews, whether they’re short or they’re tall,$NEWLINE$It’s a merry party when men laugh and joke,$NEWLINE$So let’s enjoy ourselves this
Shrovetide,$NEWLINE$Shrovetide$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$Enjoy, enjoy!

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$I did not think Master Silence had been a man of this mettle.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$I didn’t think Master Silence had this in him.

paragraphs.original: SILENCE$NEWLINE$Who, I? I have been merry twice and once ere now.
paragraphs.translated: SILENCE$NEWLINE$Who, me? I’ve let loose once or twice in my life.

paragraphs.original: Enter DAVY$NEWLINE$DAVY
paragraphs.translated: DAVY enters.$NEWLINE$DAVY

paragraphs.original: DAVY$NEWLINE$(to BARDOLPH) There’s a dish of leather-coats for you.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: DAVY$NEWLINE$(to BARDOLPH) Here’s a dish of red apples for you.

paragraphs.original: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Davy!
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Davy!

paragraphs.original: DAVY$NEWLINE$Your Worship, I’ll be with you straight.—$NEWLINE$(to BARDOLPH) A cup of wine, sir?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: DAVY$NEWLINE$Yes, sir! I’ll be with you in a second. (to BARDOLPH) A cup of wine, sir?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: SILENCE$NEWLINE$(sings) A cup of wine that’s brisk and fine,$NEWLINE$(sings)$NEWLINE$And drink unto thee, leman mine,$NEWLINE$And a merry heart lives long-a.
paragraphs.translated: SILENCE$NEWLINE$(sings) A cup of wine that’s fresh and fine,$NEWLINE$(sings)$NEWLINE$And drink to you, darling mine,$NEWLINE$And a happy heart lives long!

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Well said, Master Silence.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Well said, Master Silence.

paragraphs.original: SILENCE$NEWLINE$And we shall be merry; now comes in the sweet o' th' night.
paragraphs.translated: SILENCE$NEWLINE$And we will enjoy ourselves. Now’s the best time of night.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Health and long life to you, Master Silence.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Here’s to your health and long life, Master Silence.

paragraphs.original: SILENCE$NEWLINE$(sings) Fill the cup, and let it come,$NEWLINE$(sings)$NEWLINE$I’ll pledge you a mile to th' bottom.
paragraphs.translated: SILENCE$NEWLINE$(sings) Fill the cup, and pass it here,$NEWLINE$(sings)$NEWLINE$I’ll drink it to the bottom, even if it’s a mile down.

paragraphs.original: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Honest Bardolph, welcome. If thou wantest anything and$NEWLINE$wilt not call, beshrew thy heart.—$NEWLINE$(to the PAGE) Welcome, my little tiny thief, and welcome$NEWLINE$(to the$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$indeed too. I’ll drink to Master Bardolph, and to all the$NEWLINE$cabileros about London.
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Welcome, honest Master Bardolph. If you want something and don’t ask for it, that’s your tough luck. (to the PAGE) Welcome, my little tiny thief, welcome indeed. I’ll drink to Master Bardolph, and to all the good sports around London.$NEWLINE$(to the$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: DAVY$NEWLINE$I hope to see London once ere I die.
paragraphs.translated: DAVY$NEWLINE$I hope to see London once before I die.

paragraphs.original: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$An I might see you there, Davy!
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$If I see you there, Davy—

paragraphs.original: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$By the Mass, you’ll crack a quart together, ha, will you not,$NEWLINE$Master Bardolph?
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$By God, you’ll break open a quart bottle together, ha! Won’t you, Master Bardolph?

paragraphs.original: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Yea, sir, in a pottle-pot.
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Yessir, in a two-quart glass.

paragraphs.original: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$By God’s liggens, I thank thee. The knave will stick by thee,$NEWLINE$I can assure thee that. He will not out, he. 'Tis true bred!
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$By God’s fingers, I thank you. This rogue will stick with you, I promise you that. He won’t fail, he’s true blue.

paragraphs.original: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$And I’ll stick by him, sir.
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$And I’ll stick with him, sir.

paragraphs.original: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Why, there spoke a king. Lack nothing, be merry.$NEWLINE$One knocks at the door within$NEWLINE$Look who’s at door there, ho. Who knocks?
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Spoken like a king. Take whatever you want: enjoy yourselves!$NEWLINE$Knocking is heard offstage.$NEWLINE$Knocking is heard offstage.$NEWLINE$Hey, see who’s at the door there! Who’s knocking?

paragraphs.original: Exit DAVY$NEWLINE$DAVY
paragraphs.translated: DAVY exits.$NEWLINE$DAVY

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$(to SILENCE) Why, now you have done me right.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$(to SILENCE) You’re really keeping up with me!$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: SILENCE$NEWLINE$(sings) Do me right,$NEWLINE$(sings)$NEWLINE$And dub me knight,$NEWLINE$Samingo.$NEWLINE$Is ’t not so?
paragraphs.translated: SILENCE$NEWLINE$(sings) Keep up with me,$NEWLINE$(sings)$NEWLINE$Then dub me a knight!$NEWLINE$Samingo!$NEWLINE$Samingo$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$Right?

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$'Tis so.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Right.

paragraphs.original: SILENCE$NEWLINE$Is ’t so? Why then, say an old man can do somewhat.
paragraphs.translated: SILENCE$NEWLINE$Right? Then you’ve got to admit that an old man can do some things.

paragraphs.original: Enter DAVY$NEWLINE$DAVY
paragraphs.translated: DAVY returns.$NEWLINE$DAVY

paragraphs.original: DAVY$NEWLINE$An ’t please your Worship, there’s one Pistol come from the$NEWLINE$court with news.
paragraphs.translated: DAVY$NEWLINE$Sir, if I may say so, there’s someone named Pistol here from the royal court. He’s got news.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$From the court? Let him come in.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$From the royal court? Let him in.

paragraphs.original: Enter PISTOL$NEWLINE$PISTOL
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL enters.$NEWLINE$PISTOL

paragraphs.original: How now, Pistol?
paragraphs.translated: What’s up, Pistol!

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Sir John, God save you.
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$God save you, Sir John.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$What wind blew you hither, Pistol?
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$What wind blew you here, Pistol?

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Not the ill wind which blows no man to good. Sweet knight,$NEWLINE$thou art now one of the greatest men in this realm.
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Not the evil wind that blows no one toward any good. Sweet knight, you are now one of the hugest men in the country.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: SILENCE$NEWLINE$By 'r Lady, I think he be, but Goodman Puff of Barson.
paragraphs.translated: SILENCE$NEWLINE$I swear, I think he is—except for the good fellow Puff, from Barson.

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Puff?$NEWLINE$Puff in thy teeth, most recreant coward base!—$NEWLINE$Sir John, I am thy Pistol and thy friend,$NEWLINE$And helter-skelter have I rode to thee,$NEWLINE$And tidings do I bring, and lucky joys,$NEWLINE$And golden times, and happy news of price.
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Puff? Puff in your face, you degenerate coward! Sir John, I’m your Pistol and your friend, and I rode at full tilt to find you here. I bring you reports, and good luck, and golden times, and happy, valuable news.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$I pray thee now, deliver them like a man of this world.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Then please, deliver this news like a human being who lives in this world.

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$A foutre for the world and worldlings base!$NEWLINE$I speak of Africa and golden joys.
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Damn this world, and the vile little people who live in it! I’m talking about Africa, and its golden joys.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$O base Assyrian knight, what is thy news?$NEWLINE$Let King Cophetua know the truth thereof.
paragraphs.translated:
FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Oh, you vulgar Assyrian knight, what is your news? Convey to
King Cophetua the story therein.$NEWLINE$King Cophetua$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: SILENCE$NEWLINE$(sings) And Robin Hood, Scarlet, and John.$NEWLINE$(sings)
paragraphs.translated:
SILENCE$NEWLINE$(sings)
And Robin Hood, Scarlet, and John.$NEWLINE$(sings)$NEWLINE$And Robin Hood, Scarlet, and John$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Shall dunghill curs confront the Helicons,$NEWLINE$And shall good news be baffled?$NEWLINE$Then, Pistol, lay thy head in Furies' lap.
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Will junkyard dogs attack the Muses, goddesses of poetry? Will my good news be thwarted this way? Then Pistol, go ahead and plead with the Furies, the goddesses of revenge.

paragraphs.original: SILENCE$NEWLINE$Honest gentleman, I know not your breeding.
paragraphs.translated: SILENCE$NEWLINE$Honest gentleman, I don’t know what kind of family you’re from.

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Why then, lament therefor.
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$That’s your loss.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Give me pardon, sir. If, sir, you come with news from the$NEWLINE$court, I take it there’s but two ways, either to utter them, or$NEWLINE$to conceal them. I am, sir, under the King in some authority.
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Forgive me saying so, sir, but if you’ve got news from the court, then you have only two choices: you can either tell it or not tell it. I have some authority from the King, you know.

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Under which king, besonian? Speak or die.
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$From which king, you beggar? Speak, or die.

paragraphs.original: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Under King Harry.
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$For King Henry.

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Harry the Fourth, or Fifth?
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Henry the Fourth, or Fifth?

paragraphs.original: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Harry the Fourth.
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$Henry the Fourth.

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$A foutre for thine office!—$NEWLINE$Sir John, thy tender lambkin now is king.$NEWLINE$Harry the Fifth’s the man. I speak the truth.$NEWLINE$When Pistol lies, do this (he makes an obscene gesture) and$NEWLINE$he makes an obscene gesture)$NEWLINE$fig me, like$NEWLINE$The bragging Spaniard.
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Then screw your position! Sir John, your tender little lamb is now the king. Henry the Fifth’s the man, and I speak the truth. When Pistol tells a lie, do this (he makes an obscene gesture) and tell me to go screw myself, like some crazy Spaniard.$NEWLINE$(he makes an obscene gesture)

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$What, is the old king dead?
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$What? Is the old King dead?

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$As nail in door. The things I speak are just.
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$As a doornail: these things I say are true.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Away, Bardolph.—Saddle my horse.—Master Robert$NEWLINE$Shallow, choose what office thou wilt in the land,$NEWLINE$’tis thine. Pistol, I will double-charge thee with dignities.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Get going, Bardolph! Saddle up my horse. Master Robert Shallow, pick whatever job you want in the whole country: it’s yours. Pistol, I’ll pile honors on you.

paragraphs.original: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$O joyful day! I would not take a knighthood for my fortune.
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Oh happy day! I wouldn’t even trade a knighthood for my new, good fortune.

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$What, I do bring good news!
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$There you go! I brought good news!

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Carry Master Silence to bed.—Master Shallow, my Lord$NEWLINE$Shallow, be what thou wilt. I am Fortune’s steward. Get on
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Carry Master Silence to bed. Master Shallow—Lord Shallow—call yourself whatever you want. I’m in

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: thy boots. We’ll ride all night.—O sweet Pistol!—Away,$NEWLINE$Bardolph!
paragraphs.translated: charge of all the luck in the world! Get your boots on. We’ll ride through the night. Oh sweet Pistol! Get going, Bardolph!

paragraphs.original: Exit BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$BARDOLPH
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH exits.$NEWLINE$BARDOLPH

paragraphs.original: Come, Pistol, utter more to me, and withal devise something$NEWLINE$to do thyself good. Boot, boot, Master Shallow. I know the$NEWLINE$young King is sick for me. Let us take any man’s horses. The$NEWLINE$laws of England are at my commandment. Blessed are they$NEWLINE$that have been my friends, and woe to my Lord Chief$NEWLINE$Justice!
paragraphs.translated: Pistol, tell me more, and help me think of something good we can do for you. Boots, boots, Master Shallow! I know the young King is dying to see me. Let’s just take anybody’s horses; I rule the laws of England now! Blessed are those who have been my friends, and watch out, Lord Chief Justice!

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Let vultures vile seize on his lungs also!$NEWLINE$“Where is the life that late I led?” say they.$NEWLINE$Why, here it is. Welcome these pleasant days.
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$May vultures eat out his lungs, too! You know the old saying, “What happened to the life I used to lead?” Well, they’re here; welcome to these pleasant days.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter BEADLES, dragging in MISTRESS QUICKLY and DOLL TEARSHEET$NEWLINE$BEADLES$NEWLINE$MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$DOLL TEARSHEET
paragraphs.translated: BEADLES enter, dragging DOLL TEARSHEET and MISTRESS QUICKLY.$NEWLINE$BEADLES$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$DOLL TEARSHEET$NEWLINE$MISTRESS QUICKLY

paragraphs.original: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$No, thou arrant knave. I would to God that I might die, that$NEWLINE$I might have thee hanged. Thou hast drawn my shoulder out$NEWLINE$of joint.
paragraphs.translated: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$No, you horrible rogue! I wish to God I were dead, so I could have you hanged. You dislocated my shoulder!

paragraphs.original: FIRST BEADLE$NEWLINE$The Constables have delivered her over to me, and she shall$NEWLINE$have whipping cheer enough, I warrant her. There hath been$NEWLINE$a man or two lately killed about her.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST BEADLE$NEWLINE$The street cops handed her over to me, and she’ll be whipped through and through, I promise. She’s been involved in a couple of murders.

paragraphs.original: DOLL TEARSHEET$NEWLINE$Nut-hook, nut-hook, you lie! Come on, I ’ll tell thee what,$NEWLINE$thou damned tripe-visaged rascal: an the child I now go with$NEWLINE$do miscarry, thou wert better thou hadst struck thy mother,$NEWLINE$thou paper-faced villain.
paragraphs.translated: DOLL TEARSHEET$NEWLINE$Pig, Pig! You lie! Come on! I’ll tell you what, you damned flabby-faced moron: if I have a miscarriage now, you’ll wish you’d hit your own mother, you pasty-faced villain!

paragraphs.original: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$O the Lord, that Sir John were come! I would make this a$NEWLINE$bloody day to somebody. But I pray God the fruit of her$NEWLINE$womb might miscarry.
paragraphs.translated: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$Oh God, I wish Sir John would come! He’d make somebody bleed for this. I pray to God that she has a miscarriage!

paragraphs.original: FIRST BEADLE$NEWLINE$If it do, you shall have a dozen of cushions again; you have$NEWLINE$but eleven now. Come, I charge you both go with me, for the$NEWLINE$man is dead that you and Pistol beat amongst you.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST BEADLE$NEWLINE$Well, if she does, you’ll have twelve cushions on your couch again. You have only eleven now, since she’s wearing one of them under her dress. I order both of you to come with me: the man that you two and Pistol beat up is dead.

paragraphs.original: DOLL TEARSHEET$NEWLINE$I’ll tell you what, you thin man in a censer, I will have you$NEWLINE$as soundly swinged for this, you bluebottle rogue, you filthy$NEWLINE$famished correctioner. If you be not swinged, I’ll forswear$NEWLINE$half-kirtles.
paragraphs.translated: DOLL TEARSHEET$NEWLINE$I’ll tell you what, you stick-figure; I’ll have you beaten soundly for this. You blue-coated rogue, you filthy, starving correctioner! If you aren’t walloped for this, I’ll swear off skirts.

paragraphs.original: FIRST BEADLE$NEWLINE$Come, come, you she knight-errant, come.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST BEADLE$NEWLINE$Come on, come on, you little night sinner, come on.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$O God, that right should thus overcome might! Well, of$NEWLINE$sufferance comes ease.
paragraphs.translated: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$Oh God! I can’t believe that right is overcoming might! Well, challenges build character.

paragraphs.original: DOLL TEARSHEET$NEWLINE$Come, you rogue, come, bring me to a justice.
paragraphs.translated: DOLL TEARSHEET$NEWLINE$Come on, you bastard, come on. Bring me to a judge.

paragraphs.original: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$Ay, come, you starved bloodhound.
paragraphs.translated: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$Yeah, come on, you starved dog.

paragraphs.original: DOLL TEARSHEET$NEWLINE$Goodman Death, Goodman Bones!
paragraphs.translated: DOLL TEARSHEET$NEWLINE$Master Death! Master Bones!

paragraphs.original: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$Thou atomy, thou!
paragraphs.translated: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$You skeleton, you!

paragraphs.original: DOLL TEARSHEET$NEWLINE$Come, you thin thing, come, you rascal.
paragraphs.translated: DOLL TEARSHEET$NEWLINE$Come on, you thin thing; come on, you lean deer!

paragraphs.original: FIRST BEADLE$NEWLINE$Very well.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST BEADLE$NEWLINE$Very well.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter two GROOMS, strewing rushes$NEWLINE$GROOMS
paragraphs.translated:
Two
GROOMS enter, strewing rushes to cover the floors.$NEWLINE$GROOMS$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: FIRST GROOM$NEWLINE$More rushes, more rushes.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST GROOM$NEWLINE$More rushes; more rushes.

paragraphs.original: SECOND GROOM$NEWLINE$The trumpets have sounded twice.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND GROOM$NEWLINE$The trumpets have blown twice.

paragraphs.original: FIRST GROOM$NEWLINE$'Twill be two o'clock ere they come from the coronation.$NEWLINE$Dispatch, dispatch.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST GROOM$NEWLINE$It’ll be two o'clock before they arrive from the coronation. Hurry, hurry.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter FALSTAFF, SHALLOW, PISTOL, BARDOLPH, and PAGE$NEWLINE$FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$SHALLOW$NEWLINE$PISTOL$NEWLINE$BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$PAGE
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF, SHALLOW, PISTOL, BARDOLPH, and the PAGE enter.$NEWLINE$FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$SHALLOW$NEWLINE$PISTOL$NEWLINE$BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$PAGE

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Stand here by me, Master Robert Shallow. I will make the$NEWLINE$King do you grace. I will leer upon him as he comes by, and$NEWLINE$do but mark the countenance that he will give me.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Stand here near me, Master Robert Shallow. I’ll make the King do good things for you: I’ll throw him a look as he passes by. Just watch the face he’ll make at me.

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$God bless thy lungs, good knight!
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$God bless your lungs, good knight.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Come here, Pistol, stand behind me.—(to SHALLOW) O, if I$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$had had time to have made new liveries, I would have$NEWLINE$bestowed the thousand pound I borrowed of you. But ’tis no$NEWLINE$matter. This poor show doth better. This doth infer the zeal$NEWLINE$I had to see him.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Come here, Pistol. Stand behind me. (to SHALLOW) Oh, if I’d had time to make new clothes I would have spent the thousand pounds I borrowed from you. But it doesn’t matter. These poor clothes are better; it shows how desperate I was to see him.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$It doth so.
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$It does indeed.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$It shows my earnestness of affection—
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$It shows how sincerely I love him—

paragraphs.original: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$It doth so.
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$It does indeed.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$My devotion—
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$My devotion—

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$It doth, it doth, it doth.
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$It does, it does, it does.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$As it were, to ride day and night, and not to deliberate, not$NEWLINE$to remember, not to have patience to shift me—
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$In a word, to ride all night; not to stop and think, not to dawdle, not to take the time to change my clothes—

paragraphs.original: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$It is best, certain.
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$It is best, no doubt about it.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$But to stand stained with travel and sweating with desire to$NEWLINE$see him, thinking of nothing else, putting all affairs else in$NEWLINE$oblivion, as if there were nothing else to be done but to see$NEWLINE$him.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Standing here filthy from traveling, and sweating with my desire to see him; thinking of nothing else, disregarding everything, as if the only thing in the world that mattered was seeing him.

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$'Tis semper idem, for obsque hoc nihil est;$NEWLINE$semper idem$NEWLINE$obsque hoc nihil est$NEWLINE$’tis all in every part.
paragraphs.translated:
PISTOL$NEWLINE$That’s how it is. Nothing else matters.
Semper idem. Obsque hoc nihil est.$NEWLINE$Semper idem. Obsque hoc nihil est$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$'Tis so indeed.
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW$NEWLINE$That’s exactly right.

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$My knight, I will inflame thy noble liver, and make thee$NEWLINE$rage. Thy Doll and Helen of thy noble thoughts is in base$NEWLINE$durance and contagious prison, Haled thither by most$NEWLINE$mechanical and dirty hand. Rouse up revenge from ebon den$NEWLINE$with fell Alecto’s snake, for Doll is in. Pistol speaks nought$NEWLINE$but truth.
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Knight, I’ll fire up your noble liver and make you enraged. Doll, the goddess of your thoughts, is imprisoned in a horrible jail, tossed there by a heartless and filthy hand. Stoke up dark revenge from your deepest belly and set loose the serpents of hell. Doll is in. Pistol speaks nothing but the truth.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$I will deliver her.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$I’ll set her free.

paragraphs.original: Shouts within, and the trumpets sound
paragraphs.translated: Shouts are heard offstage. Trumpets play.

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$There roared the sea, and trumpet-clangor sounds.
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$That was the roar of the sea. The clanging trumpet sounds!

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter PRINCE HENRY and his train, the Lord CHIEF JUSTICE among them$NEWLINE$PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$CHIEF JUSTICE
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY enters with a procession of attendants, including the CHIEF JUSTICE.$NEWLINE$PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$CHIEF JUSTICE

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$God save thy Grace, King Hal, my royal Hal.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$God save your grace, King Hal! My royal Hal!

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$The heavens thee guard and keep, most royal imp of fame!
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$The heavens guard and protect you, you royal child of fame!

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$God save thee, my sweet boy!
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$God save you, my sweet boy!

paragraphs.original: KING$NEWLINE$My Lord Chief Justice, speak to that vain man.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$My Lord Chief Justice, go speak to that arrogant man.

paragraphs.original: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$(to FALSTAFF) Have you your wits? Know you what ’tis to$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$speak?
paragraphs.translated: CHIEF JUSTICE$NEWLINE$(to FALSTAFF) Have you lost your mind? Do you know what you’re doing, talking like that?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$My King, my Jove, I speak to thee, my heart!
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$My King! My God! I’m talking to you, my heart!

paragraphs.original: KING$NEWLINE$I know thee not, old man. Fall to thy prayers.$NEWLINE$How ill white hairs become a fool and jester.$NEWLINE$I have long dreamt of such a kind of man,$NEWLINE$So surfeit-swelled, so old, and so profane;$NEWLINE$But being awaked, I do despise my dream.$NEWLINE$Make less thy body hence, and more thy grace;$NEWLINE$Leave gormandizing.
